I think it is well known to the Australian communityâand it should be to the Howard governmentâthat terrorist groups, including al-Qaeda and its affiliates, have used ammonium nitrate as part of their deadly campaigns. If you have any doubt about that, I simply say to the Australian community: cast your mind back to the 1993 World Trade Centre bombing, the Oklahoma bombing in 1995 and attacks on embassies in the 1990s. Ammonium nitrate is often the source of attacks doing the maximum damage by terrorist organisations throughout the world. Yet we have got foreign flag vessels plying the Australian coastline without proper checking of the crews. Often engaged in tax evasion and serious issues relating to environmental concerns, they are carrying ammonium nitrate around the Australian coastline.

This week's estimates hearings also revealed that the government has made no attemptâand I stress thisâto restrict the carriage of these cargoes, despite all of its empty security rhetoric on these issues. On the contrary, since 1 July 2004 five single-voyage permits have been issued for the carriage of ammonium nitrate between Australian ports. That means that 10,800 tonnes of this highly dangerous fertiliserânot an insignificant amountâwere carried under these five permits. The Howard government owes the Australian community an explanation about this during the course of this debate.

Let us put that into context. I refer to in incident that occurred involving an ammonium nitrate vessel in April 1947 in Texas City. This incident involved a ship, the Grandcamp, which caught alight while loading 2,300 tonnes of ammonium nitrate. As a result the ship exploded, an explosion reported to have been heard 150 miles away. Worse still, 600 people lost their lives and more than 2,000 were injured. Bear in mind that at that time Texas City had a population of around 16,000 people, 2,000 of whom were injured and 600 killed.

Just imagine the consequences of such an incident at an Australian port, perhaps Sydney Harbour or the port of Melbourne. Imagine if a foreign ship operating under a licence were to fall into the hands of a terrorist group and the cargo of the ship was ammonium nitrate. Just imagine it was in the port of Brisbane, Fremantle, Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney, Launceston or Darwin. Just imagine the damage. Imagine the consequences of such an incident in the loss of Australian lives and the potential injury to the Australian community. Imagine the damage it could do not just to human beings but also to the social and economic fabric of the port.

The opposition therefore contend that the carriage of dangerous goods such as ammonium nitrate by foreign ships must cease now. We regard it as part of Australia's fight against terrorism to guarantee that Australian shipping is given a fair go and to also take out of the hands of foreign flag vessels the potential risk to the safety and wellbeing of the Australian community. I therefore believe that the safest way to transport ammonium nitrate and other fertilisers around Australia is on Australian ships with Australian crews.

In terms of the training of Australian seafarers, we have a college of excellence in Tasmania that was originally developed to give young Australians the opportunity to train and be gainfully employed in the seafaring industry. That Maritime Training College is unfortunately more devoted now to export earnings through the training of overseas seafarers rather than the training of Australians to take up employment in the Australian shipping industry. I suggest to the House that, because of this government's lack of initiatives, nothing has been done to encourage the development of new ships for the Australian coastal shipping industry and international shipping. Our fleet is ageing and there is an urgent requirement for the government to turn its attention to assisting and renewing the shipping industry.

This takes me to the issue of the importance of a secure ship. When a secure ship with a secure crew sails out of one secure port and into another the exposure to any risk is minimal, I believe. An Australian ship crewed by Australians is secure because they are vitally concerned with Australia's national interest. That is important because, as we all appreciate, Australia is an island nation heavily dependent on imports and exports. As we all understand, we are experiencing an exponential growth in the domestic freight task. We are more than ever dependent on shipping as a key element of the transport logistics chain in the same way that we have to pay proper attention to a national highway network and the need to upgrade our rail freight system.

But what have we got? We have the Howard government actively engaged in destroying the Australian shipping industry. Its policy, reaffirmed on numerous occasions by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, is to encourage the cheapest ships in the world to ply the Australian coastline. These vessels are cheaper than Australian vessels because of low crew wages, subsidies from foreign governments and the fact that Australian laws simply do not apply to them. Unfortunately these ships, on some occasions, operate with poor maintenance, low wages and substandard and, in some instances, inhumane conditions for crews and with no regard for environmental or other standards. In the pursuit of cheap shipping rates, the Howard government pays no regard to Australia's national interest. We saw this recently with reports that foreign ships are potentially damaging the Great Barrier Reef by throwing garbage into the sea. From an environmental and tourism perspective that is unacceptable to Australia.

Why would a large island nation, isolated from its major trading partners, with a growing domestic and international freight task and increasing pressure on its land transport infrastructure want to deliberately discourage investment and skills development in its maritime sector? Why would any nation so dependent on promoting itself as a leading tourism nation place at risk its pristine coastlineâa key component of the tourism sector? Why would we support guest labour operating in this sector on substandard wages and conditions when we would not tolerate this in any other industry? Can you imagine Australia letting Filipino or Indonesian truck drivers or shopkeepers into Australia to take Australian jobs, being paid Third World wages or potentially putting Australians at risk? I do not think so. I do not think any political party would go to the next election with such a policy, yet when it comes to shipping policy it is actively and aggressively pursued by the Howard government. It also raises serious issues in relation to defence.

Finally, I would like to touch on a very important role for the Australian shipping industry, and that is as our fourth line of defence. The history of Australia shows how important the merchant navy was to defending Australia. It was exceptionally important. That is why we have an international maritime day each year to acknowledge the contribution made by the merchant navy. There is no doubt that, by running down the Australian shipping industry, the Howard government has also eroded our fourth line of defence. It has not just put Australia at risk of potential terrorist attacks with respect to the movement of ammonium nitrate; it has also deliberately eroded the fourth line of defence. The government has ignored the sacrifice merchant seafarers have traditionally made to keep Australia's coast safe and our sea lanes open.

We should not forget that in World War II more than 30,000 Allied merchant seafarers were killed and more than 4,600 were recorded missing. We not only owe it to those fallen seafarers to ensure that our shipping industry has a future, but we also need to ensure that we have a merchant fleet capable of contributing to the defence of Australia, should the need ever arise. It should also be remembered that, in recent times, Australian seafarers supported the INTERFET force deployment in East Timor. In recognition of the role of Australian seafarers, General Peter Cosgrove wrote to the Maritime Union of Australia in October 1999 acknowledging the vital role played by Australian civilian ships in supporting the Australian military contingent.

In closing, I remind the government that Australia can be a nation of shippers and a shipping nation. It is all about leadership and a willingness to give it a go. The opposition believes that in the national interest, to introduce certainty and encouragement, investment is required in the Australian shipping industry. I therefore call on the minister for transport and Deputy Prime Minister to cease the practice of abusing the cabotage provisions of the Navigation Act. These provisions were designed as a fallback to ensure availability of service, not to destroy a vital industry simply on the basis that it is unionised. It is time the Howard government listened and recognised the security, national interest and defence benefits that come from a viable shipping industry. Flag of convenience shipping is cheap, un-Australian and unacceptable in terms of our need to protect our coastline, for employment and defence, and also our need to stand up in the international fight against terrorism. There is no way foreign ships should be carrying ammonium nitrate around the Australian coast.

talk.start.para: âThe debate relating to the Navigation Amendment Bill 2004 has been wide ranging. I appreciate the comments of those opposite, particularly the member for Batman, who covered a range of issues without any real solutions to the matter of cabotage. I will be asking the farmers how they will get their nitrate. The member for Batman also covered the permit argument and of course referred to the MUA. On any assessment, the changes at the waterfront have been hugely successful, and the ports and waterfront work so much better since those changes that took place in 1998.

speech.para: For the record, the Navigation Amendment Bill amends the Navigation Act 1912 relating to the safety of ships at sea, and I will refer to those matters in the rest of my speech in this second reading debate. The legislative steps require assessors of nautical experience to advise the court on a breach of regulations relating to the prevention of collisions and the display on ships of light and signals. Fundamentally this bill is trying to bring about a safer sea and to prevent collisions, which happen from time to time. The bill revises the penalties, particularly near ice. Each person in charge of a ship involved in a collision is required to give necessary help and assistance, stay by the ship until help arrives and give information about the ship to the person in charge of the other ship. So it is a good neighbour attitude and reinforces the thrust of the previous Navigation Act, which was changed by the unreported Victorian court ruling in November 2003.

That is the technical bill before the parliament and, like other speakers, I wish to refer to some broader issues. I was delighted that the member for Oxley referred to the `ships of shame'. I am pleased that the member for Wakefield was talking about maritime matters; that might be the first time the member for Wakefield has spoken about maritime matters for some 20 years or so. I am going to refer to a number of reports that have come out over the years: Ships of shame: inquiry into ship safety; Ships of shameâA sequel: inquiry into ship safety; Ship safe;and another report called Beyond the midnight oil. Over the years, I have been involved in these reports and discussions about the safety of ships, crews, maritime matters and, as the member for Batman in his wide-ranging speech alluded to, matters of cabotage, flags of convenience ships and all those matters that impose upon Australian shipping.

Let me say from the outset that I accept the proposition that Australia is an island and depends very much upon shipping to move exports to other nations around the world and bring imports in. So the shipping lanes, the availability of ships and the availability of good port facilities is critical for the welfare of all Australians as are key those areas of transport that move the goods from the ports to areas of population. The ships of shame inquiry in 1992 was chaired by the Hon. Peter Morris, and Minister Vaile, who I see at the table, participated in the second inquiry of the ships of shameâhe may even have been the chairman at one stage, following on the outstanding work of Peter Morris. I wish to put on the record that the ships of shame and subsequent inquiries have had an influence internationally. The attitudes of Australian governments and those reports have had an impact internationally in trying to bring about a sense of balance in matters of crewing, flags of convenience, quality shipping and safety.
The member for Batman raised matters of ship safety in his wide-ranging speech. Ship safe was a report about ship safety that identified some of the risk factors in shipping. It said:

quote.para: The underlying (and interacting factors) which undermine ship safety are:

Owners, operators and charterers faced commercial pressures due to low freight rates and the strong supply of shipping relative to demand. Responsibly operated ships continue to be required to compete with substandard ships. Classifications societies, insurers and flag states also continue to be subject to market forces, raising the danger of standards being compromised in the pursuit of market position.

speech.para: The member for Batman I think quite fairly alluded to those problems of competition, of substandard shipsâparticularly the bulk ore carriersâand pressure in international freight rates that undermine the safety of ships and crews. The next point the Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform noted in the report was:

quote.para: The increasing globalisation of the shipping industry and the scattering of responsibility centres continue to make it difficult to supervise and enforce uniform practices and standards in such areas as shipbuilding, operations and language. For example, AMSA asserted that:
...we have hundreds of shipyards building ships nominally under the one standard, but under a myriad of interpretations.

speech.para: So the committee over the years have seen this assessment of ship standards, ageing ships, the insurance of different types of vessels and the inability of one nation or another, be it Australia, a European country or the USA, to make one standard of ship that is safe. The committee report went on to say:

quote.para: Inadequate accountability mechanisms mean that the beneficial owner of the ship is not always required to face the consequences of breaches of ship safety.

speech.para: As most members would be aware, that is the flags of convenience, where the ship owner, the operator of the ship and the crew could all be in different jurisdictions. The final comment was that not all participants in the industry demonstrate respect for human life. That was the thrust of both Ship safe and Ships of shame, that international shippers showed no regard for those crews from Third World countries and were prepared to let the older rust buckets, as they were referred to, slip to the bottom of the ocean with great loss of lifeâparticularly those ore carriers to Western Australia, and the Kirke, which has been referred to in some of those reports. They were certainly very questionable craft, but one or two voyages could make considerable sums of money for the owners, wherever they might be.

Other speakers have referred to international safety. The difficulty is: how do you implement a code? How do you enforce it on those recalcitrant shipowners and operators who flagrantly ignore sensible safety arrangements? There has been an International Safety Management Code which was mandated by the SOLAS convention and became binding on 128 countries, which account for more than 97 per cent of world merchant shipping tonnage. So there has been an attempt by those more responsible seafaring nations to join a code. It came into force on 1 July 1998 for passenger ships, high-speed craft, oil, chemical and gas carriers, bulk carriers and high-speed cargo craft. It was implemented in July 2002 for other cargo ships over 500 tonnes and mobile offshore drilling units. So we can see, amongst all the argument, that an attempt has been initiated by Australian governmentsâon both sides, I might sayâto bring about a better system of international rule in an area which is fraught with difficulty.

Regarding ship safety, another report called Beyond the midnight oil talked about fatigue. In Ships of Shame and the follow-up to it, we talked a lot about the fatigue of crews, pilots and captains as a possible cause of collisions at sea. I have always been particularly interested in the Exxon Valdez incident in 1989, which was brought about by ongoing fatigue. I would like to quote from what Professor Dinges told a parliamentary committee. He said:

quote.para: ... the demanned vessel meant there were fewer crew on board to do the work. On the high seas, that worked out well, but when you pulled into the Valdez port and had to load out and were under terrific time pressure, it meant that the first officer was awake 36 hours, could not go any more and finally went to bed. It meant that the second officer had been awake too long, well past the hours of service. He went to bed. And it meant that the man at the helm at the critical time as they left that port through Prince William Sound was a third officer, with limited experience.

speech.para: We all know what happened: the Valdez had a horrific accident and the spillage was horrendous. That was brought about by fatigue, a factor of crew management.

The whole issue of shipping around the Australian coastlineâthe cabotage argument, the permit argumentâis one we could probably debate forever, but, in terms of the bill before the House, I would like to refer to the international position. The Hon. Peter Morris, who is chairman of the International Commission on Shipping, brought out a report in March 2001 called Ships, Slaves and Competitionâa follow-up to the Ships of Shame report that was before this Houseâwhich made a number of recommendations. It looked at the international problem faced by shippers, crews, shipowners, classification societies and those who want to bring about a better set of international shipping arrangements. Peter Morris is now a figure of international reputation in the area of ship safety, crewing and improving the general standard of international shipping. Australia can be proud of Peter Morris's contribution and of this parliament's contribution to this whole debate, which seemed up until that time to be insolvable. Because of the difficulties of having flag state ships with foreign crews from Third World countries, who were being paid low wages and working in substandard conditions, it was felt that nobody could do anything about itâuntil we did something here in Australia.

The report recommends that crewing be looked at fairly carefully. Seafarers who have been trained in the Philippines or in other areas of repute and who have fraudulent certificates are an ongoing difficulty. Then there are the employment practices which all members have alluded to. The difficulties on some of these substandard ships with regard to the number of crew, their conditions, their food, hours of work and all those things have almost been impossible to police, but I think progress is being made. There are problems with inspecting ships to ensure they meet quality standards. There are problems associated with Lloyds's insurance assessment and inspection of oil carriers and chemical distribution ships. There are problems with non-payment and abandonment of crewsâthey are not paid and they are just left out in the cold. There are recommendations that crews on cruise ships be provided with better conditions. It can be a problem to work out who actually owns the ships. As we mentioned, with flag states, the multiple ownership of ships is a problemâno-one can actually identify who has final responsibility.

Flag states continue to be a problem. Host governments are prepared to run flag ships for taxation reasons. With some of their taxation regimes being more in line with those of Western countries, internationally people are starting to put some pressure on them to have quality ships. Classification societies have had a number of difficulties in classifying ships for insurance purposesâdistinguishing older ships from those of a younger age and putting genuine insurance premiums on those ships. Australia has done a particularly good job of looking after ports and identifying whether the ships that come here meet Australian standards. The member for Batman can be pleased with that part of Australia's regime. The ships that come here can be detained for anywhere between 24 hours to a week if they do not meet international standards. The International Maritime Organisation is attempting to get some sort of international agreement about the quality of ships. The International Labour Organisationâand I support this approachâis trying to look after some of the seafarers because they have had a pretty rough time.

I commend that report. I also commend the position Australia has taken in leading the way. Contrary to the comments of those opposite, there has been an attempt to improve shipping. Some of the more responsible importing and exporting companies in Australia are now using quality shipping. Because of port control, they have decided not to use second- and third-class shipsâ`old rustbuckets', as many members have referred to themâwhich have the potential to sink very quickly.

Australia has taken the lead. Internationally, we have provided some very good benchmarks of performance. Australia needs quality ships for exporting and importing, and in my assessment, over the 10 years that I have been interested in maritime matters, the movement has been in the right direction. The ships of lesser quality are not coming to Australia because of the port control. They know that if they come here and they have a defect in their steelwork, safety measures or lifeboats they will be detained for a period of days and that will affect their bottom line.

I commend the bill. I commend the general sentiment that the maritime industry is critical to Australia, and that all of us need to make sure we improve the quality of the personnel and the management. Now that we have improved the operation of the ports we can look forward to Australia's exports moving into world trade in a more expeditious manner.

talker.name: Lloyd, Jim, MP
Mr LLOYD
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: âI would like to thank the members for Oxley, Batman, Wakefield and Corangamite for their contributions to the second reading debate on the Navigation Amendment Bill 2004. I would, however, like to express my disappointment that whilst the opposition are supporting this bill theyâparticularly the member for Batmanâchose to use this debate to launch a political attack on the government and its general support of shipping in Australia. I speak as a former card carrying member of the Firemen and Deckhands Union and as a member of the Merchant Service Guild, so I have a personal understanding of the needs of seafarers around the Australian coastline.

speech.para: Unfortunately, there have been some 21 collisions involving fishing boats in the last 10 years. Tragically, two of these collisions resulted in the death of a crew member of the fishing boat. The Navigation Amendment Bill 2004 complements an Australia wide safety awareness campaign currently being conducted by the Australian Transport Safety Bureauâthe ATSB. The purpose of the campaign is to reduce the number of collisions between trading ships and commercial fishing boats by raising the awareness of commercial fishermen of the contributory factors which have been identified by the ATSB in its investigation of collisions.

As part of the campaign, members of the ATSB Marine Investigation Unit have begun a series of informal face-to-face discussions with commercial fishermen in fishing ports around Australia. The first of those meetings was held in Eden in December 2004. In December 2004 the ATSB released a safety bulletin aimed specifically at the crew of fishing boats. In addition, it published a series of informative articles in commercial fishing industry magazines and newsletters.

It is not only the crews of fishing boats who need to be aware of the possibility of collisions. The crews of trading ships also need to be aware of the possibility of a collision with a smaller vessel. Recognising this, in 2000 the ATSB published three safety bulletins on fishing boats, safety and fatigue. Those safety bulletins target the crews of ships trading on the Australian coast. In addition to the campaign, the Navigation Amendment Bill 2004 will strengthen the legislative regime which is intended to enforce requirements to comply with the internationally recognised collisions regulations, by amending the Navigation Act 1912âthe principal Commonwealth act relating to safety of ships.

Two of the amendments will correct deficiencies in the Navigation Act highlighted by an unreported decision of the Victorian County Court in November 2003, by, firstly, removing the requirement for assessors of nautical experience to advise the court in a prosecution for a breach of the collisions regulation. There is no mechanism for the appointment of nautical assessors. Secondly, the bill will clarify that a breach of the collisions regulation may be prosecuted on indictment. In addition, the bill will revise some penalties, including the penalty that applies where there is a failure to render assistance to a vessel in distress. In conclusion, again I thank those members who contributed to the debate on this bill, and I would like to thank the good officials of my department who also worked to put this bill together.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
