This issue is about showing a basic level of respect for the contributions of elderly Australiansâand the government should be working to find solutions to these problems instead of just watching from the sidelines.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005. In the five minutes afforded to me this afternoon prior to question time, I would like to focus on the issue of roads in the electorate of Paterson. I was awoken this morning by one of my media outlets that informed me that last night there was, yet again, a serious smash on the Tea Gardens turn-off on the Pacific Highway. Work is under way nowâthanks to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, Mr Lloyd, who provided support and assistanceâto upgrade the Pacific Highway between Karuah and the Viney Creek turn-off. One of the key issues in the development of this road, planned for by the New South Wales state government, is that there has been absolutely no allowance for a flyover.

speech.para: The accident occurred last night simply because a vehicle had to go across the oncoming traffic, which was only doing 90 kilometres an hour. There was a collision and a person is now in a serious condition in hospital. As this road is upgraded we are going to see vehicles travelling past this intersection at 110 kilometres an hour. If a car is travelling with a caravan attachedâbecause the Hawks Nest-Tea Gardens area is an extremely popular tourist destinationâcanvassing a vehicle with a caravan on the back in front of vehicles doing 110 an hour defies any logical stance on safety. I will be writing to Mr Costa this week urging him, as the new roads minister in New South Wales, to have a look at this intersection. Communities in my electorate such as North Arm Cove, Tea Gardens and Hawks Nest are up in arms at the state of the planning for this road.

Prior to the election, I had Minister Lloyd up to see the commencement of works at Nabiac. That is a section of road from Bundacree Creek right through to Nabiac. There is supposed to be a community consultative group for issues pertaining to these roadworks. The state government has established these community consultative groups in name only because each and every time these community groups go to meet with the RTA they meet a stonewall approach. I believe it is time that the planners and developers who look at this road infrastructure in New South Wales, the RTA, take into serious consideration the accident rates that occur when you do not have a flyover in place. Every time I hear of an accident or a fatality on these roads in my electorate it drives straight through me because I can feel the pain of those who are left behind and suffering. I urge the state government in New South Wales to seriously reconsider the planning approach that it takes to the upgrading of the highway, and in particular the approach it takes to flyovers in the region.

We were very fortunate during the election that the Prime Minister decided to invest an additional $10 million in roadworks in Paterson. This road work will include the works between Dungog and Raymond Terrace and an area on Lakes Way near the Seal Rocks turn-off. We were caught out by the state government in the 2001 election when we committed $20 million to the Bucketts Way. We expected that the New South Wales Labor government would do the honourable thing and match the $20 million that we were investing on a state road. They did not. So the $10 million that we have committed to these roads in the Paterson shire has a riding clause that it must be matched by the New South Wales government. We will wait and see whether they treat roadworks and motorists' safety as a priority.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 2 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 97. The debate may resume at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
âI inform the House that the Treasurer will be absent from question time today.

speech.para: Opposition membersâOh!

talk.start.para: âI know you miss him; I know you do, and he misses you. We all miss him. He is attending the annual Treasury-Finance portfolio discussions in New Zealand. In the Treasurer's absence I will answer questions on his behalf.
âI suppose the real question is: does the Prime Minister miss him?
âThe Leader of the Opposition will get to his question.

âMy question is to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the National Water Initiative, agreed at the COAG meeting in Canberra on 25 June 2004. Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the rationale behind his commitment at that meeting to the application of full cost recovery pricing for water in both urban and rural sectors? Has there been any change to that rationale? Has that caused the Commonwealth to review its commitment to the principle of full cost recovery? If so, what is the nature of that change and what is the government's position in relation to full cost recovery for water?

âThat is a very technical and well-researched question and I will do my very best, without any notice, to answer it. The National Water Initiative is the greatest single initiative to address the problem of water shortage in our country for generations. I welcome the fact that at last we have an expression of commitment to that initiative from a political leader from Western Australia because, when the initiative was signed, the Premier of Western Australia, Dr Gallop, held out and thereby denied to the farmers of Western Australia the opportunity to participate. The Leader of the Opposition asks me specifically why a provision relating to full cost recovery was included. I would, in addition to what I am about to say, examine the papers relating to that decision to see if there were further things, but I would have thought, if we are to have any kind of hope of dealing with the problem of water shortages in this country, we have got to in the future send more accurate market signals.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House whether the Kyoto protocol will be effective in reducing greenhouse gas emissions? Is the minister aware of any alternative views?

âI thank the member for Wentworth for his question. I know he and most membersâprobably all membersâof this House share the view that climate change is an issue that has to be addressed. The international community needs to address this issue. But it is the view of this government that the problem with the Kyoto protocol is that it does not address the problem. If you actually look at what the Kyoto protocol is intended to achieve, it is intended to reduce global emissions by just one per cent below what they would have otherwise been within the target period. In other words, emissions will still be some 40 per cent higher in 2010 than they would have been in 1990. I think, if the public and the international community were aware of this, they would be less enthusiastic about Kyoto. The international community is right: the issue of climate change must be addressed. But Kyoto is not addressing it.

answer.para: The Kyoto protocol has set targetsâbut how are countries going in meeting those targets? Of the countries with targets, at the moment the current projection is that Canada will be 25 per cent above its target. Yes, it has ratified the Kyoto protocol, but it will be 25 per cent above its Kyoto target. Japan will be 13 per cent above it; Denmark, a member of the European Union, will be 38 per cent above its Kyoto target; and Ireland, 27 per cent. If you take all 25 countries in the European Union at the moment, the projection is that they will be some eight per cent overshooting their target.

The point here is: if the Kyoto protocol is such a great idea, why is it doing nothing to address climate change? Our answer to that is that in this country we are spending $1.8 billion to address this issue and we are on targetâwe are on, if you like, our Kyoto target. So, whilst we do not believe in the Kyoto process for very good reason, because the Kyoto process is not working and is not workable, nevertheless we are able to make a substantial contribution ourselves to addressing this issue. It is the view of this government that the international community needs to get together and work through ideas which will seriously address this problem, not resort to the sort of stuntsmanship that we have seen from the opposition on this issue over the last few days, and ensure that the international community is driven more by substantial policy outcomes than the mere symbolism which is all that Kyoto amounts to.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister recall his comments during the election at the opening of the Gladesville campaign office when he said:

quote.para: Well we're certainly, first and foremost, we're offering a continuation of the low interest rates of the last eight and a half years.

question.para: With markets now anticipating a 0.5 per cent increase in rates, won't your government's failure to deliver the continuation of current interest rates add $148 to the monthly repayments of new home buyers in Sydney?

talk.start.para: âNo.

âMy question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Would the Prime Minister advise the House of recent developments in the Western Australian economy? Are there any risks to Western Australia's economic outlook?

âI thank the member for Hasluck for his question. I can report that Western Australia, being part of Australia, has enjoyed the wonderful economic conditions of the last nine years. I think it is fair to say that, whenever the national economy of Australia performs well, the premiers of Australiaâwhatever their political stripe may beâtry to claim credit for the economic growth in their own states. But the reality is that the federal government is responsible for the economic health of this country. That means, when the national economy is doing badly, the federal government is to blame, and, when the national economy is doing well, the federal government is entitled to take some of the credit. So it is with the economy of Western Australia.

answer.para: I have noticed with interest in the current election campaign that the Western Australian Premier is asking the people of Western Australia to re-elect him on the grounds of the strength of the Western Australian economy. Without in any way denigrating the contribution of those Australians who live in Western Australia, let me say that the strength of the Western Australian economyâwhich is undoubtedâis due overwhelmingly to the economic policies of the coalition government, just as the strength of the Queensland economy, the strength of the New South Wales economy, the strength of the South Australian economy and the strength of the Tasmanian economy are.

The message that I would like to convey is that Western Australia could be doing even better if it had a state government that followed policies that were more supportive of the national government in a number of important areas. Let us take the very important area of industrial relations. The rate of working days lost in Western Australia due to industrial disputes has trebled since the year 2001. By June 2004 Western Australia's rate of 121 working days lost per thousand employees was almost twice the national average of 67. It is right to say, as Western Australian premiers of both political complexions have said to me over the years, that Western Australia may have only 11 per cent of the population but it contributes 28 per cent of the export income of the nation. It is also fair to say that there is no reason that Western Australia cannot have an industrial record the equal of the national average and the equal of the best that is achieved around Australia. That can happen if Western Australia has a change of state government.

Let me say of the alternative Premier of Western Australia, Colin Barnett, whom I know well, that he is rightly making an issue in this campaign of taking decisions and not dithering about decisions being taken by government because, as minister for resources and energies in the 1990s, for example, he was the driving force behind the Dampier to Perth gas pipeline. I know that that is an example of the kind of focus that he will be able to bring to the government of that wonderful state if he is elected Premier on 26 February.

talk.start.para: âI inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon His Excellency Mr Gran Persson, Prime Minister of Sweden, accompanied by Her Excellency Mrs Karin Ehnbom-Palmquist, the Swedish Ambassador. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

speech.para: Honourable membersâHear, hear!

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister. I think the Prime Minister will find that Western Australians think they are responsible for Western Australia's prosperity, and they may well tell him that when he goes there.
âI would ask the Leader of the Opposition to come to his question.
âBut my question to the Prime Minister is not about that. I ask the Prime Minister if he is concerned by the IMF's recent warning:

quote.para: ... the new package unveiled in the 2004 Budget could pose some risk to the medium-term outlook. ... The mission noted that the short-term stimulatory effect ... could complicate monetary policy ...

question.para: Does the Prime Minister agree with the IMF's view that the effect of his government's fiscal policy decisions has been to complicate monetary policy?

talk.start.para: âI have read a number of reports on the Australian economy in recent years, in recent months, in recent weeks, authored by bodies such as the IMF and the OECD. As the Leader of the Opposition knows, the totality of those reports indicates that the Australian economy is seen around the world as an outstanding example of reform and good performance.

âMy question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware of media reports concerning announcements of Australian government funding in the electorate of Brand, in particular for a project to build a marina at Rockingham? What do these media reports show?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Canning for his question. Yesterday in this place we established quite plainly that the Leader of the Opposition is quite a hypocrite when it comes to the Regional Partnerships program because what he has in essence been saying is this: `This is a program that should be shut down and everyone should give their money back, except in the case of the five grants in Brand,' because he supported them. He has made applications for them. He has told his electorate how hard he has been working to secure them. But in his embarrassment and in his desire to recapture some lost territory in this place, he flourished quite dramatically a swag of press clippings which purported to show that the government was abusing regional partnership announcements. It was not that Regional Partnerships was the problem any more; it was the way the government was using the announcements, specifically by having the Liberal Party candidate in Brand make these announcements in a way that was plainly meant to favour that candidate and which was demonstrating precisely how the government was `using these rorts as opportunities to create bogus local reputations for their candidates'.

answer.para: Nine of these clippings were tabled by the Leader of the Opposition yesterday, and overnight I have had a chance to look at them. I must say there were quite a number of announcements. I was amazed to discoverâif they were all made by Liberal Party candidatesâthat you had quite a number of Liberal Party candidates in the seat of Brand. There was funding under the Black Spots Program, the roads program, by the Liberal Party candidate for Brand, whose name is Senator Ian Campbell! He made that announcement. There was Regional Partnerships funding announced by the Liberal Party candidate for Brand, my then parliamentary secretary, De-Anne Kelly! Then we had a confiscated illegal fishing boat; the Liberal Party candidate for Canning made that announcement. And then Senator Ellison presented a cheque for the Rockingham marinaâa Regional Partnerships grant.

talk.start.para: âOrder! Members on my left will come to order.

âThe Leader of the Opposition's claim that these announcements had all been made by the Liberal Party candidate in that seat is absolutely wrong. Only one announcement was made in all of these press reports by the candidate. The announcement was that he would be resigning from the marina project because he was about to become the candidate. That is the only announcement made in all of the material the opposition tabled yesterday. The Leader of the Opposition owes that candidate an apology for the claim that he was trying to establish a bogus reputation.
âThe member for Batman is warned!

âThat candidate was the founder and president of the Rockingham Marina Action Group, the treasurer of the Cruising Yacht Club of Rockingham, the chairman for marketing and promotion for Tourism Rockingham, and the co-founder of the West Coast Dive Action Group. He did not need a bogus local reputation; he is a man of real standing in the area. He is owed an apology by the Leader of the Opposition and, I tell you this, so is the Leader of the Opposition's own party because of his hypocrisy in this matter. He has led them to believe that he thinks this program should be closed down. He plainly does not. He thinks it should be strongly supported, because he has been out there actively campaigning for support under the program in the electorate of Brand.

âI inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon 100 students enrolled in the Australia and New Zealand School of Government inaugural Executive Master of Public Administration degree. One of the students is the House Serjeant-at-Arms, Mr David Elder. On behalf of the House I extend a very warm welcome to the students.

speech.para: Honourable membersâHear, hear!

talk.start.para: âI wish I had not asked the last question, but I will ask this one. My question is to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister recall the following comments made by the shadow Treasurer from this dispatch box in September 1995:

quote.para: Australia has high foreign debt and because Australia has a current account problem, that puts premium on Australian borrowings, that flows through and every Australian pays for the consequences.

question.para: Does the Prime Minister agree with his Treasurer that a high current account deficit and foreign debt will result in a premium on interest rates, especially in light of the Reserve Bank's warning last week that the current account deficit could hit 6 per cent of GDP in the December quarter?

talk.start.para: âI must confess that I do not specifically recall that, but I will not argue with the Leader of the Opposition as to whether those words were actually uttered; but as to what the context of that may have been I would have to have a look. Let me address the issue of debt. I think we are all aware that at various stages in our existence, whether as a nation, as individuals or as companies, we have debt. The question of the size of that debt and the manageability of that debt is determined by our capacity to service that debt. One of the products of the sparkling performance of the Australian economy over the last few years is that our capacity to service foreign debt has increased dramatically. One of the reasons that our capacity has increased spectacularly is the volume of government debt. Bear in mind that the foreign debt, which the Leader of the Opposition is undoubtedly alluding to, is of course largely the debt of individuals and corporations.

answer.para: The government itself has made a tremendous contribution towards reducing the government's contribution to debt. In fact, at 3.9 per cent of GDP, name me a developed country in the world that has a lower proportion to GDP of government debt than Australia. The OECD average is about 45 to 50 per cent; in the United States it is about 45 per cent; in Japan I think it is over 100 per cent; and ours is 3.9 per cent. That is due to the fact that when the government came to office and inherited a budget deficit of $10Â½ billion from the Leader of the Opposition, who was the outgoing finance minister, this government, despite the attempts of the Labor Party and others in the Senate to frustrate its budget reduction program, set about not only getting rid of that $10Â½ billion but also accumulating surpluses and paying off debt. That is one of the reasons why this country is in such a strong economic position. I warmly thank the Leader of the Opposition for the question.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister inform the House how government is protecting Indigenous communities from the dangers of petrol sniffing?

âPetrol sniffing is a serious problem. It has claimed far too many Indigenous lives, and I thank the member for Solomon for his question and for the concern he has to promote better Indigenous health in communities in the Territory. In 1998 the Commonwealth introduced a special scheme to substitute aviation fuel for normal petrol in remote Indigenous communities to help combat the problem of petrol sniffing. Because aviation fuel did not contain aromatic hydrocarbons, it was not attractive to sniffers. But as a result of environmental changes avgas has now become unleaded. It will contain aromatic hydrocarbons and therefore it is no longer an effective substitute for use in communities which are prone to petrol sniffing.

answer.para: I am very pleased to say that BP Australia has now developed a special type of unleaded fuel without any aromatic hydrocarbons, specially designed for use in remote Indigenous communities. I am pleased to say that, thanks to this, the government will continue to spend $1 million a year supplying unsniffable fuel to remote communities where petrol sniffing is a potential problem. Because of this, the government will be able to continue to work with community leaders in the fight against petrol sniffing. It is a very important fight. This has claimed 100 Indigenous lives since 1981. It needs to be continued and it will be continued thanks to this government and the good work of BP Australia.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister now aware of evidence given during Senate estimates yesterday that Mr Rod Barton advised senior Defence officials in March, April, May and June last year that he had `interviewed' prisoners in Iraq and expressed in writing his concerns about the possible abuse of detainees and further recommended that `Australia should not be involved in the interview process'? Prime Minister, on what basis, therefore, do you stand by the credibility of your defence minister when he told the Senate on 16 June last year that his statement to the Senate, omitting those crucial details, was `the most complete picture Defence can provide on its knowledge to date on this issue'?

âI am aware, broadly and in some areas in some detail, of the evidence given. I am also aware of the very clear distinction that is apparent in the Army's manual between interviews and interrogations. I have followed the comments that have been made by the member for Barton on this subject and I have also followed the comments of Mr Neil James, the head of the Australian Defence Associationâa former intelligence officer and a lieutenant colonel in the Australian Army. I quote from what he said last night on the PM program:

quote.para: So what heâ

answer.para: namely, Mr Bartonâ

quote.para: was in effect doing was he was questioning someone inside a facility that ... was used for detailed interrogation. But his questioning of that subject was by no means an interrogation.

answer.para: That is from somebody who was an intelligence officer. With the greatest of respect to the member for Barton, whom I do respect, Mr James knows a little more about this subject than the member for Barton has indicated with his comments. The reality is that within the military there is a clear understanding of this distinction. It comes out in the manual. I do stand by my minister and I think he has been unfairly, wrongly and quite disgracefully criticised by the opposition on this issue.

Let us get to the essence of this issue. The essence of this issue is that at no stage last year when we were talking about Abu Ghraib was there any evidence of substanceâany evidence at allâthat Australians had been involved in prisoner abuse. The whole exercise last year was designed, however indirectly, to create a different impression. The Leader of the Opposition knows this and those who sit on the front bench know this. Frankly, I think there are a growing number of Australians who are sick and tired of this endeavour to spear people who are trying to do an honest job on behalf of this country. They are getting sick and tired of it.

Obviously it is impossible for the defence minister or the Prime Minister, whether you have a Labor government or a Liberal government, to know the minutiae of everything that takes place in a theatre of conflict. We have to rely on the information that is provided to us by the defence department. I think the Defence people have done their level best to provide accurate information to the Senate, accurate information to ministers and accurate information to me. There is a difference between interrogation and interview. That is clearly spelled out in the military manual. It is understood by Lieutenant Colonel James. It is understood by the military officers who gave evidence to the Senate estimates committee yesterday. It ought to be understood by the Leader of the Opposition, who is a former defence minister, and it should now be understood by the member for Barton.

This exercise we have had over the past few days has been a nitpicking attempt to damage the political reputation of the Minister for Defence. I can understand that it is the mission of an opposition to damage the political reputation of their opponents, but in the process they have made unreasonable, unfair and inaccurate remarks about members of the Australian Defence Force. That is something that I am certainly opposed to and that is something that this side of the House will never defend and never support and never condone.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister update the House on the growth in Australia's resources exports? What is the Australian government doing to assist exporters?

âI thank the member for Hinkler for his question and recognise his long representation in his electorate. The port of Gladstone, in particular, is one of the foremost export ports in Australia for bulk products, particularly from the resources sector. The member for Hinkler would know that that port is owned and operated by the Queensland government, along with a number of others in Queensland.

answer.para: In answer to the member's question, the value of Australia's resources exports rose by 13 per cent in 2004 to a figure of almost $40 billion, which is the second highest level on record in Australia for the resources sector. A significant proportion of that was our coal exports, leading the way with growth in value. They grew by 24 per cent in 2004. This certainly is a remarkable performance as far as the resources sector is concerned. It sustains the livelihood of many people and of course a lot of the work force in the electorate of the member for Hinkler, particularly in Gladstone, which, by the way, returned the member for Hinkler with a very comfortable majority. It is a very wise electorate.

The Minerals Council has estimated that the resources sector is proposing to invest about $8.2 billion in 2004-05. A lot of that is going to be going into improvements in infrastructure across Australia in terms of getting those exports from their source out of the country to our export markets. Along with what our government is doing, particularly through programs like AusLink where we are set to invest $12Â½ billion over five years in Australia's road and rail infrastructure, it is all going towards developing the logistical supply chain to match the needs in the marketplace and the ability of our exports sector to deliver to those needs in the marketplace.

You might ask what the state governments across Australia are doing. What are the states doing, the people that control a lot of the export ports across Australia? We know what the Queensland state government is not doing. They are not investing in infrastructure, but they are collecting massive amounts of royalties from our resources sector. The Queensland government has forecast that it will receive around $800 million in royalties in 2004-05 from our resources exports. It is also forecast that that may even go through the billion dollar mark being collected by the Queensland government. Yet they will not invest any money back into the much needed infrastructure to accommodate the growth in the export of resources out of that state. They will not even fund a 70-kilometre rail link, worth around $100 million, to Abbott Point, which would immediately alleviate the bottleneck that currently exists at Dalrymple Bay, an issue that the Treasurer spoke about yesterday.

One of the local mayors in Queensland, the Mayor of Bowen, who wants to see this investment take place, said about the Queensland government: `It is just a matter of someone pulling their finger out and getting on with it.' We agree with him. The Queensland government should get on with investing in assets that will help our exporters get their product out, instead of living off the infrastructure that was invested by previous Queensland governments, particularly the Bjelke-Petersen government, over the last 30 years. They should stop loafing on that, join the Australian government and industry and invest in what we need to enhance our export infrastructure for the future.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister and follows his answer to the previous question from the honourable member for Barton. Does the Prime Minister accept that obtaining information even from a willing individual falls within the military's own definition of `interrogate', which is: `the systematic extraction of information from an individual either willing or unwilling'. Why, then, on 28 May last year when discussing Iraq on the Neil Mitchell program did the Prime Minister state, `We weren't involved in any interrogations'? Isn't this another example of the government's distortion of the meaning of words in order to keep the true facts from the Australian people and undermine honourable defence personnel like Mr Rod Barton?
âOrder! The Minister for Foreign Affairs.
âGeneral Cosgrove is a liar: that is what you are saying.
âOrder! The Minister for Foreign Affairs is warned.

âI thank the Leader of the Opposition for the question. The essence of the question, I think, is that there really is no difference between interrogation and interviewing. That, I think, is a fair representation of what he is putting. Particularly in the context of military operations, I do not accept that. The Australian military forces do not accept that and Neil James, who is the original author of the ADF interrogation manual, does not accept that either. Speaking on the PM program last night he had a number of things to say about the difference between interrogation and interview. He said:

quote.para: The rough working definition is simply ... you're free to get up and leave. In an interrogation you are not. There's some form of legal or criminal or physical restriction.
Generally speaking in most situations there's a clear-cut difference between what's an interview and what's an interrogation.

answer.para: The opposition defence spokesman, the member for Barton, yesterday in contradistinction, when he was asked whether he thought there was an argument in the distinction between terms of interrogation and debriefingâand bear in mind that the expression `debrief' is being used interchangeably with the expression `interview'âreplied:

quote.para: No there is not ... They have used a highly technical definition. Even on the basis of that highly technical definition there was unquestionably interrogation.

answer.para: That is the view of the member for Barton and he may hold that view and he is entitled to hold that view. But what I am putting in all seriousness to the opposition is that that is not the view of the Australian military. It is not the view of the head of the Defence Association. It was not the view of the head of military operations in Iraq who commissioned the circumstances under which people would participate in the Iraq Survey Group, and it was clearly not the view of the defence department when they provided advice to both the defence minister and to me last year. This all arises out of an attempt by the opposition to allege that in some way the defence minister and I and others in the government have misled the parliament and the Australian public.

We have done no such thing. At all stages in relation to this we have been absolutely candid. The people who are trying to distort the language, with great respect, are those who are speaking for the opposition, because they are refusing to accept what I do and what I believe most people who have examined it will do: that in the military context there is a clear distinction between an interview and an interrogation. It is spelt out in an Australian Army manual. So if it was meaningless and if we were just playing with words, why would it be spelt out in an Australian Army manual?

I say again: we have the head of the Defence Association, a former intelligence officer, who has said it very clearly. And I make no comments about Mr Bartonâhe is entitled to his viewâbut the reality is that when he signed the questionnaire that was sent out last year, the word he used was `interview'. He is a person who quintessentially was in a much better position to know the difference between `interrogation' and `interview' than I was, or the Leader of the Opposition or indeed anybody else, because he in fact had been commissioned as part of the Iraq Survey Group and he understood the terms of that commission and the terms of that engagement. He used the word `interview' when he answered the question last year. He did not use `interrogation'; he used `interview'. I suggest he did that because he then understood very clearly the distinction that existed between the two concepts, as Lieutenant Colonel James understands it, as Barton's commanding officer understands it and as I know the Leader of the Opposition understands it. Anybody who has studied the manual will understand the difference. There is a difference in Australian military parlance between the two concepts. And when that is understood, any suggestion that Senator Hill has misled the Australian public on this issue is completely false.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister update the House on the government's plans for improving standards and consistency in schools across Australia?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr NELSON
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Makin for her question and her very strong support for the government's initiatives to drive national consistency and high nationally consistent standards in Australian schooling. One of the many initiatives announced by the government during the recent election campaign was that we will move to develop and establish an Australian certificate of education which could be undertaken by students across Australia as an alternative to the conventional year 12 examinations conducted in eight different jurisdictions.

answer.para: I will shortly be calling for tenders for appropriate organisations to develop the model, which would be based on four things. The first is that we can drive consistency amongst the eight different jurisdictions at the moment in terms of year 12 assessment and make sure that we have a common test across Australia. Alternatively, the Australian certificate of education could be based on a national curriculum based assessment. Thirdly, it could take the form of a student aptitude test, which is currently applied quite successfully across the United States of America. Alternatively, it has been suggested that the Australian certificate of education could be based on the template of the international baccalaureate, which is currently being undertaken by 20,000 Australian students throughout schools because, increasingly, parents and teachers and students are frustrated and looking for a nationally and internationally recognised and consistent qualification.

No sooner had I announced the detail in relation to this than the Deputy Leader of the Opposition issued a media release on 7 February this year which described this move for national consistency and the certificate of education in the following terms: absurd, meaningless, nonsense, bureaucratic nightmareâand so on it goes. So obviously at least the Labor Party is consistent in criticising anything which drives national consistency and high quality in standards. Then I thought, no, not everybody in the Labor Party could think that way. Then I recalled that, slipped among my Christmas cards on Christmas Eve, was a letter that I had received from one of the Labor MPs. This one, rather than being the typical one you get from the Labor backbench wilderness, was indeed from the front bench.

The letter read in part: `Dear Minister, I write on behalf of a certain school located in my electorate. The school is interested in offering the international baccalaureate course to interested students. Indeed the school is collaborating with two other schools on the development of an international baccalaureate pilot program. Currently, government schools in Victoria are not allowed to offer such a course. However, in order to pilot the international baccalaureate some funding would be required. I would be grateful for your indication as to whether such a program would be considered for funding under the Howard government's Investing in our Schools program.' That, as the Prime Minister knows, is the $1 billion that this government is investing to cut through constipated educational bureaucracies to support things that are desperately needed at the school level. The letter goes on: `I would also be grateful if you would consider allocating time when you are in Melbourne to meet with representatives with the schools who are interested in this new development in public education. I look forward to your reply.'

I am sure that Julia Gillard, member for Lalor, shadow minister for health and alternate Deputy Leader of the Opposition, will look forward to my reply. My reply is that I look forward to meeting those schools. And I ask the member for Lalor: why don't we jointly write to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and she can come along to the meeting too? It would be a lovely meeting, and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition can actually listen to what parents are saying. They have had it up to here with inconsistent national standards and they are sick and tired of educational ideologues in education departments telling them what they know is not in the interests of their children.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister. I refer to his answer to our previous question. Does the Prime Minister recall the following statement by Mr Rod Barton:

quote.para: ... someone was brought to me in an orange jumpsuit with a guard with a gun standing behind him and, all right, you can call it what you wish ...

question.para: He continues:

quote.para: I believe it was an interrogation. The Iraqis regarded it as interrogation, interrogations. The Americans I think regarded it as interrogation.
It wasn't just a simple interview ...

question.para: Is the Prime Minister saying that Mr Barton has told a lie in this statement?

talk.start.para: âThe honourable the Prime Minister will answer that question but I think the last statement did not add anything to the question. Would the honourable member for Griffith like to rephrase that last part of the question?
âDoes the Prime Minister accept the accuracy of Mr Barton's statement that I have just read to the House?
âAt no stage have I accused Mr Barton of being a liar.
âYou just did before.

âNo, I do not accuse Mr Barton of being a liar. People can hold strong views about circumstances which are different from each other without either of them being a liar. I am not casting any aspersions on Mr Barton's character; I am going to the essence of this issue. The essence of this issue is that the Labor Party has tried to establish and continues to allege that the lying and the deception of the Australian public has come from the defence minister and myself. What I am doing is pointing out that there is a clear distinction between interrogation and interview in a military situation.
âWere you there or was Mr Barton?

âI am glad the member for Griffith asked, `Was I there?' No, I was not. I thank the member for Griffithâthat was one of his better interjections. Of course I was not there, and therefore I have to rely on the advice I receive from the defence department and I have to rely also on the analysis of experts. May I again return to Neil James. This is what he had to say in that very lengthy and very informative interview on PM last night:

quote.para: Rod Barton is a very distinguished biological warfare intelligence analyst.

answer.para: I have no argument with that; I am not suggesting he is not. I have not met him but I have no reason to denigrate his professional qualifications in that department, and I will not. James goes on to say:

quote.para: He's not a qualified interrogator. I don't know whether he's had any exposure to the interrogation process. But it's quite common for people with no understanding of the process, or little understanding of the process, to misunderstand the things they see and the safeguards employed.

answer.para: The question of whether Mr Barton believed thenâwhich apparently he did not, because he described it last year as an interviewâor he believes now does not alter the requirement that all of us make an objective analysis of what it was. To aid that objective analysis we must look at the military manual, which draws a clear distinction between an interrogation and an interview. That was the basis of the advice that Defence transmitted to Senator Hill last year. It remains the basis of Defence's advice and it is the basis of my claim that the attempt by the opposition to discredit the integrity of the Minister for Defence is completely false and completely dishonourable.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Would the minister advise the House how the government's tort law reforms have improved the availability and affordability of public liability and professional indemnity insurance?

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr BROUGH
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âI understand how many members of this House have been concerned about how the increase in and availability of public liability insurance to so many local community groups put at risk the future of many events, such as country shows. I am pleased to inform the House that the ACCC has just released a report which shows that the premiums for public liability insurance and professional indemnity insurance have both fallen significantly. The report shows that the premiums for public liability insurance have fallen by 15 per cent in the six months to June 2004. This is very welcome news for the community. It means that community events that were at risk due to increased premiums will now be under less financial stress and, as a result, we have a better chance of these very important aspects of community life continuing to operate.

answer.para: The finding is also very welcome news for business and particularly small business who have to find the money for the public liability insurance premiums. These reductions will be very welcome by them. The report shows that professional indemnity insurance premiums have also fallen by 17 per cent in the six months to June 2004. This is after a number of increases in previous years. Whilst these lower premiums are welcome, the government realise there is more to be done, and we will have to monitor these prices over time to ensure they do not escalate. To that end, I have agreed that the ACCC continue to monitor prices and to make that information available in an annual report, and this will be done for next three years. The one major item of tort law reform that remains outstanding is the passing of the amendments to the Trade Practices Act which were stymied by the opposition in the Senate. We will be reintroducing that measure, and I call on the Labor Party to change their position to assist the government to keep downward pressure on insurance rates.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Is it the case that the Tweed Shire Council mayor and local National Party electorate council chair was project officer of the Northern Rivers Dairy Regional Assistance Program and member of the Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee? Can the Deputy Prime Minister confirm that the National Party mayor recommended an $88,000 dairy regional assistance grant to add farm-stay accommodation to the Tea Tree Farm of prominent National Party supporters John and Kathleen Corrocher?

âMr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Asking the question in that way is in total breach of the standing orders. Using the names was in no way necessary to convey the meaning of the question, and it was a deliberate slur on those people. He should be asked to withdraw.

âThe standing orders make it clear that the names are necessary to make the question relevant or comprehensible. How on earth could I ask the Deputy Prime Minister to confirm something about which he did not know the details?

âThe point of order raised by the member for Mackellar indicates, I think, that the member for Fraser included some material that was clearly unnecessary to make the question clear. Nonetheless, I believe the Deputy Prime Minister can answer it, because the thrust of the question is in order.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âI have absolutely no idea as to the accuracy or nature of the member for Fraser's allegations. I will consult with the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, who was responsible for the administration of Dairy RAP. I presume the opposition is now going to smear Dairy RAP, a program which the federal government put in place to help the dairy farmers of this country when the states deregulated that industryâcold turkeyâwhich resulted in enormous dislocation and economic and social trauma. But, as to the details of the allegations, I will consult with the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and report back to the House.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education. Will the minister advise the House how new apprenticeship centres are helping young people to get a start in the traditional trades?

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Kingston. He would be interested to know that since 1996 there have been 530 new apprentices in training in his electorate, which is a 221 per cent increase. I urge the member to work hard to get an even better result over the years ahead. New apprenticeship centres, NACsâsuch as National Apprenticeship Services in Morphett Vale in his electorateâare contracted by the government to provide information and support, coordinate the relationships between apprentices and their employers and administer incentives for new apprenticeships. Over the last two years the number of new apprenticeship centresâan investment by this government in Australian apprenticeshipsâhas increased from 300 to some 500 right around Australia. This year the government will spend more than $685 million on incentives paid directly to employers of new apprentices and on the provision of these support services.

answer.para: This support is absolutely essential. It is helping young people to get a start in traditional trades such as metal trades, motor trades, carpentry and plumbing. We have seen an 18 per cent increase in the number of those taking up those trades, which proves the success of the NACs. A recent survey which was commissioned by my department, to listen to people, found that employers and indeed their new apprentices are highly satisfied with the work done by the new apprenticeship centres. Nine out of every 10 employers surveyed indicated that they would use the same NAC again. In fact, 93.1 per cent said they would employ a new apprentice again in the future, which is exactly what the government wants to see Australian businesses doing. This is why the ongoing success of the government's many measures to deal with the growth of new apprentices in the Australian economy has grown training in Australia from a pitiful 141,000 apprentices in 1995 to around 400,000 today.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Can the minister explain the involvement of the Tweed Shire Council's National Party mayor and the former National Party member for Richmond in the grant of $273,000 of taxpayers' money to Seawind, a South Tweed seafood company that has subsequently gone bust? What financial probity checks did the minister make before approving the grant to Seawind to ensure that taxpayers' money would not be wasted?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for his question. In essence, it goes to the question of checking and establishing whether or not programs are worthy and whether they are going to make a difference in terms of jobs and local outcomes. In this particular case, the normal probity arrangements and checks would have been takenâI am sure of thatâ

âOccasionally, with the best will in the world, companies do go under. I will undertake to check the veracity of the member for Wills's claim and come back to the House on it. The House might like to know that I checked with my department to see whether or not any of the offers made by the federal Labor Party to various constituencies around the country during the election campaign had been submitted for any analysis or costing. First amongst those offers was the $150 million they promised for the Murwillumbah-Casino railway line. There were no probity checks whatsoever; there was not even an analysis done by the shadow minister for transport at the time.
âOh, you did check it? Let us see it. Where is it?

âIt was not; it was done by the Leader of the Opposition and Mr Carr in New South Wales. We have not received any applications or requests for checking in relation to an offer of $1 million for a national centre of democracy at Ballarat; none for a $10 million commitment for a national museum of Indigenous culture in Cairns; nothing for the $1.5 million for a turtle interpretation centre in Queensland; $3 million for a sporting complex at Thuringowa; $6 million for the Rockhampton showgrounds; or $12.5 million to upgrade transport infrastructure at Blacktown. And the opposition have a go at us for a Tasmanian package of $12 million. What about their $54 million Tasmanian package? And it goes on and on. The hypocrisy of the Labor Party on this knows no bounds whatsoever. The Leader of the Opposition's motto is very simple: `Do as I say, not as I doâand I hope none of you notice that in my electorate I support the regional programs.'

answer.para: I also think it is time the opposition started to tell us which programs they would withdraw funding from. They should go out and tell the people who have had the benefit of those programs which ones they do not support. They should go down to Mogo, in the member for Eden-Monaro's seat, and tell those people that the $97,000 that secured four full-time jobs in a zoo should be withdrawn, that they should all go back on welfare and that the tourism industry should just fold up and go back to where it was.

talk.start.para: âLeave the animals alone!
âThe member for Grayndler is warned!
âThere are proper processes in place, the opposition's own Senate inquiry is probing those processes, and I am sure the department will be only too happy to explain what processes are in place.
âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Ageing. Would the minister inform the House how the government is supporting the aged care sector and ensuring high quality care for older Australians?

âI thank the member for Greenway for her question. What an outstanding local representative is the member for Greenway. Last year I visited St Elizabeth's Nursing Home and Hostel in her electorate. She is an outstanding advocate for aged care issues. Today I announced details of a key plank of the government's reform agenda on aged careâthe conditions attaching to the $877 million funding boost announced in the last budget. This payment was in addition to the annually indexed aged care subsidy already provided by the government. In order to receive this extra payment aged care providers must prepare a financial report that is audited annually and made available to residents, they must provide and encourage training opportunities for all their staff and take part in work force surveys and work force reporting.

answer.para: This conditional adjustment payment means that there is more transparent financial reporting in the aged care sector. That will boost market confidence and encourage greater investment in the sector. It means that there is more funding available for aged care providers so that they can pay competitive wages to staff to ensure that we continue to attract and retain quality aged care staff and it means greater improvements in the quality of care.

This government is building consumer confidence and market confidence in the aged care sector. It is part of our ongoing reform agenda to ensure that we have a sustainable, flexible and innovative aged care sectorâa leading model for aged care across the world. This is our government's reform agenda, and we are delivering on it.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister and it concerns $660,000 the taxpayers would really love to get back. Is the Prime Minister aware that yesterday the Queensland Supreme Court gave possession to Beaudesert Rail creditors assets that included a diesel engine, carriages, machinery sheds and office equipment? Doesn't his statement yesterday that they had made some on-balance judgments to put an additional $660,000 into Beaudesert Rail, notwithstanding that the department had concluded it could not meet the financial viability criteria, make a complete mockery of the Regional Partnerships program guidelines?
âNo.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Workforce Participation. Would the minister inform the House of the benefits of work for the dole to young jobseekers such as those in my electorate of Stirling? Are there any alternative views?

âThe interjections have started already, because we know the Labor Party hates the Work for the Dole program. On 327 occasions now someone across there has criticised that program. I have reported that to the House before. We are still looking for a commitment to this program from the member for Brand. I start by congratulating the member for Stirling on a fantastic result in his seat. It is great to have a live member in Stirling. He is somebody who has supported local community groups alreadyâ
âI rise on a point of order. I know that the previous member for Stirling is no longer here but that was an extraordinary slur on her condition and I ask that it be withdrawn.
âI think the minister might oblige on that request.

âAbsolutely; no slur was intended, whatsoever. It goes to show how sensitive the Labor Party is about this program. This program is providing real results for young Australians, yet at every opportunity the opposition opposes this program. Recently I announced 339 new programs which will help 4,000 young people across this country to provide support to their local communities. This government remains absolutely committed to the Work for the Dole program. In the member for Stirling's electorate one of those programs relates to the assistance provided to the local PCYCâhelping the local police in that community to work with the children to provide support around the administration of the centre. It is a wonderful program that contributes right around the countryâto the relief aid in the tsunami affected areas right across Indonesia. If the opposition remains opposed to the Work for the Dole program, why don't they dispense with the semantics and come out and say where they stand. If they are opposed to it they should scrap it as part of their policy. This government is committed to the program because it is part of the reason we have been able to bring unemployment levels down by half compared to when the opposition leader was the employment services minister.
âMr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

âMr Speaker, during question time you required the honourable member for Griffith to rephrase a section of a question which sought to ask the government whether it was the government's position that a person who is not a member of this House, Mr Rod Barton, was lying. I wonder could you explain to the House which standing order this part of the question breached and whether it is now the position that a member is unable to ask a minister whether it is the government's position that a particular person who is not a member of this House or the Senate, or the Governor-General or the Queen, is lying?

âI would remind the honourable member that it is not my job to give instructions. It is my job to uphold the standing orders. You will note quite clearly that one of the standing orders on questions makes it clear that reflections on members should be on notice, so I asked the member for Griffith to rephrase the question rather than putting it on notice.
âAny person of the public.
âMr Speaker, I again ask you which standing order the question from the member for Griffith was in breach of.
âI have answered the question.

âMr Speaker, I have a question concerning the operation of the standing orders and the standards of the House. I seek advice from you, and perhaps you would consider referring the matter to the Procedure Committee, as to whether it is appropriate during question time to conduct party ballots for the Liberal Party for trips, for example, to New York, including the candidates for Boothby, Grey, Paterson, Pearce and Cook. It would be appreciated if you would consider this issue and report back to the House or, alternatively, refer the matter to the Procedure Committee for advice.
âI thank the member for Batman. I am not aware that that would be covered by any standing order. I will make further inquiries and get to back to him if necessary.

âMr Speaker, I draw your attention to the standing order that requires ministers to address their remarks through the chair. I note that the Deputy Prime Minister, during question time, answered questions put to him with his back to you, playing to his comrades in the National Party at the far end of the room. It is an obvious mark of disrespect to you, and I am raising the matter in the hope that the Deputy Prime Minister and other National Party members will show some respect to you.
âI thank the member for Corio for his question. I will endeavour to remind ministers that when they answer questions they should speak through the chair and, particularly, through the microphone.
âMr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
âDoes the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
âYes.
âPlease proceed.

âThe Assistant Treasurer, despite my clarification in later debate yesterday, issued a press release yesterday afternoon accusing me of describing a new capital allowance regime for heavy vehicle transport as `industry welfare'. As the Hansard record will show, Mr Speaker, what I said was that Labor will continue to support departures from the effective life regime when a sound economic or social cost has been made out, as we did in this case, but not when it represents no more than industry welfare.

debate.para: Mr ABBOTT (WarringahâLeader of the House) (3.10 p.m.)âDocuments are presented as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members earlier today. Details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

Mr ABBOTT (WarringahâLeader of the House) (3.10 p.m.)âI present documents on the following subjects, being petitions which are not in accordance with the standing and sessional orders of the House:

quote.para: In relation to an immigration matterâfrom the member for Deakinâ297 Petitioners
Concerning student income supportâfrom the member for Pageâ83 Petitioners

talk.start.para: âI have received a letter from the honourable member for Brand proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The need for the government to be open and honest with the Australian people

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ

talk.start.para: â`Truth in government'. We have opponents across the chamber from us who will say anything and do anything to get themselves elected. They will say anything, do anything, slander any reputation while in office to protect their political position. They will spend anything, under any set of conditions, and ignore any guidelines in order to secure certain amounts of money for their candidates to ensure they get elected.

speech.para: This government is unacquainted with the truth or any decent standard that would be expected of it by a public. It has abandoned truthfulness, it has abandoned good public policy and it has abandoned all proper processes. It rejects the advice of independent experts, it ignores criticism and it covers over any facts that do not fit its message. This government and the Prime Minister are obsessed with spin doctoring, with controlling every image and every story to suit their political interests, no matter what the cost. It does not matter to them if the cost is that hundreds of millions of dollars are diverted from urgently needed infrastructure into political slush funds. It does not matter to them if the cost is that they damage the reputation of dedicated public servants and service men and women. It does not matter to them if the cost is an ever-deepening public cynicism towards democratic institutions. If there is short-term political gain, the government will be in it.

Despite the government's obsession with secrecy, we sometimes find out things they do not want us to know. That has been happening through the Senate estimates process this week, a process that will be much diminished in value from the middle of this year when the government will assume absolute control of this parliament. We are seeing perhaps the last phase of the value of that institution in accountability terms in Australia, and we are going to be the poorer for it. When the facts do come out, they will paint a damning picture of a government that has contempt for integrity and openness and an obsession with spinning a message that always paints it in the most favourable light.

I want to address three issues that demonstrate the urgent need for this government to radically change its priorities and to start putting the interests of the Australian people above the interests of Liberal and National Party politicians. The first is the deliberate deception that this government has practised by promising to keep interest rates low while implementing policies that are increasing inflationary pressures and making an interest rate increase a serious possibility in the coming months by its actions. The second is the deliberate deception that this government practised last year in concealing the fact that Australian armed forces participated in the interrogation of Iraqi prisoners. The third is the deliberate deception that this government has practised by allocating hundreds of millions of dollars to spending programs that have been driven by one priorityâpolitical profit for politicians.

Let me deal with the first of those, on interest rates. All of us in this place were contestants at the last election or we would not be here. Day after day in that election campaign, we saw statement after statement by the government along the lines of that statement I quoted in question time. Here is another one:

quote.para: Well, we're certainly, first and foremost, we're offering a continuation of the low interest rates of the last eight and a half years.

speech.para: They slandered the Labor Party, which was the only political party that went into this election campaign with savings for its expenditure programs in order to reduce budgetary pressures on interest rates, through that campaign. They whipped up a fear campaign about it and they won the election. What do we find in the aftermath of that election? We find the Prime Minister here in this chamber with weasel words: `We didn't really say that. Oh, no, we didn't promise the Australian people that interest rates would not rise.' Let me tell him there are at least 10 million Australians out there who think he did, and a substantial number of them voted for him on that basis. But, no, he cites the weasel words. Every day in question time there is another exercise in hairsplitting. We heard a few of them affecting Defence personnel today, and all year we have heard the hairsplitting on the question of interest rates. But the Australian people do not believe the government and, when the government find themselves presiding over increased interest rates, they will know exactly who to blame.

The government understand this is about to happen to them, so off they go to find scapegoats. The unions are the scapegoats. We have the government's industrial relations legislation in operation. We have a quiet union movement in this country. What we have as well is a population that is not as skilled as it should be and that is creating the pressure, the glitches and the blockages in our economy now as companies that wish to invest in new developments find themselves without the work force that they need. It is not that they have an undisciplined work force; it is that they cannot get a skilled work force and blockages emerge from the infrastructure.

Yesterday, the Treasurer stood up in this place and discussed the coal loader in Queenslandâvery interesting. The statement he cited from the Queensland minister is about as old as the hills. It is the first time the Treasurer has managed to get up and discuss it in this place, but why did he discuss it? Because he has discovered what the opposition's infrastructure spokespersons and Treasury spokespersons have been talking about since the day they were appointed, and they have been joined by the OECD and by the Reserve Bank. One of the glitches in the economy at the moment is the manifest inattention by this government to the infrastructure needs of this nation that has been the hallmark of its rule, or its misrule, for the last nine years.

The government inherited an economy in which great changes had been made that drove it to be one of the exemplary economies in the growth of wealth of the last decade or so. There were bitter experiences for many of us who served in those governments as we took the hard decisions to make changes and we were, as a result, the targets of many of those who had suffered as those changes were made. But the rewards were all reaped in political terms by this government, and this government has trashed them. It has trashed those rewards as it has sought, every time an election has come round, to buy itself back into power.

As the Reserve Bank governor sits down and contemplates what he intends to do about the future, there is no question that one of the things he has at the back of his mind is the $66 billion that this government punched out of the budget surplus in one year flat to get itself re-elected. Did the government think that the $66 billion punched into the economy to rocket-fuel it would pass the attention of the Reserve Bank governor and that, after the election was over, he might not think about doing something about it? But what he does about it ought to be sheeted right home to our political opponents.

There is no need for interest rates to rise. They boast about interest rates, but our interest rates are about the highest in the industrialised world. On a comparative basis, we have an official rate of 5.2 per cent. It is around two per cent in the US and in Europe. The nearest rate to ours is the British, which is 4.75 per cent. The Japanese rate is 0.1 per cent. And we are talking about the possibility of a 50 basis point rise in those circumstances. Where is our international competitiveness here? What is going to happen to Australian businesses as a result of that? And it can all be sheeted back to that $66 billion punch and the other matters that I have been referring to that John Howard put out for his re-election campaign.

The icing on the cake of that $66 billion had to be that extraordinary campaign launch of his. I have seen a few rippers in my time, and the odd Labor Party leader has been responsible for one or two of them, but I have never seen money spent in a policy speech at the rate of $200 million a minute. That absolutely took the prize, that absolutely took the cake; and that was our political opponents.

Truth in government goes elsewhere as well. It can go to national security areas and to the honour with which civil servants are dealt. The Prime Minister attacked us in question time today as though we have been attacking Defence personnel. He got up and said, `What the Labor Party are trying to prove is that Australian Defence personnel were involved in torture at Abu Ghraib.' No, that is not it. We are on the same wavelength as Mr Bartonâthe person who has blown the whistle on the governmentâan honourable public servant. We are trying to prove that the Australian people were deceived and this parliament was deceived when the government said it knew nothing about it and was not informed of these things until they became public matters.

Why would we want to know if the government knew something about it beforehand? The reason is that we take our allied duties seriously. Anyone can see, and it certainly was obviously the case after this issue broke out, that this would hand our enemies an unsurpassed propaganda victory and, if there were an opportunity to give a sensible warning to our ally that this sort of behaviour would be 100 per cent counterproductive to the objectives we seek in our life-and-death struggle with militant, fundamentalist terror, we would want at least a performance by the government in that regard.

The government seeks always to evade responsibility. When you take upon yourself the sort of struggle that is now being engaged in in Iraq, however mistaken that may be, you take upon yourself every single element of it. You must know the detail of what is going on with all armed service personnel in the area. And if a fella has come back and is seriously concerned enough to get the secretary of his department to write to the American ambassador here to warn him that this is going onâto get them back in the United States to stop things happening in Abu Ghraibâwhy in God's name didn't you do something about it? Instead of running around trying to evade responsibility and cover your backsides, why don't you just take a bit of responsibility for the jobs that you have in hand and deal with the problems?

A question was asked by the honourable member for Griffith about the difference between interrogation and interviewing. If a chap who is manacled thinks an interrogation is being conducted when the bloke standing behind the fellow in front of him has a gun, does he think he is having a little chatâ`This is just a small conversation; a chin wag about the state of the world'? Fair dinkum, you must really think that we have a very foolish Australian public to wander around in this place hairsplitting on a subject like that. It is very important that you are hairsplitting. Why do you hairsplit on that? Is it to arrive at the truth of what we were told about Abu Ghraib and to have a bit of analysis about how we might have done a bit better in this? Is that the reason? No; because if we accept that `interview' means `interrogate' then the Prime Minister has lied to parliament. If he has lied to parliament, even under all the conventions the government has trampled on, the normal consequence is that you resign. He does not want that. He does not want Senator Hill to have to resign, he does not want to have to resign himself, and so words are given different meanings and decent people have their reputations trampled upon. That is what has happened in this case.

Finally, we get the performance. I have got to get myself onto the tactics committee of the other side and pinch a few of the questionsâlike the one that was asked today of the Deputy Prime Minister. If anything ever exposed what they were on about with these regional rorts, that was an absolute ripper. The only person who did not feature in the announcements in Brand was the member for Brand. Everybody else had a chop. Every Liberal Party and National Party minister had his fingerprints on it. They all had a chop, but the honourable member for Brand missed out. The simple fact of the matter is this: you have used $400 million of taxpayers' funds to undermine your political opponents. In most countries, that is described as corruption. Unfortunately, the consequence of this is that it has stripped your capacity to deal with the infrastructure of this nation on a proper basis. That is what it has done. We do have problems like that coal loader in Queensland and we do have problems with the port-rail interface. Why? Because the Commonwealth has put all the funds for those purposes into the campaign treasuries of the National Party and the Liberal Party, looting royally, and incompetently, I might say, as we have revealed in case after case in this place, and then has misled the Australian people about what it is up to. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âI remind the Leader of the Opposition of the point of order by the member for Corio about the member not addressing the chair. I do not think he addressed the chair once.

âWe have seen the Leader of the Opposition get very, very excited and get very, very worked up, and we have had the hot air, interrupted by the falsetto laugh, but the fact of the matter is that he has called the government just about every pejorative adjective in the book. He said we were unscrupulous, he said we were corrupt, he said we were secretive and he said we were dictatorial. I thought to myself, `Which government is he talking about?' Is it the Iranian government, is it the Libyan government or is it the North Korean government? We are supposed to believe all this is true of the government of Australia, a pacific democracy, a government which has just been re-elected by the people of Australia with an increased majority.

speech.para: In the end, what is the Leader of the Opposition's real complaint? His real complaint is that this government won and that opposition lost. His real complaint is that for the fourth time members opposite have failed to secure the trust of the Australian people. So, rather than accepting the truth that members opposite simply are not up to it and that the last four times members opposite simply have not put an adequate case to the Australian people for their election, rather than accept that simple, democratic truth, he has to pretend that somehow `they was robbed'. `We was robbed' is the essential claim that the Leader of the Opposition is making now. He made it in 1998; he made it in 1996. It is this constant, tired refrain: `We was robbed.' I say to the Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues: get over it; this government won and it is time for members opposite to do the hard work of reconstructing themselves as a credible alternative government.
The matter of public importance to which the Leader of the Opposition was speaking is:

quote.para: The need for the Government to be open and honest with the Australian people.

speech.para: Yes, it is important to be open and honest with the Australian people. Honesty and openness must be demanded by people who are open and honest themselves. I would like to read from a document that was being widely distributed on election night:

quote.para: There can be no denying that last year the Labor Party was deeply divided. No-one can make that claim now and that is one of Mark Latham's greatest achievements. We believe Mark Latham ran a very strong campaign. He demonstrated that he has discipline, focus and is inclusive.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âThe member for Melbourne Ports is warned!
âIt continues:

quote.para: He broke the campaign mould. He was the first leader in more than a decade to hold open community forums during a campaign. Many events like these were unscripted. He showed real leadership during the campaign. He had a story to tell on how Labor would govern Australia, and he told it. People are no longer in any doubt about what the Labor Party stands for and we will be able to build on that.

speech.para: These people who claim that there is nothing more important than being open and honest are the same people who distributed this document. It is a document distributed by the secretariat of the Australian Labor Party to all frontbenchers and spokesmen on election night. Plainly, it is a tissue of lies, an absolute fabrication from start to finish.
