The Labor Party were so united that their leader was dumped humiliatingly, acrimoniously and unprecedentedly just a couple of months after the election campaign.

The fact of the matter is that these people opposite, huffing and puffing hysterically about the alleged lies and deceit of this government, do not come to this debate with clean hands. We have seen from the Leader of the Opposition over the last couple of weeks a bad case of political schizophrenia because obviously there are two Kims. There is Brand Kim, who is desperately seeking, desperately demanding, Regional Partnerships grants, desperately trying to claim the credit for $1.1 million worth of Regional Partnerships grants in his electorate, writing to the Deputy Prime Minister demanding that the government provide Regional Partnerships grants to his electorate, distributing to his electorate newsletters that try to claim credit for the award of Regional Partnerships grants in his electorate, and then there is Canberra Kim, who tries to suggest that all of this is some kind of giant boondoggle, that this is some kind of giant election slush fund. You cannot have it both ways: it is impossible to be in favour of Regional Partnerships grants in your electorate and opposed to Regional Partnerships grants in this parliament. The Leader of the Opposition stands exposed yet again, as he has stood so many times in this parliament, as a hypocrite, as a two-timer, as someone who says one thing in the electorate and another thing in this parliament. The Australian people know him, they have rejected him and they are not going to let him get away with this kind of treatment of the parliament and the people for that much longer.

The lie to the claims from members opposite was given today in a most interesting opinion piece on the op-ed page of the Australian Financial Review. One of the more credible, one of the more honourable and one of the more honest members of the Australian Labor Party is the member for Melbourneâa member of this parliament who, if the Leader of the Opposition himself had more strength and more integrity, would be on the frontbench of the Australian Labor Party. He is misguided in many respects, but he is honest and he is honourable. He tells the truth: he says what he means and means what he says. What did the member for Melbourne say today in the Australian Financial Review of this whole tedious campaign that has been run by the Leader of the Opposition over the past fortnight? I quote:

quote.para: Sadly, neither I nor the Labor Party have been entirely pure in these matters. Since losing office in 1996, our manifestos have contained similar promises of specific local grants. As opposition transport spokesman, I promised to fund a study into pilot training at Launceston Airport and a rail research institute in Adelaide.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: It's about time we got serious about the misuse of money ...

speech.para: He has given the lie to the entire Labor Party campaign of the last fortnightâguilty as charged, he says of the Australian Labor Party. This is not a guilty government; this is a guilty opposition. Indeed, if there is any guilt in this, and I do not believe that there is, it is a guilty parliament. So let us have no more of this two-timing cant from members opposite about some alleged problem with the Regional Partnerships grant program.

It is important that people who come into this parliament talking about the need for openness and honesty have been open and honest themselves. We had a press release yesterday from none other than the member for Lalor, the shadow minister for health, who says:

quote.para: At the Pink Ribbon Breakfast on the 1st of October 2004 the Minister for Health, Tony Abbott, announced that the Howard Government would commit $90 000 over 4 years to the NOCNâ

speech.para: the National Ovarian Cancer Network. I happened to look at the press release that was put out for that very function, which says:

quote.para: The Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, announced today that the Government would provide an additional $3 million over four years towards the National Breast Cancer Centre and an additional $600,000 for the Breast Cancer Network Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Lalor!

âI looked everywhere in this press release for the $90,000 that I allegedly promised at the Pink Ribbon Breakfast on 1 October 2004. Having made a false claim, the member for Lalor then desperately ran around yesterday afternoon, trying to find some factual justification for the false claim that I had misled this worthy outfit.
âThe member for Lalor!

âShe is still claiming it todayâthis person who boasts of being open and honest with the Australian people, this person who waxes self-righteous daily about her virtue and the alleged perfidy of the Australian government. Today she sends me a letter. It says:

quote.para: ... On the 14th or 15th October 2004, Mr Barnesâ

speech.para: of my officeâ

quote.para: confirmed that funding as sought for the 2005 Awareness Week would be supplied.

speech.para: This is a far cry from the claim made in the press release yesterday where she was caught outâ

talk.start.para: âBut you still promised it.
âwhere she was caught outâ
âYou still promised it.
âThe member for Lalor seems to think she has a right to interject at any time. I warn her!
âin a blatant untruth. If she were still a lawyer, she would be struck off for the kind of behaviourâ
âThat's all right, is it?
âthat she has been guilty of over the last couple of days.

âThe member for Lalor is now challenging the chair. I remind her of standing order 94(a). She is the Manager of Opposition Business in the House. She gets some leniency in this place, but she continually interjects.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
âMember for Lingiari, if this is a frivolous point of order, I willâ
âI ask him to withdraw that comment about the member's legal profession.
âWhat was that comment? I did not hear it.
âHe made a derogatory remark.
âI was calling the member for Lalor to order. If she was quiet, I might have heard it.
âI heard it.
âMr Deputy Speakerâ
âThe member for Chifley seems to be in a hurry to speak to the point of order.
âVery much so. The Leader of the House reflected on the member for Lalor in a way that requires aâ
âI am just dealing with that. Will the member withdraw it?
âIf it offends people, given the decline in legal standards perhaps, I will withdraw. But lest everyoneâ
âI rise on a point of orderâ
âIf this is frivolous, I will deal with it.
âThe withdrawal needs to be unqualified.
âThe member withdrew the comment. The member for Chifley will resume his seat.
âIt was not unqualifiedâ
âThe member for Chifley will remove himself from the House under standing order 94(a)!
âLest anyone had been listening to the caterwauling that we have had from members oppositeâ
âTell us about Archbishop Pell: did you see him or not?
âThe member for Lingiari!

âlet me table the emails between my office and the Ovarian Cancer Network. I will tell you what these emails will reveal. These emails will reveal a worthy organisation that wanted funds for a good cause. They will reveal an office which tried very hard to help this organisation and will continue to try to help this organisation. I say to the Ovarian Cancer Network that there will be a program put swiftly in place, as this government promised during the election campaign. They are welcome to apply to that program, and I hope they do get support, because they are a good organisation. I table these emails which completely give the lie to the claims made by the member for Lalor. I also table a letter that she gave me today, and I table the press release that she put out yesterday.

speech.para: It is very clear: nothing has been said in this chamber or elsewhere by the opposition over the last fortnight to indicate that this is anything other than a good government getting on with the job of governing this countryâgetting on with the job, putting its election commitments in place. There is no evidence that anyone on the frontbench of this government has ever answered questions other than honestly on the basis of the best knowledge available to that minister at that time. As the Prime Minister said so well in this chamber today, there is no evidence that Senator Hill has done anything other than patiently and comprehensively answer questions put to him on the basis of the best advice that he had at the time.

This is an opposition which has become somewhat hysterical. What is behind all the activities of the last few days? It is not concern for the people of Iraq. It is not concern for Cornelia Rau. It is not concern for the dental health of the people of New South Wales. All that matters to them is trying to prove that the Prime Minister is an incompetent liar. I think they need to get over their fixation with Prime Minister Howard. I think they need to have a long, hard look at themselves. In particular, the Leader of the Opposition needs to have a long, hard look at himself and try to prove that he is different from the person that the Australian people do know well and have rejected so often. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to complement the Leader of the Opposition's contribution to this debate by talking about the need for us to get honesty from this government with the Australian people in relation to Regional Partnerships, which has degenerated into an all-singing, all-dancing $400 million Howard government slush fund. If you have got the contacts, if you are in the know, there is no limit to what you can get it to fund. It has allocated $138,000 for a day-care centre for dogs in Brisbane. It has allocated $231,000 to build a tomato greenhouse at Port Macquarie. It has allocated $271,000 to create a pet food business. It has allocated money for a private zoo, money for a golf course, money for lights for tennis courts and money for child-care centres, doctors surgeries and X-ray companies. It has allocated $550,000 for a mushroom farm south of Cairns.

speech.para: Of course, most of us were given the mushroom treatment about Regional Partnerships: we were kept in the dark. They did not advertise it on TV, or radio or in the newspapers. They certainly did not write to Labor or any other non-government MPs telling us this $400 million program existed. I wish they had written to me. Last year I needed to get a housing loan; I would have gone to Regional Partnerships if only I had known about it!

talk.start.para: âThe member for Melbourne Ports has been warned!

âYesterday the Queensland Supreme Court ordered that the creditors of the Beaudesert railway be given possession of Beaudesert Rail's diesel engine, carriages, machinery, sheds and office equipment. The Beaudesert railway is now left with just a steam engine, which is itself security for an outstanding debt to the Queensland government. What a monument to this government's financial mismanagementâa sorry tale of government ineptitude and incompetence, of throwing good taxpayers' money after bad. We had the Prime Minister in here yesterday telling the House he made an `on-balance judgment' to provide a further $660,000 of taxpayers' money to Beaudesert Rail. Never mind that this made a complete joke of the Regional Partnerships guidelines about the need for financial viability, never mind that the department believed it was not financially viable, never mind that the provisional liquidator did not believe it was financially viable, never mind its failure to properly acquit the $5 million Centenary of Federation funds: the Prime Minister made an `on-balance judgment' to put another $660,000 of taxpayers' money into this lemon.

speech.para: Why did he do it? He did it to save the Liberal member for Forde from embarrassment in the lead-up to an election. You see, she had her name all over the original $5 million Centenary of Federation grant to get the Beaudesert Rail project up and going. When she heard that this project was about to go off the rails and the $5 million was going to be wasted, she was no doubt mortified. She is the person who persuaded the Prime Minister to first offer a $400,000 loan and later turn it into a $660,000 grantâ$660,000 to save the face of the member for Forde. Menelaus thought Helen of Troy's face worthy of the launch of a thousand ships. The Prime Minister thought the member for Forde's face worthy of $660,000 of taxpayers' money!

The 13 June 2003 report of the provisional liquidator makes this absolutely clear. He says that, after his appointment, he was able to conclude that Beaudesert Rail could not pay its creditors merely from trading. He says that he contacted Mrs Kay Elson, the federal member for Forde, to discuss the possibility of receiving further funds. He says: `In a discussion with Ms Elson and Mr Ron Munn, the Mayor of Beaudesert, it was clearly put to me that by keeping the train trading, albeit at a loss, it would significantly enhance the prospects of receiving federal government funding.' The provisional liquidator then became caught between the concerns of creditors, on the one handâhe says that `the committee of creditors were understandably concerned that we were trading at a loss'; they were trading while insolventâand, on the other hand, the urgings of the member for Forde to keep the train going.

The provisional liquidator decided to bring things to a head. He said that, unless something concrete was received by 5 June 2003, Beaudesert Rail should cease business and market its assets for sale. The next day, he said, `It was made clear to me by Mr Munn and Ms Elson that approval of government funding was a matter of days away and that this funding was to save Beaudesert Rail and to close down would make it more difficult to obtain the funding, if not impossible.' On Friday, 6 June, he said, `I received a letter from Ms Elson advising that government funding was imminent and I made the decision to trade the business over the weekend to see if this was the case.' Honourable members, I am sure, can feel the air of crisis here. On 12 June 2003, the provisional liquidator received a letter from the Prime Minister making a conditional offer of a $400,000 loan.

It is absolutely clear from the provisional liquidator's report that the actions of the member for Forde and the Prime Minister compromised the government and, therefore, Australian taxpayers in this matter. The reason Beaudesert Rail kept running during this period, its losses increasing with each passing week, was because the member for Forde and the Prime Minister had made representations to the provisional liquidator. Just imagine if, after all that, the government had said, `We've examined your project, and we think it's a dog, and we're not going to give it any more money,' the creditors would have been outraged, and with good reason. So we come to the end of the line for $5.7 million of taxpayers' money. Where the Prime Minister should have been interrogating the member for Forde over that money, it looks like he did not even bother to interview her.

Where there is a rort, you just feel it in your bones, you know the National Party is going to be in there somewhereâand so it is here. The Beaudesert Rail project had been spearheaded by Joy Drescher, a former National Party candidate for state parliament, who was elected mayor of Beaudesert earlier this year. Yesterday the member for Grayndler urged the Prime Minister to carpe diemâto seize the dayâon the issue of climate change. But the National Party has its own motto. It is not carpe diem; it is carpe prosciuttoâLatin for `seize the pork'. The member for Hotham, who fancies himself as a bit of a Latin scholar, thinks it should be carpe porchettaâbut perhaps he is just advertising a restaurant chain. The National Party is so reliable in this that I have developed my own law of physics, which says: `Where there's a coalition trough, there's a National Party snout.' Now I know it is not as elegant or as important as Einstein's law of relativity or Newton's law of gravity, but it holds good for the overwhelming majority of Howard government programs.

And so it is that we heard today that it is not just the National Party mayor of Beaudesert but the National Party mayor of Tweed Heads, south of the border, Mr Warren Polglase, who recommended a $273,000 Dairy Assistance Program grant to Seawind, a South Tweed seafood company which has now gone bust. Mr Polglase is a very active man. He is the mayor of Tweed Shire Council, the local National Party Electorate Council chair and a member of the Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee. He managed to get himself appointed as an executive officer or a project officer to administer the Dairy Assistance Program.

We understand that this position was advertised but that no interviewsâcertainly no interrogationsâfor the position were ever held. Warren Polglase just got the job. Minister Anderson needs to inform the parliament and the Australian people just what selection process Mr Polglase went through before he was given this position. Mr Polglase has all the hallmarks of the Queensland National Party under Joh Bjelke-Petersen. If you read what has been happening in the New South Wales inquiry, you will discover that he is something of a colourful National Party identity. But, as the executive officer for the Dairy Assistance Program, he managed to recommend $88,000 in Dairy Regional Assistance grant money to prominent National Party supporters to add farm-stay accommodation to their tea tree farm and to recommend $273,000 of taxpayers' money to Seawind, a South Tweed seafood company that has subsequently gone bust.
My time is coming to a close but, as there was a bit of enthusiasm for the nursery rhyme last week, I will conclude with a verse:

quote.para: The Ballad of Beaudesert Rail
They say it comes out on the nights of full moon
The ghost train of Beaudesert from its rusting cocoon
It once used to run amid whoops amid hollers
Till it chewed up 5 million of taxpayers' dollars
The Deputy PM put it back on the track
With six hundred grand more that went straight up the stack
So now it sits idle a monument stored
And nobody comes when they shout âAll aboardâ
And they talk about rorts and they talk about fraud
Of a train with one passenger, the Member here for Forde
And it's just a classic case of throwing good money after bad
And how voters they were conned, and taxpayers they were had.
But there's still hope for it yet tho much ill of it we speak
Build a rail line to Dobell? Let it dredge the Tumbi Creek! (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is clear that the member for Wills should not give up his day job. As a poet he has no chance at all. This matter of public importance, which says, `The need for the government to be open and honest with the Australian people,' is a jokeâthe ALP talking about honesty and integrity in government! They should be the last ones to talk about it. In fact, we all remember the lead-up to the 1993 election, when the tax cuts were going to become `l-a-w law'. There were going to be no tax increases at all. You could rest on itâPaul Keating went out and told the Australian public: `You can trust this Labor government. You can rely on it. We will deliver on our promises. There will be no tax increases.' Of course, once the electionâ (Quorum formed)

speech.para: It is very clear that the opposition do not want to hear the truth about what they promised in 1993 in terms of l-a-w law. Labor promised there were going to be tax cuts and what happened? They did not happen at all. Then, of course, when they went to the 1996 election the current Leader of the Opposition, the then minister for finance, told us that there was a surplus of $10.1 billion. He said that frequently around the country. What was the reality of it? In fact, a week after this government came to office we found it was a $10.3 billion deficit. So much for honesty. It was only a $20 billion lieânot badâand it was the Leader of the Opposition who got up and said it.

Of course, we remember that wonderful institution Centenary House. It is just a prime example of honesty and integrity in government. It is like a symbol. If you went into the old East Block, there would be a symbol of the working man there to show what they are about. I think in future there will be tours to Centenary House to show people: this is what the Labor Party in office believed was appropriate integrity, honesty and openness for the Australian people. It was called a $43 billion rort. And they are the ones who are lecturing us on honesty.

Regarding the regional grants that we are now talking about, there were some 800 applications from coalition held seats and 200 from Labor held seats. They were too busy having their lattes and chardonnays to actually help people fill in their applications. (Quorum formed) Again the Labor Party do not want to hear the truth. The Labor Party did not assist their communities to apply for regional grants. The fact is that the percentage of applications that were approved for Labor seats and the percentage approved for coalition seats was exactly the same. There was clearly no bias; it was independently audited three times by KPMG. There were three reviews which made no findings of impropriety.

By contrast, we remember old Ros Kelly, the then member for Canberra. Did she know how to rort. She was the master of rort with the old whiteboard: `We'll have five for the Labor Party, one for the coalition, 10 for the Labor Party.' They took the whiteboard to great excellence but she did not survive. That was the member for Canberra who taught us all about what she thought was truth and honesty in government. It shows quite clearly that they have no understanding of what truth and honesty are.

In the last election they made $40 billion of promises and they said that PricewaterhouseCoopers was going to do a total audit of the costings and they indicated that they were properly funded. PricewaterhouseCoopers had to put out a statement saying that that was wrong, that all that they were required to do was to add up the amount. There was no verification of whether the funding was appropriate or the claims they made as to where the funding was. A lot of it was purely bogus money all the way through. They failed to submit their policies to Treasury and Finance before the deadline set by the department. They did not put their whole tax policy before the deadline or their child-care policy, their schools policy or their defence policy. Labor even refused to submit Medicare Gold.

In the debate today we have the Leader of the Opposition, a former finance minister, talking about interest rates. He accused this government in outrageous terms. He talked about the increases in interest rates that are happening, and of course there has been no announcement by the Reserve Bank at all about interest rate increases. We remember what the interest rates were under the other sideâ17 per cent. For small business it went up to 21 per cent. Under this government the amount is five to 6Â½ per cent. The Leader of the Opposition wants to indicate his economic credentials, but it is clear he knows nothing about interest rates.

On the issues of credibility, honesty and reliability, it is this side of the House that sets the example. The Charter of Budget Honesty that we provided set out the parameters. It showed the lies, the fraud, the dishonesty, the rorting of the previous government. We have shown what integrity in government is really about. The mob opposite are just producing a total sham. It is time they decided to get with the program and decide that honesty in government is the way to go. (Time expired)

âIn this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2004-2005 and related bills I wanted to raise two very important issues regarding the communications portfolio but the enemy, time, will prevent me from getting to the second issue. The first issue relates to the Australian Broadcasting Authority and its failure to grant a radio licence for Sydney frequency 1386AM. I foreshadow that the second issue I will raise, if I do not get time to do so today, concerns the government's failure to protect free-to-air television viewers from a loophole in the antisiphoning regime.

speech.para: There is a long history attached to the ABA's failure to grant a radio licence for Sydney frequency 1386AM. I am advised that on 25 May 2001 the ABA formed a preliminary view that an additional wide coverage community radio service should be made available in Sydney and called for public comment as to the suitable use of 1386AM for community radio. I am advised that on 27 July 2001 the ABA received several submissions, including one from Sydney Christian Broadcasters Ltd, also known as Rhema Sydney, on behalf of Sydney's estimated 900,000 churchgoing Christians. I am also advised that on 27 December 2001 the ABA received a revised draft variation to the Sydney radio licence area plan, proposing alternative sites for the community radio station. After receiving further submissions, the ABA continued to announce its support for a community radio station.

In March 2002 the ABA decided to make 1386AM available as a community broadcasting service instead of a narrowcasting service. On 15 July 2002 the ABA invited new applications for the Sydney-wide community radio licence transmitting on the 1386AM band. Again, fresh submissions were called for. On 26 March 2003 the ABA decided not to allocate radio licence 1386AM. In each case, Radio Rhema made submissions. In the final decision, the ABA was concerned about the location of a transmission station in the Sydney suburb of Homebush in my electorate of Lowe, allegedly because of concerns about proximity to new homes. On this basis, a decision was deferred for 12 months.

I am further advised that, in March 2003, eight applicants bid for the allocation of a Sydney community radio operator licence on frequency 1386 megahertz on the amplitude modulation, or AM, band. At that time, the ABA rejected all eight licence applicants. This rejection is of itself not unusual, but the failure of the ABA to grant a temporary licence was unusual. Incredibly, on 22 April 2004 the ABA called for yet another round of public comment. To this very day, there has still been no decision by the ABA to grant this radio licence.

By far the main contender in the application process is Rhema Sydney. The narrowing of bids to two main contenders follows other bidders dropping out. Put simply, Rhema Sydney has demonstrated overwhelming public interest. Rhema Sydney's application greatly outweighed all other applications in responses from the general public of Sydney, who strongly called for Rhema Sydney to be granted the 1386AM licence. In its submission, Rhema Sydney notes that it has in excess of 4,000 members and over 750 letters in support representing close to 460,000 individuals in the greater Sydney region.

I am advised that an estimated 2.4 million Sydney residents identify themselves as Christianâthat is, some 66 per cent of the Sydney metropolitan population. I am advised that an estimated 1.8 million Sydney residents attend church services at least at Easter or Christmas. Thus it may be said there are in Sydney nearly two million Christians who adhere to the main feast days on the Christian calendar. In addition, an estimated 900,000 people in Sydney are reported to attend Christian church services at least monthly.

Compounding the fact that there is a high percentage of Christians in the Sydney metropolitan area, a large number of the population are social service recipients who rely on broadcast information. Such broadcast services include the necessity for talkback radio and other media access. The average percentage of Christians in any one Sydney electorate is between 25 and 30 per cent. In my electorate of Lowe, the percentage of practising Christians reaches nearly 50 per cent. Finally, there are an estimated 2,000 Christian places of worship throughout Sydney.

In every sense, the Christian voice is frustrated in its ability to be heard. With reference to 2CBA FM, it is often claimed that Sydney already has one Christian radio station. With respect, this is a false argument. 2CBA FM does a wonderful job. However, its target audience and scope is much narrower than the proposed broadcasting service's community of interest. Firstly, it is intended that Rhema Sydney will service the broader Sydney Christian community, who have long suffered without a voice, to broadcast their services and address their mass-market needs. Secondly, Rhema Sydney intends to cater for the larger, different and cross-denominational Christian markets, each of which have demonstrably different needs and interests within the greater Sydney metropolitan area. Programming will include talkback, alternative journalists' views on news and other public affairs items, and it will give the large Christian community a voice on the public airwaves. Moreover, Rhema Sydney intends to be a voice for people with disabilities, older Australians, youth and those marginalised in our society.

I call on the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts to intervene in this matter and accept the overwhelming support of the Sydney community and the demonstrable public interest in the granting of a temporary licence to Rhema Sydney on radio frequency 1386AM. The ABA has prevaricated, obfuscated and simply refused to admit that the Rhema proposal shines above any of the other bidders. The Rhema application easily outweighs the other contenders in size, public support and sheer quality.

The facts are undeniable: there is a great unmet need for Christian radio broadcasting in the Sydney metropolitan area. There is, in my opinion, utterly no justification whatsoever for refusing to grant Rhema Sydney a radio licence or at least a temporary licence. The necessity for the ABA to call for public submissions four times is absurd. The information gathered and the submissions receivedâmany of them from members of this Houseâall point to the needs of the supporters of clearly the largest and most comprehensive submission for a licence for a radio station. I urge the minister to recognise the cross-party support, including support from members of her own coalition colleagues, in granting Rhema Sydney this transmission licence.

Mr Speaker, on another matter, you would be aware of my longstanding campaign to protect the public interest and Australia's democracy by exposing the Howard government's pandering to the interests of the major media proprietors in tearing down Australia's cross-media laws. Another appalling example of the Howard government's determination to serve the interests of the major media proprietors, ahead of the interests of the Australian people, is the cynical way the government has managed the broadcasting services antisiphoning list. The antisiphoning list is supposed to protect Australian households who do not have access to pay television from being denied important sporting events on free-to-air television. The antisiphoning list is designed to protect free-to-air television viewers by guaranteeing the rights of free-to-air television channelsâthat is, Nine, Seven, Ten, the ABC and SBSâto buy the broadcast rights to sporting events listed on the antisiphoning list. Some examples of events on the antisiphoning list, which is current until December 2010, include the Olympic Games, the Melbourne Cup, Australian rugby union and cricket test matches, the 2006 FIFA World Cup and rugby league and Australian rules football matches.

It is important to understand that the antisiphoning list does not guarantee that an event will be on free-to-air television. If the free-to-air broadcasters decline to purchase rights to listed events, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts may delist such events, allowing pay television providers to acquire the rights to televise the event. Moreover, of far greater importance, especially to the millions of Australians who have always enjoyed the coverage of nationally significant sporting events on free-to-air television, is the loophole in the antisiphoning laws. This loophole has, very sadly, all but ensured that for the first time in more than 33 years Australia's Ashes test cricket series in England from July to September 2005 will not be broadcast on free-to-air television, despite the fact that it is on the antisiphoning list. How has this happened? Free-to-air broadcasters blame a loophole in the antisiphoning laws. Remember that the antisiphoning regime was established to ensure important sporting events, such as the Ashes cricket, would not become exclusive to pay-TV licensees, such as Foxtel.
