talk.start.para: âThis evening I want to talk about an event held in the ACT during January, called the `Dream On' Cuboree for the ACT for 2005. Mr Peter Harris, a leading member of the scouting community in the ACT, came up with the original concept of a cuboree some years ago, and this most recent event was the seventh cuboree to be held. They are held every three years and we have witnessed growing participation and popularity each time. In fact, other states and territories are now holding or developing similar cuborees within their own jurisdictions.

speech.para: I had the pleasure of visiting the camp site during this three- to four-day event in the middle of January. The cuboree was held at the Kangaroo Flat camping ground here in Canberraâan area that was very savagely affected by the 18 January 2003 fires which occurred in the ACT. It is an absolute testament to the dedication and determination of everyone involved in the scouting movement in Canberra, under the leadership of the Chief Commissioner of Scouts ACT, Neville Tomkins, that they could even imagine going ahead and holding a cuboree of this size on this site, given the damage that was incurred just over two years ago.

The theme for this year's cuboree was `Dream on' with activities around the camp site encouraging the youngsters to establish their dreams, learn to have the courage to strive for them and learn how to encourage others in their team to dare to dream with them. A time capsule from the 1996 cuboree, containing the hopes and the dreams of cubs at that particular function, was dug up by some who were there at that time.

Altogether 1,150 people, including more than 800 cubs, plus leaders and volunteers, attended this cuboree. That is a pretty large number of folk under tents for three to four days in the heat of January in Canberra. If any member is planning a similarly large event, I can assure them that I have a recipe available from the people who ran this cuboree, which will produce spaghetti bolognaise for 1,150 people. The recipe starts with 195 kilograms of mince and 140 kilograms of spaghetti. That gives you an idea of the enormous size of this particular event.

When I visited, with other guests for the afternoon, I was absolutely moved by the enthusiasm of the leaders and the volunteers in ensuring that these young people from the ACT, New South Wales and some areas of South Australia, who came to participate in this three-yearly event, had the best time and learnt a great deal. There was a massive camaraderie and it was all a testament to the people who organised it.

On a second issue, I would like to make brief reference to the recent very tragic fires in South Australia. As the member for Canberra, I can assure the House and the member for Grey, Mr Wakelin, of my concern and compassion on behalf of the community here towards the community in South Australia and the Eyre Peninsula. The events there brought back bad memories for us and we know the sort of trauma that they were facing during those tragic fires in South Australia.

I have to commend the ACT government. They very quickly got in touch with the authorities in South Australia and offered ACT SES assistance. A public servant, Di Butcher, who achieved a great deal in successfully establishing and running the ACT Bushfire Recovery Centre, has, I believe, visited South Australiaâat their wishâon several occasions to assist them to set up a similar sort of arrangement in that area of South Australia. We learnt a great deal through the necessities of the events surrounding the fires here in January 2003 and we were only too happy to offer whatever support, compassion and sympathy we could.

The residents of Duffyâpart of my constituency that was very severely hit by the fires of 2003âimmediately started fundraising and I believe they have already raised over $2,000, and that amount is increasing. The Duffy residents suffered the sort of damage that epitomised what was unfortunately felt here in Canberra and they immediately wanted to step in and offer some sort of support to those people on the Eyre Peninsulaâand they are doing so, along with other people in my constituency. I take the opportunity to offer, on behalf of my constituents, our sympathies to those people who were so severely and tragically affected on the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia, and our ongoing support in any way that we can offer, given our experience.

talk.start.para: âYesterday in this House the member for Wills made reference to one of my constituents, Mrs Melinda Poor, who is also the Liberal candidate for the state seat of Balcatta in the upcoming election. The member for Wills recounted the events that occurred when Mrs Poor called into a radio station where the former member for Stirling and I were having a live debate. He believes her call caused a great deal of electoral grief for the Labor member for Stirling.

speech.para: I might remind the House of what actually transpired. The debate between the former member and me occurred not long after the Labor Party released their new family tax package. Astonishingly, this package would have disadvantaged struggling families in many areas of my electorate and around Australia. Mrs Poor called ABC radio to express her concern that her husband and three children would be roughly $500 worse off under the Labor Party's policy. At that time she was pregnant with her fourth child and when the baby was born she would have become roughly $1,000 worse off under Labor's policy. So Mrs Poor, quite rightly, called her local member and asked her what she thought of local families being disadvantaged in this way.

The former member for Stirling replied that the Labor Party would need to look at changing the package. At the time, this rightly caused a media storm as the opposition struggled to explain why they would adopt such a punitive tax regime. Following the former member for Stirling's comments, the Labor Party gagged her and she was not allowed to talk to the media for rest of the campaign. My campaign team and I really had a laugh when the Labor Party would not even let her finish a prearranged commitment to do a 90-second pre-recorded interview about her hobbies.

I would suggest to the member for Wills that it was not one of my constituents calling talkback radio to truthfully express her concern about how her family was going to suffer under a Labor government that caused the former member for Stirling electoral grief. It was the person who dreamed up Labor's failed electoral platform plus the actions of the former member that were to blame. The people of Stirling were not prepared to wear a party that attacked the living standards of those described by one Perth reporter as `world-class battlers'.

As to the concerns expressed that Mrs Poor and I had met before she called the radio, it is well known that we did. What Mrs Poor actually said later in the same article quoted by the member for Wills is that we did not know each other well. Fortunately, though, since that time I have come to know Mrs Poor because I have been campaigning with her as she is the Liberal candidate for Balcatta. I have spent time campaigning and listening to the concerns that the people of Stirling have about the Gallop state Labor government. I can tell the member for Wills that the people of the state electorate of Balcatta are sick of the indecision, the committees, the inquiries, the scoping studies, the reports and the total inability of the state Labor government to make decisions and to get on with the job of governing the great state of Western Australia. They are crying out to be represented by real people from their own communities who understand their needs and aspirationsâexactly the sort of candidate represented by Mrs Poor. So I predict that, just as the people of Stirling rejected federal Labor, the people of WA will reject state Labor on 26 February and vote for Colin Barnett and his Liberal team to give us decisions, not more delays.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to talk on the issue of mine safety in China. At a time when Australia's relationship with China is becoming increasingly important to our economic future, I address the House this evening on a subject that must not be ignored in the context of negotiating a bilateral trade agreement, future investment flows and the production and manufacture of our traded resources, goods and services. That subject is, of course, human rights and core labour standards.

speech.para: Earlier this week a massive gas explosion ripped through the Sunjiawan coalmine in north-eastern China, killing more than 200 workers. This is a great tragedy for the families of those workers and their communities, and I am sure all Australians extend their deepest sympathy to them. The incident itself is particularly concerning because the Sunjiawan colliery is one of the bigger, more modern mines in China and because the blast follows a complete overhaul of safety ordered by the Prime Minister. This followed two earlier underground disasters late last year in which 166 miners were killed in Shaanxi and 148 killed in Henan. Officially, and interestingly, it is reported that more than 6,000 workers were killed in coalmines alone in China last year. But human rights and labour organisations claim that the real figure is closer to 20,000 deaths per year.

I hope we would agree on both sides of the parliament that the main goal of economic development and trade is to advance the human condition. I hope we would also agree that respect for human life and the protection of human rights is and must remain at the core of all our public policy. As the President of the ACTU noted earlier this week, free trade advocates would argue that the market will automatically provide for improvements in living standards for working people and for the protection of their human rights. This ignores the fact that all markets are actually regulated at some level. For example, the World Trade Organisation establishes trade rules incorporating a dispute resolution process and an enforcement mechanism, and those rules are supported by all the major nations. Similarly, the International Labour Office promulgates international labour standards to assure human rights and effective minimum standards for working people and employer representatives, yet these rules are seen by the major nations as a fetter on market forces.

Our government, unfortunately, refuses to sign ILO Convention 176, the Safety and Health in Mines Convention, not because our mining industry cannot meet it but because it is a government ideologically opposed to the rights of working men and women to guaranteed minimum labour standards and to the right of the ILO to promote them. This is a government committed to dragging Australian labour standards, including health and safety, down to the lowest common denominator of the trading nations. This is unacceptable to the opposition and it is unacceptable to the great majority of working men and women in Australia. We in the Labor party believe in the right to collectively bargain and in the need for effective minimum standards to provide the market with parameters that ensure working men and women get a fair share of the fruits of their endeavours. Core labour standards are also essential to guarantee more sustainable development and rising standards of living for people in poorer countries. There is no trickle-down effect.

At the moment China is the key market supporting Australia's resources boom, but it is also a potential competitor in resources trade and it is certainly a competitor in manufacturing. It is therefore incumbent on the government, when entering discussions with China about bilateral trade, to also talk about equal core labour standards that uphold the rights of working people to a safe workplace, the right to fair minimum wages and conditions and the right to collectively bargain. It is time for the government, too, to look at the track record of companies on labour practices when they invest in this country, particularly in the area of health and safety. This is one of the areas in which the Treasurer and the Foreign Investment Review Board could, and should, impose conditions on foreign investment in the nation's best interest.

It is time for Australia to play a bigger role in international labour markets, particularly in promoting health and safety in the workplace and respect for human life. International trade negotiations are one of the key avenues we can and must use to do this. It is now up to our trade negotiators in the proposed Australia-China free trade agreement to have regard to these accepted minimum international standards, core working standards developed by a tripartite process at the International Labour Officeâemployer, worker and government representativesâstandards which any decent human being would expect. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI stand here today to highlight the threats we face in the war on terrorism. As a former senior sergeant with the Victoria Police Counter Terrorism Coordination Unit, this issue is particularly close to me. Australians abroad have endured much heartache at the hands of terrorists from the September 11 plane crashes in America to the bombing of the Sari nightclub in Bali. The threat of terrorism still hangs over Australia, and our darkest hour may be yet to come.

speech.para: The release of Mamdouh Habib from Guantanamo Bay and his recent interviews raise the dilemma: is he a terrorist or a person who for no reason has been targeted by authorities both here and abroad? As Habib was recently released and has spoken openly about his experiences in detention, which have been well reported in the media and by the Australian Labor Party, I feel it is important to look at what we currently know about his experiences prior to his arrest in Pakistan in 2001.

In 1991, while in New York, Habib was invited by Ibrahim el-Gabrowny to rally support outside the courthouse where el-Gabrowny's cousin el-Sayyid Nosair was standing trial for the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane. Apart from Habib and el-Gabrowny, Nosair's supporters in the courtroom included Mahmud Abouhalima. Abouhalima, el-Gabrowny and Habib were all followers of Omar Abdul Rahman, otherwise known as the `blind sheikh'âa militant cleric who calls for his followers to kill the enemies of God. Habib continued to have contact with el-Gabrowny and Omar Abdul Rahman after leaving New York. He even rallied other members of his Sydney mosque to help Rahman financially and to protest against his imprisonment.

On 26 February 1993, a bombing at the World Trade Centre in New York killed six people and injured over 1,000. Habib's friends, Abouhalima, el-Gabrowny and Rahman were all later arrested, charged and convicted for their involvement with the World Trade Centre bombing in 1993. Back in Australia, Sheikh Abu Ayman, head of the Haldon Street prayer hall in Lakemba, told the ABC's Four Corners program entitled `Worst of the Worst?' that Habib was lobbying for members to join a jihad and that he had turned up to the prayer hall wearing a ninja outfit on one occasion and an Osama bin Laden t-shirt on another.

Habib would later assist fundraising efforts for the Chechen rebels. There are reported links between the Chechnya rebels and al-Qaeda but, regardless, Chechen rebels have been responsible for a range of terrorist attacks, from the 700 hostages taken at the Moscow theatre in October 2002 to the Beslan school massacre in September 2004, where over 320 people, half of them children, were killed.

Habib's behaviour at the Haldon Street prayer hall led to Sheikh Abu Ayman banning him from the group. In 2000, Habib travelled to Pakistan for two months and upon his return announced his plans to go to Afghanistan to join the bin Laden camp. Mr Habib's friend Ibrahim Fraser told Four Corners that, in a conversation they had had, Habib had explained that he wanted to live in a bin Laden camp and that it would be a good life.

On 29 July 2001, Habib again visited Pakistan. It is believed that during this visit Mr Habib travelled to Afghanistan, as well as to Pakistan, and participated in an advanced al-Qaeda training course. Habib was captured after the September 11 attacks in Pakistan with two Germans: Ibrahim Diab and Bekim Ademi. Diab and Ademi were part of the Hamburg al-Qaeda cell led by Mohammed Atta, the lead hijacker in the September 11 attacks. Diab and Ademi were arrested after participating in an al-Qaeda training camp near Kabul.

Habib has not provided details as to why he was in Afghanistan, preferring to keep this a mystery, even during Channel 9's 60 Minutes,where they paid him for half a story. The accounts of Mamdouh Habib's whereabouts over the past decade suggest a long association with figures tied to the al-Qaeda network, a keen interest in fundraising for convicted terrorist figures, and a person who has tried to recruit others to support a jihad holy war and who has a travel itinerary based around Afghanistan, which at the time was a haven for terrorists. It is a shame that 60 Minutes, with their $200,000 terrorist money, and the Australian Labor Party have let Habib's lies get in the way of the truth.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask that the member for La Trobe withdraw his last comment accusing the Labor Party of being associated with lies concerning Mamdouh Habib. That is clearly offensive to representatives of the Labor Party, and it should be withdrawn.
âIn deference to the member for Barton, I ask the member for La Trobe to withdraw that last statement.
âOn the Speaker's request, without condition, I withdraw.

âI rise tonight to pay tribute to the parliamentary career ended prematurely by the ill health of Mark Latham, the member for Werriwa. Mark was elected on 29 January 1994. It was appropriate that he was the member for Werriwa given that his mentorâthe great Gough Whitlamârepresented that seat with such distinction, including as Prime Minister in the years between 1972 and 1975. Mark Latham's service federally followed other public service, in particular his service as a local councillor on Liverpool council between 1987 and 1994 and as mayor from 1991.

speech.para: Mark had humble origins. He was proud of being a `houso'. He never shied away from being the boy from Green Valley. He was a person of ideas. He was a prolific writer. He helped write five books, most notably Civilising global capital: new thinking for Australian Labor. He was a great communicator verbally, and I think this was his greatest asset. He was articulate, clever, incisive, passionate and humorous. He could be tough. He was devastating on his opponents, but he could also be gentle, as he was when he spoke about his mum, and that certainly endeared him to me on a personal level.

I did not always agree with Mark's viewsâfar from it. We had major disagreements over economic policy and social policy both within and outside the forums of the Australian Labor Party. Mark, however, was always prepared to engage in political debate. He was indeed a great political figure. Whether you agreed with him or not, he always made a difference; you noticed that Mark Latham was there, both within and outside the party.

One of his last public forums was in my electorate of Grayndler, at Leichhardt Town Hall, on Monday, 22 November last year. We sent out invitations. People thought it was rather odd that I was doorknocking just after the election. Some 600 or 700 people filled the hallâwe do not know, because it was packed. Many people were turned away. He engaged on a whole range of issues. He took questions from all comers.

I did not vote for him to be leader of the Labor Party. I believed that Kim Beazley was the best prospect to win the prime ministership. But as the leader he certainly set the agenda. He had the Howard government on the run over issues such as parliamentary superannuation and the free trade agreement, where he came up with a clever and principled solution to some of the internal disagreements the Labor Party had of moving amendments to protect the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and to protect our cultural content. In the end, the government had to cave in to a Labor position. He led a principled position in opposition to the Iraq war. I marched with Mark, young Oliver and my family at the demonstration in Sydney where more than a quarter of a million people marched in favour of peace just before that war began.

It is unfortunate that Mark's career has been cut short by ill health. I wish him, his wife, Janine, and his wonderful two boys, Oliver and Isaac, all the best. Parliamentary life is very hard; it can be particularly hard on people's health. Mark has made a decision that is in the interests of himself and his family. I am sure that all parliamentarians wish him well.

subdebateinfo.title: Paterson Electorate: Jetstar Fleet Maintenance Base

talk.start.para: âI advise the House of the announcement by Jetstar at Williamtown Airport on 11 February to expand the heavy maintenance hangar at Newcastle. That is an investment of $29 million. The question is: why did they take the opportunity to choose Newcastle? There was extensive lobbying for the hangar facility for the maintenance of the A320 fleet to be located in New Zealand, in Singapore, in Hong Kong or in another area of Australia. What came through was the ability of the people in the Hunterâthe skill sets that we have in the Hunter.

speech.para: There are currently 82 people working in highly skilled jobs at the Jetstar facility at Newcastle airport. What is impressive is that 25 of those people are apprentices. They are committed to developing a skills base that will serve the country well. The announcement of the $29 million investment at Newcastle airport to service the A320 fleet will lead to an additional 50 jobs over five years, and I understand that more apprenticeships will be rolled out over that period. I am pleased that this will involve upskilling young people in our local area.

We also have in my electorate, on the other side of the airstrip, RAAF Base Williamtown. One of the key aspects of RAAF Base Williamtown, and it is the premier RAAF base in Australia, is that a lot of highly skilled technicians get posted there. They discover the lifestyle of the Hunter Valley. I think I am correct in saying that one of the highest exit rates from the Air Force is to Williamtownâwhether or not they go to another posting afterwards, they come back to our region, to Medowie and Salamander Bay. Those high levels of skills allowed British Aerospace to set up and build the Hawk lead-in fighters. We have a magnificent facility in our region that can service, build and develop aircraft. This project will expand on that. I can remember when this hangar facility was originally started by Impulse Airlines to service the Beechcraft 1900 aircraft. When QantasLink took over Impulse Airlines the aircraft were shifted up to the B717sâa new aircraft brought into the Australian fleetâand now we are moving to the A320s.

I am concerned at the reports of an open skies agreement between Australia and Singapore. If agreed to, this agreement will see an open arrangement for Singapore Airlines to fly from the east coast of Australia to the west coast of the USA. Singapore's Minister for Transport, Mr Yew Cheow Tong, has met with our government officials this week in Canberra. He said:

quote.para: It will give travellers a wider choice. I think it will result in lower fares and it will bring in additional visitors into Australia ... It is good for the economy and I do think they [the government] recognise that. There is scope for a lot more tourists in Australia.

speech.para: I do not dispute that, but I have to stand up for the people in my electorate. I have to stand up for the skills base on which Jetstar and Qantas have made their decision to invest in my electorate. I do not want to see competition at the expense of jobs at the airport in my electorate.

Today Qantas posted its half-yearly results to 31 December. On a revenue base of $6.4 billion, it has announced a profit before tax of $601.3 million. There are competitive pressures in the airline industry, and part of that competitive pressure is to maintain a profit so that it can service the needs of its shareholders. Qantas will be establishing 400 new flight attendants, to be based out of London. If we open up our airways to other countriesâcountries whose airlines are subsidised by their governmentsâQantas will have to look further offshore to reduce its costs. I fear that those jobs in maintenance may end up being located offshore. We had to bid strongly against New Zealand, against Hong Kong and against Singapore to have the fleet maintenance base in Australia. I say to our Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources: do not proceed with the open skies policy, because it will be to the detriment of my workers. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 5.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to talk about one of the most amazing people I have had the good fortune to meet. Sister Janet Mead of the Sisters of Mercy was last year made South Australian of the year. She accepted the honour in Glenelg, which is within the electorate of Hindmarsh. I think of Sister Mead as South Australia's very own Mother Theresa. I know that if she reads this speech she will chastise me, because her humility is also key to the way she lives her life and the work that she does. When most of us walk down the street and see a bedraggled unkempt man stumbling towards us we instantly put up all of the barriers we can. Without thinking, we see this person as different, as bad and as a danger to us, so we ignore him, pretend we do not see him and tell ourselves that there is nothing we can do to help him. We think that it is up to him to pull himself out of the life he lives and learn how to live like the rest of us. Of course that is complete rubbish; it is all about creating reasons to turn our backs on someone in need.

speech.para: Sister Janet Mead does not tell herself those sorts of lies. She spends her life with the poorest, most marginalised and most isolated people in our society. She works with the Adelaide Day Care Centre for Homeless Persons, the Brian Burdekin Clinic and Westcare. She helps homeless people overcome the tremendous challenges they face as they live their lives. The Adelaide day care centre has created a community for homeless people. Amongst other things, they can share a cooked lunch, work in the vegie garden or fix old furniture.

It is easy to misunderstand this work as some sort of sacrifice on the part of Sister Mead, but she feels fortunate to live her life in this way. She speaks of having learned so much from the people she works with. She says that she has learned a view of the world that places love above statusâwhat a lesson for all of us whose lives are entangled in this place. Sister Mead teaches us that what she does is within reach of all of us. It is possible to find our open-heartedness and give a little, even for those who have forgotten that they ever had a soft spot. She teaches us that, in doing so, we can grow. One day we might be brave enough to give a smile to someone who scares us and another day we might be able to make a donation or buy an edition of the Big Issue. In doing so, we open our hearts enough to make our lives and the lives of those we love a little easier because that is what happens when we give to others without any agenda or any expectation of getting something back.

Sister Janet Mead says she reaps the most amazing rewards from the people she works with. She tells a story of a homeless man who told her, `Life's journey is not to arrive at the grave safely in a well-preserved body but to skid in sideways, totally worn out, shouting âHoly hell, what a ride!â' We have all had the good fortune at one time or another to meet someone whose generosity and openness could make us realise that something was not quite right in our lives. Sister Janet Mead is one of those people. For all the fear that we put in the space between ourselves and anyone else who we perceive to be different from us, Sister Janet Mead teaches that we are fooling ourselves and tricking ourselves out of learning that when we ignore suffering we contribute to it.

As a society we have a great deal to learn about becoming a community. Increasingly people are finding that the teachings of Christianity can help us to connect with our world, but as we do that we must be watchful that we do not close off from others who we perceive to have lost their way. When we do help those people we must be watchful that we do not define Christian values too narrowly because, as Sister Janet Mead demonstrates each day, Jesus Christ would have turned his back on no-one. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âHonourable members would know I am not one easily given to hubris, but I would like to highlight the clearest possible demonstration of a turnaround of fortunes of two sectors of my electorate of Hinkler in Central Queensland. Since the Howard government came to office there have been huge improvements in national indicators such as unemployment, interest rates and inflation. We are now seeing this filter down into areas which have had endemic levels of unemployment in the past.

speech.para: My electorate of Hinkler, and for that matter the entire Wide Bay-Burnett region, is one such area. But the Wide Bay-Burnett region has experienced the biggest percentage drop in unemployment in Australia in the past 12 months, and my electorate has just had the best percentage increase in bulk-billing rates in Queensland and one of the best in Australia over the last 12 months. Wide Bay-Burnett's unemployment rate now sits at six per cent, down a full 3.6 per cent in December 2004 from December 2003. Over the same period, employment numbers, now at 99,100, increased by 10.4 per centâa remarkable figure. This can be clearly attributed to sound economic management of the nation, which has given businesses the confidence to invest in regional areas and to provide much needed local employment.

The region has also gone ahead in the health sphere, with Hinkler's bulk-billing rate going up by 12.8 per cent between December 2003 and December 2004, and it now stands at 60.5 per cent. This might not seem significant to many members but consider this: Hinkler's bulk-billing rate has gone up by 16.9 per cent since 2002 when, in many other parts of the nation, it went down. I am confident we will see further improvements because we have not yet seen the full effect of the coalition's additional $7.65 payment for concession card holders and children under 16 or the annual impact of the doctors being paid the full schedule fee.

These two indicators fly in the face of the ALP's doom and gloom message that they put out in my electorate during the election campaign. It is the clearest possible demonstration that they were wrong. The area has often been targeted as one of the worst unemployment areas in Australia; it had endemic unemployment. We now see the electorate, as a result of our economic management, coming out of that. I congratulate the government on its focus and on behalf of my electors I thank the government for the improvements that have made an area that was very much challenged in past years a better one. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSome questions need to be seriously asked at this point in time and in this place. What kind of country do we live in when a government minister tells citizens with a serious health problem that they should hope that some charitable doctorâor, in this case, dentistâwill come forward to solve their problem? What kind of country do we live in that a government can spend $66 billion in a matter of minutes in an effort to get re-elected but hopes that a charitable person will come forward and pick up the slack for an area of serious government neglect? What depths have we sunk to as a society when we will not spend any money to fix the teeth of low-income earners and pensioners even after 14 years of economic growth, record high tax revenues and a $4 billion surplus?
âThat's the state government's job.

âNot under the Constitution, the member for Gilmore. Australia is that kind of country in the year 2005. The serious dereliction of public dental health that has emerged in the last few days is, sadly, not a new story. Since the year 2000, the Illawarrra Dental Health Action Group has been campaigning to `stop the rot'. As recently as the last election campaign, my attention was drawn to the case of a pensioner in Wollongong, in addition to the case that was reported in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, who had two teeth remaining. He has been patiently waiting for his dentures to be made, because he could not afford to pay for them himself. He was not complaining but he was certainly keen to tell me that he dreamed of the day when he could again enjoy a steak or even a piece of fruit.

speech.para: When Mr Abbott told John Laws on Tuesday, `There are lots of tragedies in life,' he could not have been more correct, but the biggest tragedy faced by this country right now in health is that we have a completely uncaring minister. At the last election, Labor pledged $300 million towards a Commonwealth dental program in an attempt to fix the decay that the government has allowed to set in and to cut the waiting lists among low-income earners and pensioners, which was a successful program of the former Keating government.

The government and the minister have acknowledged that the Keating government's program was a successâthat is, until it was axed in 1997. The program reduced waiting lists and gave those in our community who could least afford it the opportunity to access dental health services that can reasonably be expected to be available in a modern first-world country. When times get a bit tough, the government is often quick to blame the states, but a cursory glance at section 51 of the Constitution shows that the powers of the federal government extend to dental services. I am sure they would not want to give away other sections of section 51, such as trade, tax, telephones and trademarks, so why the flick pass on dental health? (Time expired)

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
Mr HUNT
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI want to talk today about the potential for technical college education within and servicing the electorate of Flinders. I want to set out the need, the opportunity and the steps forward. The need is very clear. The technical college education at state level has largely been failing young people on the Mornington Peninsula, at the top of Westernport and on Bass Coast. That is a result of changes made over a decade ago, but the gaps are there. In the towns of Hastings and Koo Wee Rup and on the Bass Coast there is a young population with needs to develop skills, be they in welding, plumbing, some form of manufacturing, engineering, marine, maritime or IT.

speech.para: In relation to that need, there are two very clear proposals which I wish to present to the House today. The first is for a technical college, under the Australian technical college system, based in the south-east of Melbourne. That college would have, at the very least, two annexes which are relevant to my electorate. The first of those would be an annex in the town of Hastings, under the Australian technical college proposal, in conjunction with Westernport Secondary College. This is something to which I am committed and for which I want to fight. What I believe about this is that if an annex of an Australian technical college were constructed at Westernport Secondary College, the opportunity would exist to help students with a marine and maritime focus to cooperate with BlueScope Steel, the Mornington Peninsula Shire, Westernport Secondary and all of the maritime related companies and firms within the area. I think that, in conjunction with a campus at Pakenham servicing Koo Wee Rup, Clyde, Devon Meadows and Lang Lang, which would have a building and agricultural focus, this is a tremendous opportunity.

The second part of the proposal is to service the Bass Coast region through the town of Wonthaggi. I believe that there is potential for an annex for a Gippsland based Australian technical college. The government is committed to a Gippsland based Australian technical college. My argument, in conjunction with Russell Broadbent, the member for McMillan, is that we should push to have some representation through a local annex in Wonthaggi. That would be a tremendous boost for the people of Phillip Island, San Remo, Granville, the hills areas, Dalyston, Kilcunda and Wonthaggi. I put those two proposals on the table. I endorse them and I am going to fight for them.

talk.start.para: âI would like to draw the House's attention to the declining birth rates in regional Australia, particularly in the Hunter-New England region, in which my electorate of Newcastle is located. The latest figures show that between 1999 and 2003 the number of mothers giving birth per year in the Hunter-New England region fell by 4.7 per cent. Statewide the figure fell by 1.1 per cent. That means the number of mothers giving birth in our region is declining more than four times faster than it is in the rest of the state. Sadly, this trend is evident in other regions of New South Wales. If it continues, regions do face the danger of terminal decline and Australia is in danger of losing one of the most important aspects of its identity.

speech.para: For a government whose junior partner is The Nationals, it is shameful that the regions do face annihilation. For a government that prides itself on family values, we have seen precious few policies to assist regional families or sustain rural and regional communities. Young people move away to gain education and do not return. Job insecurity drives people to the cities, and skills and knowledge disappear with them. Health and disability services dwindle, and the increasing costs of isolation and distance continue unchecked. Vital infrastructure that links regional communities and provides expanded market opportunities is neglected or removed. And what is the first off the block in the reform agenda of this newly re-elected government? We have had a hypocritical moral values debate about abortion, tighter wages control through a new industrial relations regime, tax cuts for the wealthy and competition deregulation that will make it harder for small business. What we do need are clever policy ideas and reform that boost productivity by sustaining regional economies, by supporting family friendly workplaces and by reducing the economic barriers to having childrenânot the same tired old agenda that the government will be bringing back and ramming through the Senate from July.

The Rural Doctors Association of Australia tells us that the number of GP obstetricians in New South Wales has halved since 1996. In fact the greatest medical work force shortages are in regional Australia. Recent estimates of the cost of seeing a child born last year through education from preschool to university suggest a price tag of $200,000. If you add the cost for regional parents of sending their children away for education, it will be even more. Expenditure per child-care place under the Howard government has dropped by a massive 10.2 per cent, and now we find that parents will not see a cent of the promised 30 per cent rebate on child-care fees until the 2006-07 financial year.

The essentials of raising children have become much more difficult under the Howard government. Is it any wonder then that the Australian Institute of Family Studies reports that one of the main factors dissuading people from starting a family is economic insecurity. Yet the report also found that 90 per cent of people surveyed want to have children. We must get our family policies right, especially in our regions, to allow people to fulfil their parenting dreams. The Howard government's cynical regional rorts scheme may have bought it another term in government, but it will never be a substitute for the real policies needed to help families in regional Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe member for Newcastle is quite correct when she points out that the declining birth rate is one of the challenges that we face as a nation. The combination of the ageing population and the declining birth rate present policy challenges which this government has commenced to addressed. I do, however, wonder where the member for Newcastle stands on the issue of the Medicare funding of abortions, which is of course a conscience voteâas it should beâin this place. The fact that we have 100,000 abortions in this country each year no doubt does move in some direction towards reducing the national birth rate. However, I did not rise in this chamber to talk about that particular topic at this time.

speech.para: I am pleased to announce that the bulk-billing rate in my electorate of Fisher has continued to rise as a result of the Howard government's investment in Medicare and is now at 70.2 per cent. The bulk-billing rate in Fisher increased 10.3 percentage points in 2004 compared with 2003. This latest increase shows that the Howard government's investment in Medicare is delivering more affordable GP services for everyone living on the Sunshine Coast and in surrounding regions. This increase in Fisher reflects the national trend. The health minister has done a wonderful job in helping to boost the rate of bulk-billing. The national GP bulk-billing rate is at its highest level in 2Â½ years. The rate increased again during the December quarter 2004 and is now 72.4 per cent, an increase of 5.9 percentage points since the government introduced its Medicare package a year ago. The national GP bulk-billing rate for people 65 years of age and over also increased during the December quarter to its highest level in almost four years of 82.7 per cent, an increase of 8.7 percentage points on the December quarter of 2003.

Locally, as well as nationally, more than seven out of 10 GP attendances are being bulk-billed, and across the nation more than eight out of 10 GP attendances for people over 65 are being bulk-billed. This is the first time in 10 years that the national bulk-billing rate has increased over four successive quarters. GPs who bulk-bill Commonwealth concession card holders and children under 16 receive an extra $5.10 or $7.65, depending on their location. This is in addition to a recent increase in the Medicare rebate to $30.85. GPs now have more incentive to bulk-bill their patientsâfor example, if a GP in Tasmania bulk-bills a concession card holder or child then he or she will receive $38.50. This compares with a rate of $25.70 in November 2003. Since the introduction of bulk-billing incentives, all states and territories have experienced an increase in GP bulk-billing rates. In my state of Queensland, the most wonderful part of the country in which to live, the bulk-billing rate has increased by 7.6 percentage points to 69.3 per cent. The government do have the recipe right. We are delivering for Australians, particularly those Australians who are fortunate enough to live on Queensland's wonderful Sunshine Coast.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âOrder! In accordance with standing order 193 the time for members' statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 16 February, on motion by Mrs Markus:

motion.para: That the address be agreed to.

talk.start.para: âIt is a pleasure to be able to stand in this chamber once again and make an address-in-reply as the re-elected member for Paterson. Paterson's curse is a weed which, no doubt, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, in your role as a rural member, you would only too well understand. It is a noxious weed to livestock. It spreads like another suburban weed, lantanaâand like lantana its flowers are purple. When you see a field of it off in the distance and do not know what it is, you might think it is rather picturesque. But, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is a curse.

speech.para: It is a curse because it is virtually impossible to get rid of and it can kill off your livestock. Paterson's curse also applied to the federal seat of Paterson, which, since it was recreated in 1993, had not been won by the sitting member once. Last year, I broke politics' Paterson's curse. I want to recognise that there are many new members in this parliament and I want to remark on the people that they have replaced. When I was voted out in 1998 it took me a long time to come to terms with failure. For the first time I had to take a long hard look at what I did when I was the member for Paterson. I have done that again this time around and I can honestly say it is much nicer to analyse the results from my current position, as opposed to the position I was in after the election in 1998.

We in the coalition showed that elections in marginal seats do not start when the election is calledâthey run over the entire term. Weâmy staff and Iâworked very hard to attract more funding, better services and better representation over the entire three-year period. We never gave up fighting for the things that were important to the people in Paterson. It is a fight we will continue over the next term of this government and beyond. We have a hunger to improve services and get more funding for areas such as aged care, roads and health.

Paterson has four local government areas in its boundaries: Port Stephens, Dungog, Gloucester, and Great Lakes, as well as small parts of the cities of Maitland and Newcastle. Two of these areas are coastal, two are rural and the parts of Maitland and Newcastle are regional, almost urban. The coastal communities are largely made up of retirees. The bay areas of Fullerton Cove, Stockton Bight, Fingal Bay, Shoal Bay, Nelson Bay, Salamander Bay, Tanilba Bay and Lemon Tree Passage are attracting more affluent retirees. In Foster-Tuncurry in the north the retirees are not as affluent as they are in the south. Statistics show they are about five years older on average than their counterparts in the lower part of the electorate. The Maitland area, including Thornton and Morpeth, is a more prosperous area. Thornton is one of the fastest growing suburbs in the state and there are many young families in the suburb.

Beresfield, Woodbury and Tarro are older suburbs that are affordable for low-income earners and still in an area which is close to health, transport and education facilities. The shire of Gloucester is a farming area for mainly dairy and beef. Farmers have done it tough over the past two years or so, with many experiencing hardship as a result of the drought and dairy deregulation. Every small town along the Bucketts WayâLimeburners Creek, Allworth, Booral, Stroud, Stroud Road, Wards River, Craven and Stratfordâhas a popular hall, a voting place and a need for better roads, schools and, indeed, basic access to health care. Every small community along the Pacific Highway, whether it be Karuah, North Arm Cove, Tea Gardens, Hawks Nest, Nerong, Bulahdelah, Wootton, Coolongolook or Nabiac, has a hall, church or a meeting place. These communities may have a rural fire service or a church volunteer group. They may have a popular hall which is maintained by a small number of hardworking community committees.

The results for Paterson in the 2004 election varied from a primary vote swing to me of two per cent in the areas which were traditionally liberal to around 12 per cent in the areas which I would have considered Labor heartland. I am deeply humbled by the result. Although the election was in October last year this has been my first opportunity in the parliament to thank those who have helped me in the campaign. We expect our staff to know a little about a lot of things. We expect them to know about tax, telecommunications and Centrelink, to have a good local knowledge of our electorates, to keep us informed and on time and to get us to the right place. We ask them to work incredibly long hours during the sitting weeks and the non-sitting weeks. Then we back up and expect them to put in three times the effort during an election.

I want to personally thank my staffâMike, Anna and Juliaâfor being such a tremendous support to me and our community over the past years. I also want to thank my campaign team for their tremendous work: Bob Geoghegan, the campaign director and John Murphy, the treasurer. On the advisory team I want to thank Josh Hodges, Sally Dover, Michelle Moffatt, Daryl Lewis and Peter West. I want to thank Sally Dover's husband, Gary, and Alan Ray for driving my mobile office around the electorate for me when Daryl could not. And thank you to Alan's better half, Marty Ray, for keeping him company. It was a sad day when the mobile office rolled and was written off a week out from polling day. But, within days, I had a replacement on the road to make sure the people did not forget me and were not denied access.

On polling day, there were around 600 people working for me in the electorate of Paterson, and I sincerely thank them for all their help. I cannot name them all in the time allowed, but there are some community leaders that I would like to thankâRoss Presgrave; Margaret Godsmark; Gerry Jermon; Sue Slater; Jan McWilliams; Peter Mason and his wife, Anne Mason; Trevor and Jacquie Wark; Sean and Robyn Brennanâwho have all become community leaders through the Port Stephens crime forum work. Doreen Bradley, a natural leader in her community who has been recognised with an OAM, has become a great supporter because we stood up and fought for the issues that were important to her and her community.

I would like to thank the Young Liberals team, who letterboxed the hilliest parts of our electorate. My thanks also go out to the former state director, Scott Morrison, who managed the state secretariat better than it had ever been managed before. We will miss you. At the end, I owe especial thanks to my brothers and sisters in Christ in the Raymond Terrace Christian Life Centre, in particular my pastors, Colin Haddow and Rod Smith. All members in this House need the support of their families, and my especial thanks go to my wife, Cynthia, who gives me unconditional support, my twin sons, David and RobbieâI had the proudest moment last Sunday in witnessing their first parade as naval cadets from training ship Tobrukâand of course my daughter, Samantha. I thank them all.

Now that we are well and truly on our way in this new term of government, I want to highlight some of the issues that we are fighting for in Paterson. Firstly, I will address the issue of schools and RAAF Base Williamtown. Salt Ash Public School in my electorate is affected by aircraft noise from the RAAF weapons range at Salt Ash. This has been the case for a number of years, which is why it was a ridiculous state of affairs when the New South Wales government had just completed building a new classroom without noise amelioration. The Minister for Defence and I announced that we would fix the New South Wales government's botched job and build a new library, this time with appropriate noise insulation. The Salt Ash Weapons Range has had a significant impact on the learning of children at that school and also the Williamtown Public School, for which I have also successfully lobbied for amelioration measures.

In the case of other schools in my area, the P&Cs are almost tearing their hair out, trying to get the right facilities for their children. Grahamstown Public School was built only 10 years ago by the state government, long after the base was built, so it included noise attenuation measures. But it was built without airconditioning. This means that in summer they cannot shut the doors because it is too hot, and in the winter they cannot shut the doors because the fumes from the gas heater are dangerous. That is why I am so pleased that the public schools will now be able to apply directly to the Australian government for funds instead of going through the state government, as a part of our $700 million package. This means that Grahamstown Public School P&C can apply for funding for airconditioning directly from the Australian government and not worry about the New South Wales education department deeming it not to be a priority.

The P&Cs of all of the schools in my electorate, whether they be in Dungog, Medowie, Gloucester, Stroud Road, Forster or Bulahdelah, to mention a few, can apply for funding. Last year, we faced the hottest November on record, yet the roll-out program for airconditioning in schools is over four or five years. But, for the first time, parents and teachers do not have to worry about any roll-out program developed by an overpaid policy officer in an airconditioned office in Sydney. We will deliver results.

The other issue I would like to raise in relation to education is my continued push for a high school in the Medowie-Tilligerry area. Finally, we have the state government waking up to the fact that this is a growing and developing area, with a number of students, that will support the existence of a high school.

Turning my attention now to health matters in my electorate, I received letters of congratulation from a pensioner in Salamander Bay. I sorted out a Medicare matter for him earlier in the year, and in the process of the correspondence he made some remarks about politicians and how we do not look after our constituents. I did not hear anything from this pensioner until about one week after the election, when he wrote to me and thanked me for my help. He said he voted for me on the back of that help. I was flummoxed, because I thought he had voted informal or, worse, for a minor party.

His comments about bulk-billing and the cost of visiting a doctor helped me give the Prime Minister and health minister feedback on what we should do with Medicare. Even though bulk-billing has risen from 53.3 per cent to 59.7 per cent, no doctors are bulk-billing in the bay area, and a policy which did not recognise bulk-billing black spots would not work. People would have to change doctors to get the benefit of a policy. A full rebate will work for people like Claude.

I mentioned that in the top end of my electorate there were many who are considered frail aged. One of my volunteers, Richard, who did some letterboxing for me, is 78 years of age. But he is one of the many older Australians who no longer drives but walks everywhere. Some older drivers elect to have a restricted licence which gets them to the nearest business district. I want to thank the health minister for recognising this mobility issue and announcing a Medicare office for the Forster-Tuncurry area. Richard will now be able to walk to the Medicare office to claim his rebate.

But there are still holes in the health service in this area. We need public hospital facilities in the Great Lakes area, and I will keep on pushing our state government for some action. We have a private hospital in Forster called Cape Hawke Hospital. It has a complete floor of beds waiting to be developed. It defies logic why the state government will not enter into an arrangement to lease these beds to provide access for all in our community. The state government seem to think that hospital facilities in Taree are adequate for the burgeoning population in Forster-Tuncurry, Smiths Lakes and the Pacific Palms areas, but they simply do not understand. In the lower part of my electorate, Port Stephens desperately needs a hospital, but the New South Wales government will not even fund a feasibility study into whether the population in this area warrants a fully fledged hospital. The polyclinic at Nelson Bay, like our local schools, has had to fundraise to get airconditioning.

Turning my attention to telephones, we clearly want to improve communications in communities like Hawkes Nest, Tea Gardens, Vasey and Gresford. They need the internet to do business, both with business and the government. They need reliable landlines in case of emergencies and a mobile phone service that is not full of patches. A reliable communications service via the internet and a phone is just as vital in rural communities as good roads. In fact, I would argue that reliable internet and telephone services are more vital in towns further away from the city than they are in the city itself. I am not sure if many people in city electorates are aware of this, but some milk manufacturers now expect dairy farmers to submit their tenders via the internet. Any city member who argues that you cannot realistically expect a city-quality service in the bush should tell that to the milk manufacturers.

The difference between high-speed internet access and dial-up could be worth tens of thousands of dollars to a dairy farmer. I say this emphatically because areas such as Dungog and Gloucester have done it tough with deregulation. I would like to commend the former minister for communications and the current minister for continuing to upgrade the facilities to provide the internet to rural areas and for continuing to fix mobile telephone black spots. The geography of my electorate consists of hills and valleys. This causes mobile phone black spots, and both Vasey and Gresford have had new mobile phone towers switched on.

If there is one issue in my electorate that used to cause a huge amount of frustration with my constituents, and in some places it still does, it is that of television reception. For many of the elderly in my electorate television is their only source of entertainment and information. It sounds a bit fickle but, if a retiree is 80 and bedridden, this is the only form of entertainment and information that they have. For everyone else, staying in touch via the news or watching one or two favourite programs a year is all they expect. Earlier this year the new television booster tower for Stroud was switched on. It is still being adjusted to ensure a perfect picture every time, but at least it is up. Funding has been approved for similar towers in Booral, Elizabeth Beach and Smiths Lakes, which are operational. Funding of almost $750,000 was announced in mid-2004 for a television tower for the bay area in my electorate. It is a project that I am committed to. I will keep lobbying all of the stakeholders until we have the digital retransmission facility established on Gan Gan Hill.

In the area of aged care I am determined to get more aged care beds and funding for my electorate as a part of the government's roll-out of beds over the next three years. The minister for ageing has done a tremendous job since taking over this portfolio, continuing the work of former ministers and ensuring this area is well funded to support the growing needs throughout Australia. Many people come to retire in my electorate. The provision of aged care services that they may need in later years is an important part of their decision to move to communities such as Forster-Tuncurry and Port Stephens. If a person needs a nursing home they want to get into one near their families and friends. This is critically important.

I would also like to express my absolute zeal for bed places for couples. After years of marriage, raising a family and spending every night together, it is right that people can spend their nursing home days together too. The number of aged care places in the electorate of Paterson has doubled under the Howard government. Over the next three years it will increase substantially, with 940 places to be distributed in the Hunter region and 765 to be distributed in the mid North Coast region as part of the government's $2.2 billion Investing in Australia's Aged Care: More Places, Better Care Program.

We have had developments open up in the past six months, including the Port Stephens Gardens Nursing Centre in Salamander Bay, which is a 120-bed facility, and the opening of the Kularoo Gardens expansion in Forster. In the near future we hope to see Barclay Gardens in Tuncurry open, the expansion of the Myall Lodge in Hawks Nest, the expansion of the Great Lakes Nursing Home in Bulahdelah and the expansion of the Lara Aged Care Facility in Dungogânot forgetting the recently opened expansion of the GLAICA nursing home in Tuncurry.

I will continue to fight for one of the most important issues in my electorate, and that is roads. I have fought for a great deal of funding for projects in my electorate, such as the $20 million investment in Buckett's Way and the $25 million investment for Weakley's Drive. These projects, when completed, will bring great benefits to many communities. No-one should underestimate the importance of improved roads to the economies of regional areas. There are roads in the Dungog Shireâabout which Mayor Steve Low and I have spoken on many occasionsâwhich council cannot afford to fix on their current income. To make matters worse, they are ineligible for state government funding for particular roads.

Then there is the popular tourist route of Lakes Way, which links the Pacific Highway and Forster-Tuncurry with communities such as Pacific Palms and Smiths Lake. Tourist operators have told me how they tell motorists to take the alternative Pacific Highway route, instead of the scenic Lake's Way, because of concerns for their safety. To assist councils that cover these particular roads, the Australian government made a commitment during the election for $10 million to be spread across the Dungog, Port Stephens and Great Lakes shires, a commitment which must be matched by the state government. I have written to the New South Wales Minister for Roads, Michael Costa, about this project and the need for their support. I am hoping that he will take up our offer and improve the roads in my electorate.

In conclusion, health, communications, aged care and roads are just some of the issues I will continue to fight for in Paterson in this term of government. This is my first consecutive term as a member of parliament, and I want to let my constituents know that I am just as motivated this time as I was the very first day I was elected to this parliament. I would like to thank the people of Paterson for putting their faith in me, and everyoneâfrom staff to volunteersâwho has helped me along the way. It is an honour to represent the people of Paterson in this place of government, and that honour should never be treated lightly. I will give them the service that not only they expect but, more importantly, they deserve.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: âI want to use this opportunity today to talk about some very serious issues affecting the Australian economy. We all know that Australia has traditionally addressed skills shortages through mass migration programs. From the 1950s, public infrastructureâfor example, the huge Snowy Mountains schemeâwas built using migrant labour, with many individuals, but also families, moving away from the war-torn zones of the Northern Hemisphere. Those peopleâthey were often skilled but some were not skilledâworked initially on a whole range of government supported programs before moving into the wider economy. As we know, the original migrants who came in that period and their descendents form the backbone of our society today.

speech.para: We are very grateful for the mix and the cultural diversity that that migration wave brought, especially to areas like the great Goulburn and Murray valleys in my electorate, which are probably two of the most multiracial and multicultural communities in Australia. We are proud of that. That diversity has brought a richness of culture and resulted in a tolerant society. Our economy has been built on the hard work of these people, who have come to this country often with nothing more than a cardboard suitcase and a will to work.

Today Australia shares with most other developed economies a significant and growing shortage of skilled workers. This is a problem that is acknowledged throughout the OECD. Over a million skilled Australiansâmostly younger peopleâare working offshore, taking opportunities for professional advancement, perhaps with better pay. Certainly it is a chance for them to develop their careers, but we hope they will come back. On the other side of the coin, Australia depends on the flow from other countries of, in particular, health service professionals. Most rural and regional hospitals, particularly those in the public hospital system and certainly those in my part of the world, depend on overseas trained doctors. For example, over 70 per cent of the doctors in Goulburn Valley Health, which is the main Shepparton public hospital, are from overseas. They are very welcome and we appreciate their presence. Our health services would collapse without them.

Successive Australian governments have tackled the skills shortages. I mentioned at the beginning of my remarks the mass migrations of the fifties and a little before then. No government has as conscientiously and successfully tackled the skills shortages, especially for rural and regional Australia, as the Howard government. I commend in particular the Regional Skilled Migration Scheme and the recent changes which have allowed offshore students to stay in Australia, under certain careful criteria, if they have employment in a rural area. I commend the Howard government for understanding that we need skilled migrants to come into this country and work in rural and regional Australia.

What I am equally concerned about is the unskilled labour category, comprising those who are prepared to do manual work, particularly the seasonal manual work that is absolutely essential for our horticulture industry, in which I include vegetables, nursery production, fruit and nuts and some viticulture. Some vines are able to be machine picked. In 2000, the gross value of production of horticulture was $5.5 billion, with a farm gate value of $4.7 billion. This production is dependent on access to labour in the form of pickers, pruners, planters and people who are prepared to work in packing sheds. This is seasonal work. Unfortunately farm enterprises typically cannot afford, or do not have the work, to offer jobs for a whole season. There is often a peak period in which they require a certain number of pickersâin the case of the Goulburn Valley, some 8,000 to 10,000 pickers and, in the following months, about half that number to do pruning. Without that labour, quite simply our horticultural industries cannot expand. They cannot take advantage of the growing access to the fresh fruit and vegetable, nut and honey markets that we have worked hard to develop access to.

We have a serious issue of illegal workers in the harvest areas. As we speak, a number of raids are going on in my electorate of Murray and in the neighbouring electorate of Mallee. Just two days ago some 40 or so illegal workers were picked up on some vegetable farms. Those workers came from Cambodia, Thailand and other near neighbours in Asia. They were cutting and harvesting vegetablesâa high-value crop for domestic and export markets. Those farmers, those property owners, now have no labour. Those crops will need to be ploughed in. They cannot obtain additional or alternative labour. Of course they were not aware that those people were illegal. Some of them had been employed for over four years and they had been obtained through a contract labour hire service. It was the understanding of the farmers that those workers had the right to work in Australia. Sadly, it turns out they did not. Of course the owners of those properties do not support illegal work in Australia. On the other hand, they are faced with this extraordinary dilemma. How do they produce magnificent product in regions where the irrigation infrastructure has been built at public expense over a hundred years, where they have the soils, the climate and the clean green image? All is there for them to prosper but they cannot obtain the labour.

A number of countries, particularly many of our competitors in agricultural production, have overcome this problem with visas and market labour programs that bring in seasonal workers. Most countries have temporary worker programs for both high- and low-skilled workers. Some have separate programs for IT professionals, health-care workers, managers and executives, but there are special programs for farm workersâand also for maids and caregivers in some countries. There is always a concern in Australia that an overseas worker might literally `disappear' into the economy after their visa expires, because we are such a multiracial, multicultural society and we have such a huge continent. Obviously compliance issues are very difficult in Australia because we are such an open country in terms of movement. But other countries have come up with some quite careful and workable solutionsâobviously negotiated with the home country and with the workers themselves. The negotiations have included such conditions as withholding part of their paymentsâthis is of course with the workers' permissionâuntil they are literally on their way back to their home country; not having families arrive with the workers but just having individuals come so that there is a greater incentive for them to return; and compliance with a temporary work visa creating the opportunity to return year after year, for perhaps six or nine months of the year, to work as a seasonal worker.

While I am talking about horticultureâfruit growing, vegetable growing, nuts, harvesting and table grapesâthe same issues also affect Australia's hospitality industry, where there is a chronic shortage of workers, and our rag trade. But let me focus at the moment on the issue that most significantly affects my electorate, which is the access to labour for horticulture. I want to mention a couple of programs used by other countries. Canada, for example, has the Commonwealth Caribbean and Mexican Agricultural Seasonal Workers Program, or ASWP. It has allowed Canadian farmers to import foreign workers for up to eight months a year from the Caribbean since 1966 and from Mexico since 1974. About 80 per cent of these ASWP migrants are employed in fruit, vegetable and tobacco farms in Ontario. Their average stay in Canada is four months.

Mexicans are recruited and employed under the terms of a government-to-government memorandum of understanding that makes the Mexican Ministry of Labor responsible for recruiting workers and negotiating their wages with Human Resources Development Canada, a government agency. The admissions process begins with farm employers applying to local Human Resources centres for certification to employ the foreign workers, at least eight weeks before they are needed. There is, of course, always a preference for Canadian workers under the Canadians First policy, but if there is evidence that no Canadian nationals are available then farmers may access these foreign workers. They must pay them an agreed piece rate or the prevailing wage.

There can be absolutely no intention of exploiting labour from countries where salaries or piece work payments may be substantially lower than in the Australian economy. Their housing, their access to health services and every other condition of their work must be equivalent to Australian working standards. There must be no possibility of exploitation of these people. In the Canadian experience, migrants are given entry papers in their countries of origin, and a special Foreign Agricultural Resource Management Services agency affiliate arranges to transport these workers to Canada and to the employer who has applied for them. Farmers advance the cost of transportation from Mexico to Canada and deduct four per cent of workers' wages to cover the transport costs. Farmers also deduct payroll taxes and insurance costs from their workers' pay, and there is a 14-day probation period after their arrival.

Other countries have similar sorts of programs. Swiss programs, for example, are long established, and indeed that country totally depends on foreign workers. In December 2001, foreigners in the Swiss work force represented 25 per cent of all workers. Of those, 20 per cent had renewable one-year work permits and 18 per cent were border commuters. Switzerland's agriculture based industries could not continue without these workers, but there are certain conditions of compliance associated with their programs.

With regard to the French programs, the numbers of seasonal foreign workers admitted for employment in agriculture rise and fall. In 1972 a peak of 138,000 seasonal foreign workers were admitted into France. Two-thirds came from Spain; two-thirds were employed to do the grape harvest. The admission process began with French farmers having their need for foreign workers certified by local labour officers. Spanish workers were then requested by name by French employers, and many arrived by train in work crews that could shift from employer to employer. French employers paid for worker transportation and provided housing. It has been noted that the recruitment of seasonal foreign workers for agriculture was not halted with the recruitment of foreign workers who came in for other purposes. There has been a shrinking and expanding of the need for workers in France for agriculture, but in the late 1990s almost 11,000 seasonal foreign workers were admitted. In fact, in 2001, there were 11,000 seasonal workers for agriculture; half came from Morocco and 43 per cent came from Poland.

I want to emphasise the success of programs in other countries. Many of us are also aware of the longstanding guest worker programs in countries such as the United States, in particularâand I have already mentioned Canada. They have a very well-known program where they try very hard to ensure the rights of workers and to ensure that those who come through the borders illegally are not exploited but, rather, go through a legal process. That gives the farmers access to seasonal work, which means that the Californian industries have survived and thrived, many of them in competition with Australia's agribusiness.

Israel also has a longstanding worker program, where teams of workers arrive from the Middle East and other neighbouring countries for only, on some occasions, four months of work on their kibbutzim to meet the seasonal peaks of their horticultural demand. The workers return with apparently very little loss in terms of overstaying. Israel's horticultural industry's prosperity is linked to their access to this labour.

I have been speaking to our Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. She is very aware of this problem and is concerned about making sure that we have immigration programs in Australia that do not lead to overstaying or exploitation. We, of course, have sex industry problems in Australia, where illegal workers are brought into this country. Women are very significantly exploited when this happens, but we have introduced sex slavery legislation into this House to ensure that we can properly prosecute those who use illegal workers in our country in the sex industry.

These are very serious issues associated with guest workers that I know our government is keen to address and will address. I want to make the point, however, that enforcing compliance, with the so-called raids that are undertaken in horticulture to find illegal workers, is costly. Perhaps the cost is more than that of administering a scheme of introduced seasonal workers where the rules are very carefully thought through. If we take the very best of the systems that have been introduced overseas, we can then solve a number of problems. We can have our multibillion dollar horticultural industry thrive and our export industries grow. We can remove the incentive for illegal overstays, and we can perhaps build on our relationships with our near neighbours, particularly in Asian countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines and Malaysia, who have numbers of workers only too willing to come to Australia for short terms. We can build relationships further, with close connections between certain districts and regions in those countries and our horticultural regions in Australia. The need is very great, and I know we will find a solution. I look forward to working with the minister in developing a solution to this problem. I want to say that the John Howard government is one of the first to be serious about regional employment issues, and I commend the skilled migration programs that are bringing us workers for the first time in decades. But the seasonal worker program now needs serious attention.
Dr SOUTHCOTT (Boothby) (10.35 a.m.)âI move:

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to have this opportunity to add my voice to those in this and the other place who have already expressed their deep shock and sadness at the events of 26 December 2004. When the death toll was estimated in the thousands, I was shocked by the magnitude of the disaster. As the number of victims increased with every hour, day and news bulletin, my shock, and that of others, turned to utter disbelief. I fear that the final human cost of this disaster will never be truly known. Having spent 2Â½ years in Bangkok during my time with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade some years ago, I have a very deep affection and respect for the people of Thailand. There is no way to describe the sadness I feel at the thought of such a warm people, so generous in nature and rich in culture, having such a tragedy inflicted upon them. Sadly, they were not the only country so afflicted.

speech.para: Sections of the Australian and international communities have expressed in a variety of ways their support for those affected. Very soon after 26 December, I had the opportunity and the privilege here in my electorate of Canberra to attend interfaith services at the Royal Thai Embassy; St Christopher's Catholic Church, in Manuka; the City Uniting Church; the Indonesian Embassy; and the Mandir Society, in Mawson. I was immensely impressed by the level of attendance, given that one of those services was held on the morning of 1 January, New Year's Day, at a time when everybody was very much in holiday mode. Yet, when these services came along and offered an opportunity for people to gather, it became very evident that people really needed to do that. For my own part I appreciated very much the efforts behind each of those services that I attended. I understood very clearly, from my own personal feelings, the importance of gathering. Sitting at home and watching the news was one thing, but I cannot overstate how important it was to have the opportunity to get together with other people, some of whom were personally affected through family connections in some of the countries affected.
