The tsunami did not respect national borders, ethnic, cultural or political differences. The water claimed the lives of people from many different religions, backgrounds and nationalities. The response to this catastrophe has been that the geographic and cultural barriers disregarded by the tsunami are also being disregarded by those seeking to support and to help repair the damage. As each country affected by the rising water began to assess the enormous task of rebuilding, in this country alone churches, synagogues, mosques, scout groups, schools, pubs, workplaces, sporting groups, neighbourhoodsâevery level of our societyâbegan fundraising. I know all members of this House will join me in saying that we were both amazed and pleased by the level of generosity shown by Canberra residents and the generosity that has been mirrored around the country.

It is interesting to note that money was collected from such huge events as WaveAid right down to children collecting in their neighbourhood streets. It was a response we have never needed to see before, but it warms the heart to know that it happened. I would like to express my support, as others in this place have already, for the measures taken by the Australian government in response to the events of 26 December. I would also like to thank the government departments and individuals whose reaction to this crisis can make us all so proud.

Many Canberra residents returned early from their hard-earned leave as government departments reacted to the disaster. Being the national capital, Canberra is also home to the majority of Commonwealth public servants in this country. It is fair to say, and I do not think anybody will mind me reflecting in this way, that it can sometimes be fashionable to knock public servantsâand I do not mean just politicians; I mean anybody around the country. It is quite often a bit of sport. However, the reaction of those people working in all areas of the Public Service over that period might put that kind of practice to bed for ever. There has never been a better demonstration of absolute dedication to a job or to providing a service than was seen at all levels of the public service sector following this terrible disaster.

Acting to help seems to have been an automatic reaction to the crisis rather than a conscious decision. These people simply saw what was required and went to work to respond. In the days following 26 December, the people at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade worked tirelessly to provide information to Australians seeking news of loved ones in the affected regions. To put things into perspective, I am informed that shortly after the Bali bombing the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade received around 35,000 calls. By 10 January this year, that same call centre had received over 82,000 calls, an enormous level of response and work required.

Some of the first help to get to Thailand came from the ACT hospital trauma section. Three of our medical trauma specialists were up there very quickly assisting with triage to help assist and move people as quickly as they could in those important first few days following the effect that was felt in southern Thailand. RAAF personnel were among the first Australians sent to Indonesia to help, and Australian Defence Force personnel remain in some of the worst affected areas providing, medical, logistical and other relief services. They will be there for some time. The AFP was also very involved and remains so. While so many Australians were justifiably attempting to return home as quickly as possible, the Australian armed services were preparing to send people just as quickly into Banda Aceh. I understand that some forensics teams that lent their services to the Indonesian government in the wake of the Bali bombing are now conducting DNA tests to identify, as much as possible, the unnamed victims of the tsunami. They are performing a truly unenviable task, and I believe no words expressed here can adequately describe the courage or the quality of character displayed by those people.

A Canberra residentâin fact, a constituent of mineâPercy Samara-Wickrama is a retired engineer originally from Galle in Sri Lanka. Percy has contributed to aid projects in Bosnia and Kosovo with an aid organisation known as RedRâRegistered Engineers for Disaster Relief. Percy returned to Sri Lanka, to Galle, very soon after the disaster to assist in the rebuilding of two villages as part of a project called Operation Hope. One hundred per cent of funds donated to Operation Hope will go towards rebuilding those villages with a view to sustaining their long-term recovery. All administration costs are being met by Percy's family, such is his determination to help the area he was born in. I know from discussions that my officers had with Percy's son that the effort to set up Operation Hope has been enormous, and I commend very strongly the work that Percy and his family have done in that personal way to dedicate themselves to something they truly believe in.

I know that the ACT community, both through the business and professional community and just folk living out there in the electorate, are all getting behind Operation Hope and doing what they can. They can actually see a direct connection between their efforts to support this particular enterprise and the actual, physical rebuilding of a couple of villages within Percy's family's original area in Sri Lanka. I know that even local WIN TV have been following the progress of this very closely, and I commend that very strongly. This is just one example. There are so many other examples around the country where people are doing similar things.

If I or anyone else in this place were to try to name every organisation, government department or individual who deserved specific praise, I am sure we would all be here far longer than any of us have time allowed for any one speech on this issue. While the challenge of rebuilding may well be the greatest ever presented by a natural disaster on this planet, companies, charities and ordinary citizens have proved and are proving that we can and will meet this challenge. I again want to make reference to the level of response that we are seeing through all of our communities. Every one of the members and senators within this place could stand up and cite examples from their own communities where there have been wonderful responses. The type that I think epitomises it most for me has been not necessarily from here but just the photos in the papers of children setting up lemonade stalls in streets. At any level that people can, they want to be involved and they need to be involved. We can be very proud, as Australians, of seeing the sort of human response that is coming from our Australian community to this terrible disaster.

I would like once more to extend my condolences to the nations affected by this disaster. All of those nations have been named in the parliament, and I do not need to go through those again. Suffice it to say that there are far too many, and the tragic outcome is still being measured in many of those countries. I want to record, as well, on behalf of my electorate, my gratitude to our armed forces, our charities and the people of my community and of Australia generally for their collective response to this tragedy.

In conclusion, whilst the response has been, as I have said, so warm-hearted, the difficulty now, I think, will be to continue that response into the months and the years to come. The dimension of this disaster is such that things are not going to be rebuilt overnight. Continuing connection to these communities around the Indian Ocean rim is going to be needed for some years to come. I think we all are going to need to do what we can to support the ongoing rebuilding and the ongoing call for help in re-establishing lives, communities, buildings, business enterprises and community and social networks. All of those things are going to take time. I have every confidence that the Australian community will be in a position to continue that connection with these people for the years to come, because that is what is going to be required.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the motion moved by the Prime Minister and endorse the comments of the previous speakers. Many speakers have rightly lauded the excellent work of the Australian Defence Force medical and engineering teams who have worked tirelessly to bring about real change in the areas devastated by the Boxing Day tsunami. Today, however, I wish to particularly highlight the significant contribution by the men and women of the Australian Army Aviation Corps and the Royal Australian Air Force Air Lift Group. These people deploy and operate with little publicity, but they are often the main source of mobility in areas where the ADF have served Australia, such as the drought relief in Papua New Guinea, operations in Bougainville, the Solomon Islands, Iraq, East Timor and, most recently, Banda Aceh.

speech.para: Members of 36 and 37 Squadron of the Air Lift Group have flown Hercules aircraft on a continual basis to deliver aid and to evacuate people whose lives have been devastated by the tsunami. Over 1,100 tonnes of aid have been sent from Australia to Sumatra, much of it carried by the aircraft of the Air Lift Group. Elements of the 16th Brigade Army Aviation were some of the first ADF assets deployed to Sumatra. Within days of the tsunami, 47 members of A Squadron, Fifth Aviation Regiment, had returned from leave and been deployed with four Iroquois helicopters to commence operations from Banda Aceh airport.

Members of 173 Surveillance Squadron had deployed a Super King Air aircraft to operate from Medan. To date, these Army aviators have carried over 100,000 kilograms of food, water and medical supplies as well as carrying out numerous life-saving medical evacuation flights. I should also mention the actions of Major James Brown, the A Squadron Detachment Commander, who was one of the first people on the scene when a U.S. Navy Seahawk helicopter crashed. In his actions rescuing the crew from the wreckage, he sustained injuries which required his repatriation to Australia. I wish him a full and speedy recovery.

In acknowledging and thanking the members of the Army Aviation Corps and the Air Lift Group, and the maintenance engineers who support them, I wish also to thank their families. The long period of concurrent deployments around the world of ADF aviation assets has put a huge strain on familiesâoften young familiesâwho remain at home. They cope with a number of pressures and uncertainties unique to having a family member deployed on operations, as well as the normal aspects of family life. I wish to take this opportunity to place on record my thanks to them for their sacrifice which allows the ADF to, yet again, play a significant part in contributing to our region and making all Australians proud.

talk.start.para: âFirst of all, I would like to congratulate the Prime Minister on putting this motion before the chamber. I am sure that every single member of the House would support this motion. Certainly for my own part I can say that I endorse every jot and every particle of this motion, as I also endorsed every action that the Prime Minister and the government took in the wake of the tsunami of 26 December. The action was timely, appropriate and necessary in the face of a disaster that was then not seen to be as great as it now has been revealed to be in the fullness of time. Almost 300,000 people have had their lives destroyed and their communities devastated. The timeliness of the response and its appropriateness is what any government should have deliveredâcoalition or Labor. So I congratulate the Prime Minister. I also congratulate the parliamentary secretary, the member for Dunkley, Bruce Billson, who carried most of the government's practical response during the immediate aftermath of the tsunami. In doing so, I underline the fact that this is a bipartisan response to an absolutely overwhelming natural disaster.

speech.para: There are particulars within this motion that I will come back to. I simply want to look in the first instance at point (1) which says:
That the House:

(1) extends to all Australians who suffered personal losses during the tragic 26 December Indian Ocean tsunami disaster its profound sympathy in their bereavement and wishes a speedy recovery to the injured ...

Luckily, in this disaster the level of loss of life for Australians was comparatively small when you look at the other countries affected. Sweden of course had so many thousands of its people who had their lives simply ripped away from them because they went to one destination in Thailand. Germans suffered tooânot in equal measure, but still a large number of people lost their lives. Given Australians' propensity to travel to South-East Asiaâand, indeed, to Thailand, one of the affected countriesâand to spend their holiday periods there, we were lucky that more were not lost. I have been to Phuket with my wife. I stayed at the Sheraton resort which was devastated by this tsunami. I have stood on the beach. I swam in the water. I have been in the position of those people who, almost in the twinkling of an eye, had their lives completely turned around. It is instructive in a way to step back and think about our situation and the situation of others in current circumstances, and consider how things were different before modern communications were operating in terms of the localised responses to such things.

A little while I ago stood on a headland at Balmoral Beach, out on a rocky area near the end, just past the children's pool, and I looked out towards the Heads and back to the escarpment at Balmoral. I was thinking about the deep ocean trench between Australia and New Zealand and the fact that the eruption of an earthquake within that trench could cause a tsunami to come onto Australian beaches, and that I could be in the situation that all those hundreds of thousands of people wereâhere one minute, gone the next. The predictability of this is extremely low unless you have proper and effective monitoring systems, as there are in the Pacific. So at least we have those things in place and have had for a long period.

It is quite apparent that one of the major problems in the regions affectedâin Banda Aceh in Indonesia, in Thailand and less so for those countries that were further away and, indeed, the ones that we did not hear about much at allâwas the lack of an early warning. I had contemplated going on a holiday in Mauritius during that period. Mauritius was slightly affected but had plenty of warning because of what was apparent with regard to what happened in Banda Aceh and Thailand. It also hit the Seychelles, another Indian Ocean holiday place primarily used by people from France and other parts of Europe, and it hit the African coast as well. The result and impact there were much less, not because of the intensity of the waves but because of the early warning.

For all those Australians who lost their lives because there was not an early warning system in place, I join with all of those others from the opposition and from the government side who have said that there should be a priority placed on creating the same type of early warning system in the Indian Ocean as we have had in the Pacific Ocean for many years. We have friends who have relatives living in Thailand. Indeed, they run a business on the beach. It just so happened that on that morning, because they were caught up, they were not down on the beach running the business. They had to get children from school and they were further into the hinterland. By luck, their lives were saved. But, for all of those people who were doing the very normal thing of enjoying their holidays, when something like this emerges and sweeps them away so rapidly it is really hard to comprehend the immensity of it. I really could not get a handle on the strength of the waves or their impact until I looked at the footage. Certain camera angles can show it to you, and it was only a couple of weeks down the track that some of the home footage shot by people who were there gave a better indication of what happened in particular places.

One of the things that stands out is that the world now is very different to what it was previously. In the past, going back to prehistoric times, there were of course always natural disasters, some of which wiped out hundreds of thousands of people. But when they happened two key things were different from the situation today. The first is that in the hunter-gatherer period people were effectively in small bands. The density of the population worldwide was much less. It was not until the agricultural revolution and the creation of settled communities that we had an increasing density of population and an increasing number of people in the population who could be affected locally in one place. So in prehistoric times there were fewer people to be so affected and, because they existed in scattered bands and moved through the environment in a way that did not have as much impact as settled communities, there was less chance of being caught up in these kinds of disasters. More importantly, no-one knew what happened to individual groups of people because they were isolated from their fellows.

It is only in the period of modern civilisations, not just civilisations post the agricultural revolution but those with speedy communications, that you can get a handle on what happens in fundamental natural disasters. You only need to go back 100 years or more and the reality was that people did not hear about major natural disasters, whether it was the eruption of Vesuvius or Mount Etna or the great disaster caused by Krakatoa, until either the physical evidence was present before themâand that took some time, for instance, in regard to Krakatoaâor the associated tsunamis had happened as a result of those earthquake events in the Indian Ocean or the Pacific. There was a great deal of lag time before people found out about them. As for trying to get help and support, there was not the modern response that there has been to this tsunami.

Because of modern communications, we know about, can feel about and have empathy for those people who lost their lives or had their places destroyed. As the previous speaker indicated, with their modern transport systems, the Australian defence forces were able to take aid and assistanceâmedical aid, food and waterâto people desperately in need of it. What the government did, supported by the opposition in a nonpartisan way, in moving as swiftly as possible to go to the aid of those people most in need of our help, was a tremendous achievement. It was an achievement that goes to the core of an Australian responseâthe fact that people wholeheartedly and rapidly went to the assistance of others and did so in a period when normally the country would be on holiday.

Associated with that was a very clear understanding, not only of the logistical problems that there would be in Banda Aceh, for instance, but also of the fact that targeted assistance was necessary in those places most seriously affected by the tsunami because they were the most proximate. The province of Banda Aceh suffered directly because it was closest to the undersea earthquake and had less warning time than anywhere else. Given the nature of the topography, it had a very wide area that was completely devastated, to the point where there is virtually nothing left standing. I think it is right and appropriate that Australian aid has been primarily focused there.

We also know that there has been a substantial effort in Sri Lanka, and there has been some effort as well in relation to Thailand. In fact, the Thai government have indicated that the thing we could do to help the most would be to encourage people to go on holiday to those areas againâto take up the normal response that one would see. The Thai government have the ability to rebuild their infrastructure and to handle their own demands and needs in this area themselves. But they want people to come back. They want to re-establish a sense of the necessity to support these tourist destinations by people travelling to them.

That will not happen easily unless there is a sense of sureness on the part of those people who would travel thereâthat is, a sense that the places are rebuilt, that they are safer in terms of the general safety of water, food and so on and that they have readily available services. For an event like this, coming with no signal, no clarion call and no time for people to respond, an early warning system must be built. In that way, people can be sure, if they are going to those places to relax and rebuild themselves in a holiday mode, that they will not have the idea that this could happen to them. The lives of all those hundreds of thousands of innocent people who were killed in this disaster should not have been lost only for this to happen again in the same way. It is absolutely critical to all of those peopleânot only in holiday areas but in areas like Banda Aceh, with people leading very normal lives, going about their activitiesâthat they are able to rebuild in the hills or more mountainous areas or, indeed, on the plain again. But it is also critical that they have some protection through the use of available technologies as well as the use of our intelligence and abilities to predict these incidents and their effects better than we can.

Part of the human aspect of this is that although the early warning system for the underground earthquake registered in Australia, the results were misinterpreted. First, they thought that it was not as great as it was. Second, they did not think there would be a tsunami effect because, when you look at the gradings for seismic activity, there is an exponential factor with respect to their gravity. For example, a size seven is entirely different from a size 7Â½ or a size eightâor in this case, one going on for a size nine. It is always probable in human affairs that, even with the best attention to such things, people will get them wrong. This experience has been so grave and so disastrous for the entire region and those communities involved that it is imperative that we get it right.

It is also imperative that we continue to do as we have done, and that is to build and strengthen the relationship between Australia and Indonesia so that Indonesians of goodwill will understand, as they have in the past, that the present involvement of Australia and its future involvement will be to build with them to allow them to renovate, reinvigorate and rejuvenate their people and their circumstances, particularly in Banda Aceh, so that as good neighbours and good citizens of the world we can renew what was destroyed and open up for the survivors a life that is open, free and not dominated by the fear of this happening again.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
Mr HUNT
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âIn considering and remembering the tragedy of Boxing Day, the tsunami and the human loss, I recall the words of John Donne from 400 years ago. John Donne was an English cleric, author and poet. He wrote:

quote.para: No man is an island, entire of himself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main. If a clod be washed away by the sea, Europe is the less, as well as if a promontory were ... any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in mankind, and therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.

speech.para: Those words, 400 years old, are as relevant todayâand sadly perhaps more relevant than they were thenâas one could imagine. On Boxing Day we saw that, and we saw a response which echoed the words as well, which was perhaps the bright light in an otherwise tragic episode in human history. In speaking to this motion of condolence to the tsunami victims I want to refer to three things: I want to talk briefly about the tragedy, and then about the Australian response and finally, in my role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, I want to refer to the steps forward, as I have carriage in my area of the Bureau of Meteorology, which has a significant role in warning people about the possible arrival and consequences of natural disasters.

The tragedy, as we are all aware, has probably taken 300,000 lives, and that figure may continue to grow. That figure of 300,000 was most profoundly registered in the province of Banda Aceh in Indonesia, which suffered an almost instantaneous double of earthquake and tsunami. Nothing could have been done then or now, and probably not within the next 500 years, to warn people of that kind of arrival. The process from earthquake to tsunami was almost instantaneousâwithin a period of 20 minutes. However, there is always a response. As we radiate out from the epicentre through the Indian Ocean region we see that there was a time lapse. We will be able to deal with and improve our warning systems on that front. However, the tragedy that affected Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Sri Lanka in large part, India and to a lesser extent Burma, the Maldives and even as far away as the Seychelles and the African coast, reminds us of who we are and what we have lost. It brings us together in a way that was not sought, but which is in some way uplifting.

This brings me to the second point, which is about the response. It has shown us the capacity we have as individuals, as countries, as citizens and as communities to respond in times of crisis. Sure, there was an Australian government responseâwhich was right, appropriate, just and generousâbut that is not the real focus. The real focus is what occurred in every one of our electorates. In every electorate around Australia, in every community, there was an outpouring of generosity and grief for those whom we may have not known and will never know. There was an emotional response and a practical response.

I want to acknowledge some of the practical responses within my own electorate of Flinders. Firstly, the Phillip Island Advertiser staff, led by the editor, Anne Oswin, worked with a series of community groups such as Rotary to create a table, which they then covered with $2 coins in the main street. That table was filled multiple times. Over the course of January it generated approximately $50,000 and led to that small community contributing a total of $100,000 to the international Red Cross. It was one little community, one small island and one simple activity. I commend Anne Oswin and the staff of the Advertiser, the volunteers from Rotary and all the other volunteer groups on the island. That is one example of local generosity that was replicated throughout Australia. That generosity was replicated through corporate giving and at the national level.

Whilst the government has given resources, what I think is extraordinary at the national level is the role that Australia's defence personnel have played. They have given their time, they have been drawn away from their families and they have been on the front line. The defence and medical personnel, whether it is in Banda Aceh or in other parts of the region, have played an extraordinary role. I thank them, I commend them and I acknowledge their work.

I also want to look at the steps forward. The outpouring of compassion and the response has been quick, clear and practical, and it has been uniform across the country. But the real question at this moment in history, at the beginning of the 21st century, is: what are our options for trying to avoid these sorts of disasters happening again? In Banda Aceh, nothing could be done to deal with an immediate crisis and natural disaster of this magnitude. When there is an earthquake and immediate tsunami, there will be a human tragedy. Let us not pretend that we can avoid that at this stage in our history. We simply do not have the capacity to predict an earthquake accurately to the day or the hour. We talk in decades and centuries in terms of probability.

But there are perhaps three critical steps that we can take moving forwards, which deal not just with tsunami warning systems but with the whole notion of disaster warning systems. They proceed along three fronts. The first element in any early warning system is monitoring. This is perhaps the easiest part to get right. There is a Pacific tsunami warning system based in Hawaii, but there has been no such similar thing within the Indian Ocean region. The reasons are: firstly, history and the lack of apparent needâhuman history is seen in the present century over decades, not over eons; and secondly, because it is a developing region and it has not been seen as a priority. We now know, with the benefit of hindsight, that it must be a priorityâthat we have to view our responsibilities to future generations in terms of centuries and eons, not just in terms of immediate needs. The once in a century or once in 500 year natural disaster could be now or it could be at any other time within that frame.

It is possible to provide the technological warning. That exists within the Pacific system. Australia is playing a role in coordinating through the International Oceanographic Commission that set of skills and is working towards the capabilities and the technological options within the Indian Ocean region. A system will be set up. We have already been involved through meetings in Kobe on the World Conference on Disaster Reduction and in Phuket. We will be involved in other meetings in establishing that Indian Ocean regional tsunami warning system but also more broadly in the entire disaster system.

The second element of any warning system, other than the technological capability, is educationâthat is, what to do in the event of an active, live warning. We have within Australia two very good models of thatâbushfire and cyclone events. They need to be advanced, but in terms of public education these models can be exported and replicated throughout the Indian Ocean region. We have already committed to do that. There is a lot more to do, but we will be doing that sort of public education. We will be working within each individual country to try to encourage the development of such systems.

The third and most difficult part of any warning system is about what you might call the last mileâhow you get the technology or the ability to communicate with people in rural villages in a short time frame over the last mile. We do have, through mobile technologyâand I am glad that the member for Wentworth is here; he is one of the pioneers within Australia and one of the most knowledgeable people in this fieldâthe capacity to push messages out to every mobile device and every fixed line device over the last mile through automated systems. Only this morning, I was exploring with a number of people how we can do that throughout the Indian Ocean region and also within Australia. That is something which we have not embraced yet and which we must embrace. It is the next generation of wholesale warning. But these are rural villages. These are developing parts of the world, so we also need to work on general broadcast facilities within these villages. Again, that was something we were looking at this morning.

There is a lot more to be done. These systems will not be perfect because, if we face a genuine, immediate natural disaster, there is no warning and no capacity to avoid that which is immediate. But where there is any sort of delay between event and consequence, the capacity to provide warning is something which we can do. We see now that the Indian Ocean region is vulnerable, that this was not something of the fantastic and the imaginary but potential and real. Krakatoa is not something of history; unfortunately, it is something of our present. So that is the future, that is what we have to work towards and that is what we are working towards.

Ultimately, I want to return to where I began: the notion that no man is an island and each man's death diminishes me because I am of mankind. That sentiment is with us. It is something which we forget and something which unfortunately it too often takes a tragedy to resurrect within our thinking and our being. The lesson of the last month is that, as a society, we have within us an extraordinary capacity. If we can in any way on all sides of this chamber do whatever we can to work together to try to encourage that sentiment and to encourage that sense of national unity and common humanity, then we will be doing something of real meaning for future generations. I thank all of those people, most simply signified by the people of Phillip Island, members of the Phillip Island Advertiser and Phillip Island Rotary for their generosity, because they tell us what we can be and they tell us what we should be.

talk.start.para: âToday I rise to speak on this motion in my capacity as shadow minister for health and member for Lalor, but perhaps most importantly as a human being. You would not be a human being unless you felt a strong emotional reaction to the dreadful tragedy that unfolded on our TV screens and on the pages of our newspapers from Boxing Day on. We can all probably identify different moments of that coverage which emotionally affected us. I certainly remember the Australian woman who came back to Australia with her two children but described a moment of indescribable horror when she needed to work out which child she would hold on to and which child she would let goâan almost unimaginable thing for a mother to do that we know in popular culture as Sophie's Choice. Fortunately for her, both of her children survived but in devastation where so many did not.

speech.para: We know that the devastation affected our region broadly: Indonesia, Thailand, Sri Lanka, India, Bangladesh, Burma, the Maldives, East Africa, Kenya, the Seychelles, Somalia, Madagascar, and Tanzania. The tsunami hit across our region and caused an almost unimaginable loss of lifeâabout 290,000 people, with possibly more deaths to be recorded, and 240,000 people in Indonesia alone.

I am sure we are all aware now that the unofficial Australian death toll is 24, with relatives having confirmed six deaths on top of the 18 deaths officially listed by DFAT. We know that grave concerns remain for 10 Australians who were in tsunami affected areas and whose bodies have not been identified or are still subject to formal victim identification processes. As has been remarked by many speakers in this debate, the outpouring of generosity from Australians confronted with this tragedy was hugeâhuge at both the community and the official level. That is something for which Australia can be proud. All of us have stories of seeing people put in amounts of money that were probably almost beyond their capacity to donate at one time to one cause. But so moved were they that Australians were hugely generous in response to this tragedy. The Australian government, with the full support of the opposition, of course, announced a $1 billion program, the Australia-Indonesia partnership for reconstruction and redevelopment. It is a five-year commitment and the single largest aid package in Australia's history. We should be rightly proud of that as a country.

I would particularly like to direct my remarks to the work that was done in the health and medical area as an immediate response to the tsunami. Obviously, with a disaster like this there is not only dealing with the immediate loss of life but also dealing with people who are injured and the loss of critical infrastructureâsuch as that providing fresh waterâand the consequences that has for the prospects of major disease outbreaks. Of course, one of the greatest risks facing the survivors of the tsunami was disease arising from the water or airborne diseases. The lack of fresh water and sanitation meant that outbreaks of communicable diseases such as cholera and typhoid were, rightly, very greatly feared as the next big killer after the devastation of the tsunami itself.

As recently as 4 February this year, the World Health Organisation has reported that there have been no outbreaks of disease in tsunami affected areas. That can be seen to be due to the unprecedented level of assistance from the world and from Australia to prevent that kind of catastrophe happening. Incidents of tetanus, measles and malaria have occurred but these appear to be controlled; the ability to react quickly has been crucial in ensuring their control. Australia has provided aid in the health and medical area to reduce risk. Particularly, we provided a water purification plant, capable of producing up to 480,000 litres of water a day, for distribution to the devastated communities in Banda Aceh. We also sourced and delivered 129,000 20-litre water containers to Banda Aceh to keep the supply of fresh water flowing.

There has been funding provided for a water and sanitation specialist to undertake an assessment and provide support for the provincial administration in addressing the immediate water supply and sanitation needs in Aceh. The World Health Organisation has formulated a mental health response for the people of Banda Aceh. Given the level of devastation in this region, the World Health Organisation is assessing mental health needs, training community leaders and ensuring the Aceh psychiatric hospital is equipped to deal with the longer-term effects of a disaster on this scale. Australia directly provided a 90-bed Australian Defence Force field hospital in Banda Aceh; funding for a team of 24 Australian doctors to provide urgent medical assistance; funding for a health assessment team, including specialists in health sector coordination, psychosocial support, child protection and infectious disease; and pharmaceuticals and medical supplies to Banda Aceh.

We have provided tetanus immunisation to treat and prevent the disease at the request of the World Health Organisation. We have provided medical supplies for the general hospital in Medan for the treatment of tsunami victims airlifted from Banda Aceh. We have provided support for re-establishing a procurement and medical supply distribution network in Banda Aceh and provided vital infrastructure and human resources for that purpose. We have supported the restoration of government mental health services by engaging a psychosocial trauma support specialist to undertake an assessment of the mental hospital and mental health needs more broadly in Banda Aceh. We have provided support for the restoration of government maternal health services by engaging a maternal health specialist, Kerry Ross, to conduct a rapid assessment of maternal health needs, focusing on midwife capacity, in the Aceh province. We have provided support for government engagement in infectious disease surveillance and control, and we have provided support for an infectious disease specialist from the Mentor, a malaria prevention non-government organisation which is now working on the issue of the malaria risk.

All of these things have been provided by Australia with Australian aid efforts. I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate all of those who have been involved in providing these services. Efforts of such enormous dimension require not only people on the ground providing the services but coordination. Huge amounts of work and rapid responses are needed. Hundreds of people, possibly thousands, have been involved in these individual health and medical efforts that I have reported to the House today. Each of those individuals deserves our great congratulation.

Whilst we are very proud of the rapid response, we know that there are ongoing issues that we need to deal with as a result of the tsunami. Some of those are in the health and medical area. As we move from the wave of the tsunami and the devastation it left to the time beyond, one of the deepest concerns is the mental health needs of those who have survived. When people have had their lives destroyed, when they have lost loved ones, when they have perhaps lost all of their family, there is obviously a need for ongoing mental health assistance and support.

The second ongoing challenge for us is to ensure that we look after children's health and wellbeing. In the Banda Aceh camps, where about four million people live, about three per cent, or 120,000, are children younger than five. UNICEF has warned that 12.7 per cent of children surveyed at camps in and around the provincial capital of Banda Aceh suffer malnutrition, which stunts growth, retards mental development and weakens the immune system. UNICEF has warned that conditions could be even worse outside the provincial capital and calls the situation a `critical emergency' requiring immediate intervention. So, as we have responded to the immediate challenge, now the task is to respond to some of these longer term challenges in the areas of children's health and mental health and the physical rebuilding that is required across the region.

Other members have referred to particular contributions that people in their electorates have made to the aid effort. I would like to take the opportunity to do the same. In my local community there was an immediate response to the fundraising effort, as I am sure there was across Australia. The Hudson family of Werribee were holidaying in Phuket at the time of the tsunami. Luckily they all survived. The Hudson family are good mates of mineânotwithstanding the fact that I run into them every election day handing out Liberal how-to-vote cardsâbut I do not take it personally. They are good friends, and it was good to see them all return to Australia safe and well.

The Morris and Freeman families of Werribee, who were holidaying in Phuket, stayed to help with the clean-up. My electorate is home to many members of the Sri Lankan community in Melbourne and obviously they were particularly affected and particularly concerned about the fate of their family members. A Melton resident, Rozanne Short, who is a Sri Lankan community member, helped with fundraising efforts locally, particularly within the Sri Lankan community.

The Point Cook Residents Association have been involved in a pattern of providing ongoing assistance. They are going to have a fun run in March, a trivia night in June, a bike-a-thon in October and a Christmas twilight function in December. So they have dedicated their functions across the whole year to fundraising for the tsunami. Local Wyndham residents Justine Colley and Jacquie Cook have coordinated fundraising efforts in the Werribee area. The Hoppers Crossing Cricket Club had a special match against the Sri Lankan community on Australia Day. St Andrews Primary School sold pancakes on Pancake Tuesday, and the proceeds of that are going to tsunami victims. So the efforts across my community continue, and I am sure that they are going to continue across this year and hopefully beyond, because that is what is going to be required to ensure that we help rebuild our neighbours from this disaster.

Whilst I am on my feet can I take the opportunity to also pass on my condolences to those who were affected by the South Australian bushfires. As members of this House might know, whilst I am a proud Victorian now, representing a Victorian seat, I grew up in South Australia. My parents and sister livedâit was not our family homeâfor a lot of their lives in the hills area. When you have got family members who live in those parts of Adelaide you always worry about bushfires. I was particularly concerned about family members when we faced the horror of Ash Wednesday all those years ago. Knowing what it is like to live with that kind of apprehension, I did feel a particular emotional call when we saw the devastation that flowed from the bushfires on the Eyre Peninsula, killing nine people and causing about $50 million worth of damage. So I take the opportunity to record my condolences to the surviving family members of people who lost their lives, and also to those who have been affected economically and in other ways by what was a very big bushfire disaster, even by Australian standardsâand we are a nation that knows about big bushfire disasters almost more than any other nation on earth.

talk.start.para: âOn 16 January after the terrible disaster of Boxing Day, there was a ceremony at North Bondi Surf Club at Bondi Beach. It was held in the ocean. A group of board-riders paddled out, formed a circle and cast a wreath into the ocean. It was a very poignant ceremony because of course nobody better understands than lifesavers the way in which the ocean not only entices us as a place to play and to sport ourselves in the sun but also is a very dangerous place. I think that might be why Australians have been so generous and have been filled with so much empathy and compassion for the victims of this disaster. Most of us live on the coast, most of us are very familiar with the sea and most of us recognise that as not only a place for enjoyment and a place for sport but also an element that can turn on you very quickly, be it a wave, a storm, a tide or, in this case, for the people of the Indian Ocean's rim, a gigantic tidal wave.

speech.para: I think we all recognise that these disasters can happen anywhere in the world. `There but for the grace of God go I' is a very important point. In Sydney Harbour there are giant sandstone boulders which were, geologists believe, thrown up over the cliffs, over the foreshore, into Sydney Harbour by giant waves. There is no reason to believe that the next tidal wave could not be hitting our shores or any part of it. It is hard to knowâI am not a geologist, let alone a seismologistâbut one has to ask why the big shift, the earthquake, that occurred off the coast of Tasmania did not itself create a tidal wave. Perhaps the next one will. Our hearts go out as humans. As the member for Flinders just said, we share a common humanity with all of the victims of this earthquake, as we do with the victims of all disasters. It is that humanity that ties us together all around the world, regardless of where we live. But we also share a special bond because of our understanding of the sea and our recognition of what the sea can do.

My wife and I had a very immediate connection with the disaster. A friend of ours who is a constituent of mine, a young woman called Cassie McGann, was staying in a place called Hikkaduwa in Sri Lanka. She rang my wife and left a message on Lucy's mobile phone. Her message went: `I'm sitting on a rooftop in Hikkaduwa. There's been an enormous wave and the waters are rising. Hundreds of people are dying. I don't know what's happened. I borrowed this phone from a French woman, but I think the battery is running out.' Then, indeed, it did run out and we heard no more from her. In the disaster we immediately thought, `How can we find her?' I have to say that the diplomats at the Australian High Commission in Colombo were outstanding. They were not just looking for her, of course; they were looking for all the Australians. But they immediately had teams of their staff going up and down that coast with vehicles, calling out, `Any Aussies? Any Brits? Anyone who speaks English? Are there any foreigners?' They were gathering them all together. Mercifully and miraculously, Cassie was found. She had managed to get to high ground, as, indeed, most Australians did.

It is genuinely a miracle that only a relatively small number of Australians have been killed. We miss every one of them; every one of them is a terrible loss. But, compared with the losses of other countries, including countries whose people in that region were mostly tourists, as ours were, our loss was very small. That underlines the great compassion and generosity of the Australian people. Of all the Western countries, we were probably the least affected in terms of people actually killed, and I suspect that is a function of the time of year. Most Australians who want to go to the beach on Boxing Day have a beach in Australia to go to rather than having to go to Thailand. That is not so if you are a Swede, a Norwegian or a German escaping from the frozen north. Notwithstanding that relatively small loss, tragic though it was, our contribution was greater per capita than any other country. I believe that great compassion and that generosity is because of the empathy we felt as a people who live mostly by the sea and are close to the sea and who do not turn our backs to the sea. As coast-living people we had a great and immediate empathy with that disaster, recognising its nature and recognising how it could have come to affect us.

The leadership shown by the Prime Minister and all his ministers has been outstanding, and I think it is wonderful to see such bipartisan endorsement for the government's leadership in the midst of this crisis. The Prime Minister's leadership was pre-eminent. He is the Prime Minister; it was his initiative to make this appropriately enormous pledge of aid to Indonesia, our nearest neighbour and the country that was worst hit. It is important to bear in mind, as the member for Flinders said, that no matter how good your warning system might have been no warning could have saved the people of Aceh. The earthquake was on their doorstep. Better warning systems are needed and will be put in place, and they certainly could have helped the people in Thailand, India, Sri Lanka and further afield. But if the earthquake is on your doorstep there will never be enough time.

The aid that has been given and the help that has been given by our defence forces and our public servants has been outstanding. I would also like to pay tribute to the outstanding work done by Alexander Downer, our foreign minister. Bruce Billson, the Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs, is, in many respects, an unsung hero. He was everywhere around the region organising aid. I had many discussions with him because many of my constituents who had relevant experience wanted to assist with support.

One organisation in which I am involvedâof which I am a director, in factâis Clean Up Australia, headed by Ian Kiernan. It is the largest grassroots environmental organisation in Australia and famous for organising Clean Up Australia Day, which we are all familiar with. Clean Up Australia, which has a very important commitment to water purification and water recycling, immediately put in place measures which enabled it to deliver a great many small water purification devicesâyou could call them `plants' but they are really more like devicesâto the damaged areas so that people in villages could quickly get clean drinking water again. Obviously, large water purification plants are only suitable in large centres where there is a considerable population, and in Indonesia, in particular, the population is very dispersed.

In my electorate, as in every electorateâI think every member and every senator in this parliament would have had the same experienceâconstituents were immediately generous. People were generous in accordance with their means, and some people gave beyond their means. In my own electorate there were extraordinary events. There was one dinner that my friends Michael and Judy McMahon organised at Catalina, a restaurant in Rose Bay, which raised $277,000 in one nightâan extraordinary amount of generosity. There were similar events at other restaurants and clubs, and there were walks, bikeathons and so forth. There has been a massive outpouring of compassion across Australia and of course across my own electorate.

The question, I suppose, when we talk about compassion and the generosity of our community is: how can we ensure that this continues? A lot of people are asking the question: is this just a one-off event? I visited the international charity Caritas, which is the Catholic Church's international relief agency, the other day and met with its director, Jack de Groote. They have obviously been overwhelmed by the generosity. But there are of course many other disasters in other parts of the world which have not been as spectacular but where the need is just as great. Has this event opened up the compassion in our hearts not just for this occasion but to make us a more generous, more compassionate and more humane nation? I hope it has. I believe it has. But I think it will be up to all of us to ensure that that spirit of philanthropy, that spirit of giving, continues across the community.

We should of course remember the victims of the South Australian bushfire disaster, who were very much closer to home. Natural disasters occur in many shapes, in many forms and in many different places. None of us are exempt. The victims of that disaster suffered just as the victims of the earthquake in the Indian Ocean did, and they have rightly deserved our compassion, support and sympathy as well.

In terms of the future protection against earthquakes, we cannot proof ourselves against earthquakes. The power of the earth not only exceeds the ability of man to resist it but exceeds the ability of man to comprehend it. One of the important lessons from all of this, I believe, is the need to focus on the ability to respond to disasters quickly. Were it not for the Australian and United States armed forces, the people of Aceh would not have received the aid they received in as timely a fashion as they did. The massive infrastructure that is required to deliver aid to these areas at this stage in this region is largely in the hands of the United States. After the United States, our ability to do that would be second. It is a very important role for the defence forces. It is extraordinary, really, to see that the United Statesâwhose image in parts of Indonesia and the region has perhaps not always been as high as it would like it to have beenâbecause of that massive military presence, was singularly able to give the relief that it did to the people in that region.

We need to think more about the ability to deliver aid. I remember speaking with diplomats in Colombo, on the telephone obviously, after the earthquake. They made the pointâand this was even more the case in Indonesiaâthat there simply was no infrastructure left. The roads had been destroyed. It was extremely hard to get aid into places which had been so damaged other than by ship or by air. By definition, your conventional infrastructure has been destroyed, so you need something else.

In summary, this has been a disaster almost beyond comprehension. However, it has brought out in the people of Australia not just great sympathy and great compassion but great deeds by many Australians in the defence forces and the public service and by our diplomats and our medical teams. Right down to the day-to-day level of ordinary Australians, people have felt the pain of our neighbours in the Indian Ocean, and they have done their best, be it with big cheques from corporations or wealthy individuals down to coins in buckets in shopping centres and in churches. In doing that, we have shown what we have always known but too often forget: that everybody around the world, all of us, are each other's brothers and sisters, and when any of us are hurt or when any of us are subject to a disaster then we all suffer. We relieve that suffering by showing our compassion and our generosity in the way we have done.

talk.start.para: âI felt very strongly that I needed to speak on this motion. As an individual I wanted to express my sincere sympathy for the survivors of this terrible disaster and to pay my respects to those hundreds of thousands of people who have lost their lives. I also want to stand here as the member for Capricornia to express on behalf of my electors, the people of Central Queensland, their sense of loss and connection to this event that has rocked our world. Hopefully this is going to shape our world into the future as we meet the challenges that this disaster has presented to us.

speech.para: I got a sense of how the community was feeling when I attended a service at St Joseph's Cathedral, which is just a couple of blocks away from my house. Rockhampton's Churches Together group organised the remembrance service and put the call out to the community to come together to share our shock, our grief and our sense of solidarity and unity as human beings as we were confronted with the terrible images that were coming through the media, and the stories that people in our local community were connected to more directly from the disaster zone.

We met together at St Joseph's Cathedral, and one of the touches that was suggestedâI believe it was by Bishop Brian Heenan from the Catholic Churchâwas for each person to bring a small tribute; not a wreath or a fancy bouquet that we can just ring up and order from the florist, but for each person or family to bring along a small tribute from their garden, something that meant something to them personally. It was quite moving to watch people from all walks of life from Central Queensland filing down the centre aisle of the cathedral and placing those floral tributes on the altar of the cathedral. Rockhampton is a very tropical place and of course there were hibiscus and frangipani and all the tropical flowers that are bursting out all over Queensland at the moment. More than anything else, that really spelled out to me the connection between the people of Central Queensland and the people in Thailand, Indonesia and Sri Lanka. We linked ourselves to that region through the image of those tropical flowers, because, of course, that is the environment our neighbours in the Indian Ocean and South-East Asia share with us as people of the tropics. That really brought home to me how my community was feeling and the importance of using this opportunity to express, on their behalf, their sympathy and feelings of solidarity with our neighbours who are trying to rebuild their lives after this terrible disaster.

Having said that I felt strongly that I should participate in this debate, I actually found it incredibly difficult to prepare for it because going through the news clippings and the speeches that have been made about this just brought it all back. It made me look again at the pictures of those orphaned children and the people who had lost everything. I also saw the joy that people with nothing material left in their lives felt when they found a loved one who they thought was missing. It really made me forget about being a member of parliament and respond to it as a human being. So, in trying to prepare for this, I really got lost in the enormity of it allânot just the scale of loss and the scale of the disaster but also the scale of the rebuilding effort that is going to be required by the international community as we help our neighbours in the Indian Ocean nations rebuild their countries, lives and communities.

It is one thing for me to relive it by flipping through some news clippings; it is another thing for the people who are actually living through this day by dayâthe people who have lost their homes, families and everything they know. This was really brought home to me when I attended the Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum in Vietnam in the middle of January. Sitting around the table were representatives from Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia who were directly affected by this happening to their countries. The Indonesian delegation made a presentation on the first morning of the meeting. They had a video presentation that was the most graphic thing that I have seen in all the news coverage. This was an absolute fly-on-the-wall documentary, taken in what appeared to me to be real time, of people just sitting outside in Banda Aceh having breakfast in front of cafes, stopping to chat to neighboursâit was normal life happening in front of your eyesâand then all of a sudden there was water flowing down the streets. In the footage that I saw, it was quite innocuousâthere was just this water coming. But then it kept coming, and all of a sudden it was not water anymoreâit was a solid wall of debris sweeping everything in front of it. This idyllic scene of families talking, planning their mornings and eating their breakfast was swept away, both in reality in that location and metaphorically as that happened across a quarter of our world. It was so graphic and profound. The scale of the disaster was demonstrated to me by breaking it down to that very personal snapshot of what was happening in these people's lives as their whole world was swept away.

The point of all that is that, while it is hard for us to relive what happened, we have to keep reliving it, remembering it and understanding what is required to help these people get back on their feet. It was a situation where you could not change the channel; we were watching the video as part of the Indonesian presentation. As hard as it was and as horrific as it was, you could not change the channel. That is what we have to rememberâthe people in Thailand, Indonesia and Sri Lanka cannot change the channel. It is their life, and if it is their life then it is our life too.

The scale of the disaster was enormous but so was the scale of the response from Australia. I am incredibly proud of the $1 billion that the Australian government has provided and the leadership in the aid effort that we have shown as a country. There has also been a quarter of a billion dollars donated by ordinary people and corporations from around Australia. I pay tribute to the people in my electorate for the wonderful response they made. I do not think I have been to a community function since this happened where there has not been a raffle, tickets for a dinner or a street stall raising money and awareness of what is happening in these places, what is required to assist, and the importance of ongoing assistance to ensure that we do not forget what is needed to help these people.

I would also like to pay tribute to those people in my electorate who have gone to work as volunteersâthe doctors, engineers and other aid workers who have gone over to these places to be confronted with incredible hardship and to work in a terribly testing environment. They are basically putting their comfortable lives, in many cases, on hold to help those most in need in our international community.

Although many members have said this, it is worth noting again: the open-heartedness and generosity demonstrated by the Australian people offer a new dawn in our relationship with Indonesia and our other neighbours. As I said, I was at the Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum in Vietnam not long after the tsunami happened, and the sense of unity, the sense that we needed each other as a region and that we had an obligation to each other, was incredibly strong. It was great to be part of the goodwill between all the countries. There was a coming together as human beings and as representatives of our various countries to say, `We want to know what you need and we want to be there to help in the long term.' That is going to set the platform for such a strong relationship going forward not only with Indonesia but with our other near neighbours.

We need to take forward the lessons that come out of this. We have heard much technical detail about the need for an early warning system and the importance of Australia getting on board with that not only for our own safety and security into the future but also to assist the countries that stand to lose the most if a similar event happens in the future. We need to offer our expertise and financial assistance for those early warning systems.

We also need to respect the power of nature. We need to understand our world and the environmental challenges we face. We need to work in partnership with other countries to ensure that we do not put our heads in the sand, that we use this demonstration of how powerful and unstoppable these natural forces can be, and that we respect nature, the environment and the planet we live on. We must make sure we do everything we can to live within our natural boundaries as residents of this planet. That includes things like the Kyoto protocol and understanding the challenges facing the small island-states in our Pacific region and in other parts of the world. When we focus on what has happened in the current disaster, we must also understand the environmental disasters that might occur in the years ahead which could affect the people living on the Pacific islands and in other small island-states around the world. We must help themâand certainly not make things worse for themâand understand that we all have to shoulder our responsibility to other nations and other people around the world.

In my remarks to the APPF, I obviously expressed my condolences and also that sense of solidarity and desire to do everything we can. But I think the most important thing for us as we conclude this debate is to keep remembering, to make sure that we do not change the channel when it gets a bit confronting or go on to the next thing that comes alongâto make sure that we are there for the long haul with our neighbours. As I said to the APPF meeting, right now we have this great sense that we have done our bit, but we have to make sure that next year, the year after and the year after that we can look our neighbours in the eye and know that we have continued to do everything we can to help them as they rebuild their lives. Australia has the capacity to do itâwe have already shown that in the last monthâbut we need to make sure that we continue to do it and continue to build those bridges, both real and metaphorical, with our neighbours. Thank you for the opportunity to participate in the debate on this motion. The bipartisan spirit that has been demonstrated in this debate has been very instructive and shows how we can work together when it really counts.

talk.start.para: âI would like to associate myself with this motion, support it and support the remarks of the speakers who have preceded me. Boxing Day in Australia is normally a day we associate with family, recovering after perhaps overindulging on Christmas Day, having a holiday if we are not involved in essential services, the start of the Sydney Hobart Yacht Race or the start of the Melbourne cricket test. There are always positive associations with Boxing Day. But now, for our lifetimes, we will always remember it as the day that the tsunami struck a number of countries right around the Indian Ocean.

speech.para: It is estimated that almost 300,000 people have lost their lives. In Aceh and in Sri Lanka there are people who have lost 50 or 60 members of their extended families. There are couples who were separatedâincluding, of course, many Australians, and we know about them. There are children who were lost. I remember one story of a woman who was holding two children and let go of the older child. Luckily that child was savedâbut just to hear that as a parent and think about ever having to make that sort of choice!

The tsunami was the result of an earthquake just off the west coast of Aceh. It appears that there is increased activity of the plates just off that coast. There have been a number of tremors in that area in the last four or five years. So, while tsunamis are uncommon in recent history in the Indian Ocean region, we do have these plates, where one has slipped underneath the other one, and it seems that tremors are now fairly common. In recent times, the biggest tsunami in that area was of course the tsunami from the explosion of Krakatoa in the 1880s. I think that led to the deaths of about 30,000 people in Indonesia, but this one has been on a different scale.

Many of these deaths were preventable. The travel times between the epicentre of the earthquake and Sri Lanka and Chennai and so on were quite long. We are not talking minutes; we are talking hours. Many of these deaths were preventable. It is hoped that, just as the Pacific Ocean has a very well-monitored and well-organised tsunami warning system, the Indian Ocean will be able to have something too.

Just as we found after the bombings in Bali, the tsunami struck many areas that Australians are familiar with. Many Australian holidaymakers would be familiar with the west coast of Thailand, especially Phuket island, with Sri Lanka, with the Maldives and with the Seychelles. We have overseas students studying in Australia and past students who have returned to their countries from Sri Lanka, India, Bangladesh, Thailand and Indonesia, including Aceh. A whole group of Acehnese students are studying in my own state at the University of South Australia.

For cricketers there were stadiums where they play test cricket, such as the stadium at Chennai, formerly Madras; and the stadium at Galle, where Shane Warne broke the record for the number of wickets taken in test cricket. There are many Australians with dual citizenship who have emigrated from these countries and who have families there. This was the largest natural disaster in the last 100 years and it affected an unprecedented number of countries. It affected their coastlines and so on, but it also affected an unprecedented number of nations and nationalities because of the Europeans who were holidaying in Sri Lanka and Thailand. These were tourist destinations, so it affected the whole world.

We saw unexpected heroesâthe young Australians in Sri Lanka and Thailand, who had some training as nurses, doctors or whatever, who interrupted their holidays to go and do what they could, without many supplies and so on, to help their fellow human beings. There was a young British girl in India, who was about 10 years old, who had learnt in her class that when the water recedes it means there is going to be a Tsunami. She warned people on her beach when she saw this happening and was able to save the lives of hundreds.

The response to the tsunami I think showed Australia at its best. I was very proud of the response from the Australian government. I was very proud of the response from the Australian public. I was very proud of the response from those who were there who did what they could. Our military personnel are trained to adapt and they are up there now providing food, fresh water, medical supplies and a 90-bed hospital. The HMAS Kanimbla is there with 250 sailors and 150 engineers. In times of tragedy we do find heroes. Peter Cosgrove became known to us through East Timor. The Australian of the Year became known to us as a burns surgeon in Bali. We now have people like Colonel Georgina Whelan, a military surgeon.

We have sent five civilian medical teams. Many of those on the civilian medical teams from South Australia I know wellâI worked and trained with them. Many of those people are enormously experienced. They have been to the Persian Gulf, Somalia, Bougainville, East Timor and so on. I met some of them last weekend and spoke to them about the work they did in cleaning up the hospital in Banda Aceh. They were given an incredibly tough job which involved cleaning up the hospital, removing bodies and so on, but they did it and they did it well. As a result of that, through the public face of Australia in Acehâour military, our civilian medical teams and so onâwe have earned enormous goodwill. We saw the Australian Public Service at its best. There was a really coordinated response right across government.

For the National Day of Mourning and Reflection last January I was able to attend a service at the Somerton Park Baptist Church and later a multifaith service at St Peter's Anglican Cathedral, which was really moving and involved Hindu, Thai, Muslim and Christian representatives. Later this month I will be going to a dinner to raise funds for people in India and Sri Lanka at the Hindu temple in Oaklands Park, in my electorate.

As part of this response we have announced $1 billion to Indonesia over five years. I am very proud that we have announced this. It is very important in the administration of this that we do not lose the goodwill that our volunteers have gained in Indonesia. This money will attract all sorts of carpetbaggers and it is really important that we attract people who are working with goodwill and working to advance the way in which Australia is seen in this area. We have had something like 6,000 medical personnel register to volunteer in a tsunami area, and I think that is great. But I am concerned that we may see, with this, people who may lose us some of the goodwill that we have.

I would like to conclude by paying tribute to a constituent of mine who was visiting Sri Lanka when the tsunami struck. He was Sujeewa Kamalasuriya, a 39-year-old Adelaide businessman. He was originally from Sri Lanka and he moved to Australia in 1990. He lived in my electorate of Boothby in Melrose Park, and he became an Australian citizen about five years ago. He ran an Adelaide cleaning business. He was a keen cricketerâhe represented Sri Lanka at the under-19 level and he played with the Adelaide High Old Scholars. He was snorkelling off Unawatuna Beach, south of Colombo, when the tsunami struck. His business partner, Sarah Roberts, was rescued but he unfortunately drowned. His body was later recovered and there was a funeral held in Adelaide in January. I would like to again give my condolences to all those who lost friends or family in the tsunami, especially to the friends and family of my constituent Sujeewa Kamalasuriya.

talk.start.para: âI thank the House for the opportunity in this place to recognise the enormous loss of life in South-East Asia and to come together as a parliament in support of the devastated communities across the region. Like the rest of the nation I watched with horror the events as they unfolded on Boxing Day. As the number of dead and missing grew each hour and the first images of what had happened and the devastation left behind began to appear on our television screens, the enormity of the tragedy sank in. Who could believe that water could do such damage in such a short time?

speech.para: People who have been to the region cannot find the words to describe the enormity of what they have seen. Traumatised survivors struggle to regain some normality in communities that have literally lost well over half of their populations. The response of the Australian community has been enormous. We can be an open-hearted, generous community, and our prompt response to the tsunami has shown that we are prepared to dig deep for disaster victims. Like all other MPs, I have many stories of local generosity, from the schoolchildren who set up lemonade stalls in the street, the Ballarat Regional Multicultural Council's concert to assist the people of the Ampara region in Sri Lanka, the City of Ballarat's variety concertâ

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 12.15 p.m. to 12.29 p.m.

talk.start.para: âOther examples of generosity have come from the Anglican church's coffee morning concert and trivia night, the Clunes community donation of the Coloma Day proceeds, the collections taken in Bacchus Marsh and the fundraising concert and the many fundraising activities of Caritas, the Seventh Day Adventists, Oxfam, Red Cross and all of the individual efforts across the Ballarat, Hepburn and Moorabool shires.

speech.para: There are two people to whom I particularly want to pay tribute. The first is Sally Harvey from Lyonville. A few weeks after the tragedy, Sally sent an email to friends in the Hepburn shire. She says, in part:

quote.para: Hello one and all

By now I have spoken to some of you and you will be aware of the project I have embarked on. Thinking about the terrible and almost unbelievable circumstances and ramifications of this tragedy, I wondered what a single mother might do other than making a $10 or so donation which, however useful, is not really the sort of contribution that satisfied my ideal of possibilities available. So I decided to have a performance night extravaganza and make a community event out of it to ensure that as many people as have an urge to have an opportunity to participate and to have a concerted effort to raise a substantial sum to help those in a situation that is affecting young and old alike all over the world.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: â`Australians are dying for a drink' was the message members and senators received at a very important briefing earlier this week. The briefing was conducted by Professor Ian Webster, Chair of the AER Foundation. AER stands for alcohol education and rehabilitation. The foundation is an independent company that was set up in 2001 with a grant from the Australian government. Its charter is to enhance the capacity of the alcohol and other drugs sector to address alcohol and other illicit substance abuse and to promote the responsible consumption of alcohol.

speech.para: Qualitative research was carried out for AER by Quantum Market Research, and interviews were conducted in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia with people 16 years and over. Mr Daryl Smeaton, CEO of the AER Foundation, highlighted the fact that:

quote.para: ... alcohol is a `sacred cow' in Australia. It is an intrinsic part of our social fabric with people reporting a gentle pressure to drink and that choosing not to drink can be confronting for those who do.

speech.para: Daryl Smeaton goes on to say:

quote.para: Individuals describe a reluctance to challenge people who are drinking to excess; the right to drink alcohol is linked to an individual's freedom.

speech.para: The research shows that here in Australia we have a huge problem caused by alcohol misuse, a problem that is increasing in severity and one which receives very little real funding compared with the massive amount of federal funding spent targeting illicit drug users. No other social problems result in such widespread harm to so many Australians. It is a fact that impulsive behaviour caused by excessive use of alcohol is a major factor in the following: 70 to 80 per cent of night-time assaults, 50 per cent of domestic and sexual violence, 50 per cent of deaths from assault, 44 per cent of deaths from fires, 35 per cent of industrial accidents, 34 per cent of deaths from falls and drowning, 30 per cent of all road deaths, 16 per cent of child abuse deaths and 12 per cent of suicides.

What do these percentages mean in reality? It is hard to believe that every year in Australia alcohol misuse contributes to around 3,500 deaths, the majority being avoidable accidents. A further 95,000 Australians are hospitalised. And what is the estimated financial cost of the problem to Australian society? A staggering $7.5 billion, and each and every one of us suffers that burden of harm. Australians need to be shaken awake from their apathy and confront the crisis that is affecting every aspect of our entire community.

And why do I say we have a crisis? The research highlights some frightening findings. I mentioned at the start of my speech that in Australian culture there is an acceptance that getting drunk is part of the Australian way of life.
