Drinking alcohol is seen as a rite of passage into adulthood. The frightening research findings are: nearly half of the respondents believed that getting drunk is an acceptable part of the Australian way of life; one in three believed that binge drinking is okay and that it is only a problem if you do it all the time; one in five believed binge drinking is okay as long as you do not embarrass yourself; one-third said it is okay to drink to excess at home or on special celebrations such as birthdays and anniversaries; and 21 per cent felt that you should not tell another person how much is too much when it comes to drinking. It is frightening, because there seems to be an acceptance of these beliefs.

Society acceptsânay, condones and encouragesâits young people to become part of this binge-drinking culture. Remember what happens in schoolies weeks in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. Next week, across Australia, during orientation week at our universities we will see a week of alcohol abuse and alcohol excess.

Having a bronzed suntan used to be part of being Australian. However, the threat of skin cancer and the Slip, Slop, Slap campaign motivated more and more reasonable behaviour. If Australia can achieve a cultural shift away from the bronzed Aussie image where skin cancer incidences are reducing, then why, oh why, can't we do it with binge drinking?

subdebateinfo.title: Flinders Electorate: Rural Support and Telecommunications Services

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
Mr HUNT
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI want to take this opportunity to announce a series of rural services which will assist the seat of Flinders and residents throughout Bass Coast, Westernport and the Mornington Peninsula, primarily in the area of rural support services and improved telecommunications services. I want to congratulate those individuals and community groups that have fought hard for these services.

speech.para: My first announcement is about the Grantville rural transaction centre. I am delighted to inform the House that the Grantville rural transaction centre will officially open on 19 March 2005. One month from now we will see a new centre opening on the main highway which will provide a range of new and enhanced services: (1) it will provide local government services (2) it will be a Centrelink access point (3) it will have Medicare Easy Claim facilities and (4) most important of all the different facilities, the Grantville transaction centre will include medical rooms. Already, thanks to the work of Bass Coast Shire Council, particularly Councillor John Hulley, who has done a tremendous job, and Helen Padalini, also from the Bass Coast Shire Council, there will be a doctor who will visit there on a part-time basis. That is a tremendous outcome and a great result for the towns of Corinella, Coronet Bay, Glen Forbes, Kernot, Almurta and, of course, Grantville and the town of Bass itself. On 19 March, along with a series of other facilities which come with it, the Bass Coast Shire Grantville rural transaction centre will be opened. That is great step forward. I want to congratulate all those involvedâin particular, the community, led by Councillor John Hulley and Helen Padalini, and the broader community in general.

My next announcement concerns a series of mobile and broadband telephony services which have been increased or will be increased across Flinders. In relation to mobile phone coverage, Optus has installed 10 new mobile sites over the past two years. Significantly, it plans to improve mobile coverage within the seat of Flinders in at least eight areas over the coming two years in Blairgowrie Beach, Rye, central Rosebud, east Rosebud, the Osborne area of Mount Martha, central Moorooduc, Tooradin and north Lang Lang. There will be improved mobile phone coverage from Optus in all those areas. Similarlyâand this is one of the benefits of competitionâTelstra has increased and will increase both its broadband and its mobile coverage throughout the Mornington Peninsula and Westernport areas. It has done so over the last few years and will do so in the coming few years. Broadbandâand I am delighted to say thisâhas recently been extended to Crib Point, Fingal, Flinders, Pearcedale, Shoreham, Warneet, Tyabb and Devon Meadows. Over the coming 16 months broadband is planned for Koo Wee Rup, Grantville, Corinella, Main Ridge, Red Hill, Tooradin, Newhaven and San Remo. All of those areas will have increased broadband services. I am delighted with the result and pleased to have been able to work with the community on those outcomes in each of those areas.

In addition to that, mobile coverage has already been extended in Ventnor, Anderson, Newhaven, Hastings, Cranbourne, Tooradin, Blairgowrie and Sorrento and will be extended to Rosebud, Cranbourne and Balnarring. Hopefully, it will also be extended to Shoreham, Boneo, Moondah Beach and other areas on the Mornington Peninsula. Taken together, that is a tremendous set of initiatives. I believe that we have made real progress. Something as simple as a payphone can make a difference to those who can neither afford nor have access to telephony within their own homes. There will be four new installations in our area that will be completed in the next 18 months. They include a new payphone for Eramosa Road in Somerville, Josephine Avenue in west Cranbourne, Point Nepean Road in Rosebud and also Mathis Avenue in Tootgarook, amongst others. Telecommunications and medical services are critical. On both of those fronts we are making tremendous progress. I am delighted to inform the House of this, and I thank the community. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI want to add my support to the growing number of calls for the upcoming Ashes series to be broadcast on free-to-air television. I am sure we all have stories from our families about our fathers or grandfathers sitting there wrapped up in a blankets on a cold winter's night in front of the old radiogram listening to the broadcasts of the Ashes tours of England in the fifties and sixties. In my family there is a story of my dad falling asleep on the floor listening to the test cricket coverage in the middle of the night. I suspect there are a number of members of this chamber who have similar memories of their introduction to Ashes cricket.

speech.para: The government needs to act, and act now, if it is to preserve those experiences in the lives of our current generation of young cricket fans. The government has itself acknowledged the importance of events like the Ashes test series to our sense of national identity and pride by including them in the antisiphoning scheme set up in the Broadcasting Services Act. The purpose of the scheme, we are told, is to protect the access of Australian viewers to events of national importance and cultural significance on free-to-air television by preventing pay TV operators from siphoning off television coverage of those events before free-to-air broadcasters have an opportunity to obtain broadcasting rights.

The problem is that the upcoming Ashes series has fallen through the gaps in the government's antisiphoning scheme and at this stage will only be seen by the 25 per cent of Australians who have access to pay TV. So far the government has adopted a hands-off approach which is totally indifferent to the concerns of ordinary sports fans in my electorate. For example, in answer to a question in the Senate on 18 November last year the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts said:

quote.para: The acquisition of broadcast rights is, I am sure all would agree, a commercial decision for the relevant broadcasters.

speech.para: The minister went on to say:

quote.para: Ultimately, the government would not as a matter of principle dictate day-to-day decisions on programming which are taken by either the national or commercial broadcasters.

speech.para: We are not asking the minister to do the networks' job for them, but we are asking the minister to do her jobâthat is, to protect the interests of the average Australian viewer like those in my electorate. The truth is that Channel 9 has grabbed so many exclusive rights to major sporting events that it cannot do justice to any of them. We have seen a fall in attendances at football matches and cricket matches because the public is not given enough coverage to maintain the public interest in these sports. Now with the Ashes we see the true damage done to our Australian way of life as this government allows our great sporting tradition to be used for profit by a few media moguls.

Last year, for example, my constituents complained that they were not able to see their favourite AFL team on free-to-air television. They did not understand why they had to give up their Friday night indoor bowls or other activities if they wanted to see their rugby league match of the round. You have to ask yourself: who decided to move the rugby league games? Who decided that Channel 9 would not take this year's Ashes tour? Who decided that regional Queenslanders could only watch Aussie rules after 11 p.m.? Of course it is the same people who stand to gain the most by forcing sports fans onto pay TV. Once again we see regional Australians suffering as this government does everything it can to give Mr Murdoch and Mr Packer everything they want.

At the moment the ABC are the only ones in there having a go. The ABC are negotiating over broadcast rights for the Ashes with the England and Wales Cricket Board, but they need help from the government to give them the best possible chance of securing free-to-air broadcast rights. In the Senate estimates hearings earlier this week Mr Russell Balding explained that the ABC could be assisted by the minister keeping the Ashes tour on the antisiphoning listâand not accede to the request by the English cricket board to de-list the Ashes seriesâand would like the parliament to consider lifting the genre restrictions on the ABC's second digital channel. Of course the ALP has gotten behind that call and is asking the minister to do those things to give the ABC the best chance possible of broadcasting the Ashes. The people of Central Queensland have had enough. They demand that this government does whatever is necessary to ensure the 2005 Ashes series is broadcast live and free to air for all Australians. Otherwise it will no longer be a question of the game never being the same but rather that the game will simple cease to be.

talk.start.para: âI acknowledge the member for Capricornia, who joins a long list of people from the opposition speaking about antisiphoning but coming up with simply no concrete solution to coverage of the Ashes series, except suggesting that somebody steps in or we protect the interest of Australian viewers. How relative things are. Just eight years ago damage to the Australian way of life was no jobs, inflation, interest rates, collapsing businesses and no hope for ordinary Australians, and now damage to the Australian way of life is not having coverage of the Ashes series locked in a few weeks before the first test.

speech.para: I rise to continue my remarks from Monday on the ongoing humanitarian and human rights crisis in Darfur in Western Sudan. I am driven to make these comments because of my time on the Sudanese border just one month ago at a time when President Mubarak was announcing a package of aid and economic cooperation from Egypt for Sudan. It is of great concern to me that within that country, as one examines the current situation in Darfur, we are seeing shades of Rwandaâthe great lesson in public policy of the last century about inaction and indecisiveness. Those atrocities in Rwanda ring loudly in the ears of anyone who was involved in international aid and reconstruction over the last decade.

The causes of this particular conflict are unique, but they have a familiar pattern. Competition back in the 1980s between the nomadic and mainly northern Arabic populations and the more stable grazing and farmland communities further south has led to an administrative system heavily biased in favour of the Arabic tribes, who control 19 of the 24 administrative areas. The Khartoum government has supported that and discriminated against and marginalised the African communities by providing support to the Janjaweed to suppress the non-Arab populations. Janjaweed is a colloquial expression which means `man with a gun on a horse'. These militiamen are primarily members of a nomadic Arab tribe who have lighter skin than their African counterparts.

Earlier this month, the United Nations special inquiry found that attacks by the Janjaweed militia were occurring with the acquiescence of state officials, and that is the problem: the notion of state sovereignty and whether we can intervene in situations like this. It flows on from 18 September 2004, when the United Nations Security Council passed resolution 1594 establishing a commission of inquiry and raising the possibility of sanctions against Sudan if it did not act to stop attacks against civilians and allow humanitarian agencies to do their good work without hindrance.

Jan Pronk, the UN's special representative, commented in his report that the el-Bashir government had failed to stop the Janjaweed. According to that reportâand, again, doesn't this sound like Rwanda or echoes of the Congo, where there have been 70,000 deaths each and every year for two decadesâthere has been indiscriminate and widespread killing and bombing of civilians; the forcible transfer of 1.85 million Darfur civilians; the creation of 1.65 million internally displaced persons, with over 200,000 refugees fleeing across the border to Chad; the destruction of 2,000 villages and hamlets; the systematic perpetration of rape and violence, including abduction, torture and gang rape of women and girls; the plundering and looting of civilian property; the torture and inhumane treatment of civiliansâand the list goes on.

The Australian government wrote to the President of the United Nations Security Council on 28 January this year, urging action to prevent further violence in Darfur. The Australian government has called for the introduction of targeted measures, such as individual travel bans and asset seizures, to bring pressure to bear on the parties. We know that these are important steps but of limited impact unless they are coordinated through the UN. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has already indicated that, if requested by the United Nations, Australia would consider sending assistance or a small peacekeeping force.

I commend the Australian government, and I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs for his continued support of humanitarian efforts in Darfur and for urging a cessation of violence. It is clear from those actions of Minister Downer that the Australian government is committed to supporting those international efforts fully to end this appalling tragedy. The echo of Rwanda in our ears is heard still and also that famous comment of our former foreign minister that there is no peacekeeping possible when there is no peace to keepâand I hope I have paraphrased him correctly. We must build consensus. We must ensure that we act before it is too late. Africa's ethnic and tribal disputes must not be considered as a matter of national sovereignty and ignored. The spill-over effect to other economies is substantial. The instability that leads to erosion and loss of physical, financial, human and social capital is enormous.

talk.start.para: âI want to speak about the effects of section 21 of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and in particular about its effects and the unreasonable hardship it is causing to one of my constituents, Ian Emery, and his family, and to many other former public servants. Changes were made in 2001 to ensure that all federal public servants on compensation received 75 per cent of their former salary. The level of 75 per cent was promoted in the compensation scheme's charter. The changes to section 21 of the above act ensured that all federal public servants who remained on ongoing compensation payments received that amount of former salary. These changes fail to include Mr Emery or the cohort group that he belongs to of some 1,500 former public servants, some of whom are receiving as little as 40 per cent of former salary. Mr Emery received a voluntary redundancy package and remains on ongoing compensation payments because Comcare's support for invalidity and retirement was not accepted by the retirement benefits office.

speech.para: While sections 19, 20 and 21 under the SRC Act were originally introduced to avoid double-dippingâprior to 1988 officers were actually entitled to receive payments both from ComSuper and Comcareâit was at no time the intention of the original legislation to create further disadvantage to those falling within the provisions of sections 19, 20 and 21. Mr Emery's financial hardship is further compounded by the reduction of his wife's parenting allowance by some 80 per cent as a result of the CPI increases that Mr Emery is paid. It reduces his wife's payment by 50 per cent on each increase. This has effectively reduced Mrs Emery's parenting allowance from $370 to just $70 per fortnight.

The two areas of concern under the SRC Act which I would like to draw to the attention of the House are as follows: firstly, the deeming provisions for lump sum superannuation payments and, secondly, the discounting of the weekly compensation payments by five per cent to take account of the amount that the employees are required to pay as a compulsory contribution to superannuation. The only explanation for this deduction offered by Department of Employment and Workplace Relations is stated in their training manualâthat is, `because it came out before'. It is simply that. There is no other reason. Just because it happened in the past, it continues to happen now.

Under section 21 of the SRC Act the deeming provisions for lump sum superannuation payments prescribe the application of a notional rate of 10 per cent per annum. Provisions apply when a person in receipt of compensation exits from employment under voluntary redundancy provisions and takes superannuation entitlements as a lump sum. To determine the notional weekly value of the superannuation lump sum benefit, it is divided by 520. This divisor assumes that over the long-term period invested at 10 per cent there will be a certain specific return. This rate was set in 1988 when interest rates were much higher. A former employee in receipt of both a compensation related payment and a lump sum has the amount of weekly payments reduced by the method set out, which I have just explained. Each year, therefore, it is assumed that the superannuation lump sum is generating an earning rate of 10 per cent. The fortnightly compensation payment, under the SRC Act, is reduced accordingly. Hence the inequality in what is taking place today.

For the past 10 years, Mr Emery's lump sum payment has been deemed with 11 per cent, which means a fortnightly deduction of $542 from his compensation payment. This has resulted in the recovery by the federal government of more than the total amount of $141,000 that Mr Emery had originally received in his voluntary redundancy package in 1994. Mr Emery's case is a special case, as he and his wife and three young children are not only financially affected by the impact of section 21 but his wife's parenting allowance is also reduced by more than $300 per fortnight. I am sure members everywhere in this House can understand the extreme hardship that this person and his family are suffering, along with 1,500 other former public servants who are treated in a very inequitable way by the provisions under this act, which can be fixed. It was never the intention of this act to do this to people.

For employees who continue to work, the five per cent deduction from their salary accumulates a benefit which is repaid as a lump sum plus earnings on retirement. In contrast, the five per cent deduction is lost to Mr Emery forever, which is contrary to the intention of the current legislation. The intention of this superannuation deduction is clearly spelt out in Comcare's letter to the Superannuated Commonwealth Officers' Association Federal Council dated 18 March 2002, which states that the deduction is meant to continue a benefit. It does not in Mr Emery's case or in the cases of those other people it affects.

The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations appears to have failed to recognise this fact. I have written to them, I have written to the minister and I will continue to pursue this injustice until this area is fixed. The situation can easily be remedied in three ways: first, by adjusting the 10 per cent deeming rate to deeming rates used by other government departments; second, by either stopping the practice of discounting weekly compensation payments by five per cent or placing contributions into the fund that accrues the benefit; and, third, by immediately supporting an act of grace support for superannuation deductions made for those no longer in the fund. I believe, as I believe all other members in this place would, that we need to make this right, because it is hurting people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to say that James Cook University in North Queensland has done it again. James Cook is arguably now the leading regional university in Australia. Headquartered in Townsville, under the leadership of Vice-Chancellor Bernard Moulden, the university has powered ahead. Next week, after the conclusion of orientation week, university studies will begin and degrees in rehabilitation sciences will be available at James Cook for the first time. I am very pleased to say that the federal government has contributed significantly to these new degrees through the provision of some $6 million in capital to build a new rehabilitation sciences building.

speech.para: The building is state of the art. It will provide the best facilities of its type in Australia out of any of the universities in this country. It is a credit to James Cook University and to executive dean Professor Ian Wronski in what they have been able to achieve in the area of rehabilitation sciences. Many university buildings are just a set of walls and some windows; this building has been designed for the tropics and as a pleasant workspace. More than that, senior staff have been to other universities to take all of the best ideas and incorporate them in the new facility at James Cook. When the students enter the building next Monday, they are going to be delighted. The students themselves have voted with their applications. For every place that was available in the new courses, there were nine applicants. That is incredible and it is a great tribute to James Cook that students want to attend its rehabilitation sciences courses.

The new courses are integral to further developing high-quality tertiary education in North Queensland. Until now, students wishing to do degrees in rehabilitation sciences have had to go to Brisbane for their courses. I believe, as the university believes, that students who study locally will remain locally. It is particularly important in regional Australia that we have our fair share of scientists and practitioners to make sure that our community is properly serviced.

The degrees in physiotherapy and speech therapy came in response to the shortage of allied health professionals in Queensland, particularly in rural regions. The expansion of JCU's health and rehabilitation sciences degree has brought an extra 200 students to JCU. The degree headquarters will house a state-of-the-art sports performance measurement facilityâthe first of its kind outside a major Australian metropolitan centre.

But that is not all; James Cook has recognised there is more to do. We are already looking to the future, and in the next university year, starting in 2006, a new veterinary science course will begin. This will also be part of the health precinct that has been built at JCU. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you may say: why is veterinary science of interest in the health precinct? What it will be looking at and specialising in is the transfer of diseases in animals to humans, known scientifically as the process of zoonosis. We will see a tropical university looking at these sorts of things through a new vet science degree.

Then there is the tropical sciences research precinct which will be established. About $80 million will go into that. It is very exciting because it will be part of a collaboration and co-location with the reef CRC, Marine Science, CSIRO, the DPR&F, BSES and so on. It is very exciting. In 10 years we will see James Cook in the top five research universities in the world for tropical sciences. It is a tremendous achievement from a university that in 1997 did not know how it was going to pay its salaries for the next week. Congratulations to James Cook University and its leadership. You have done well and you are going to do even better.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister confirm that unregulated foreign betting exchanges are using their websites to actively target Australians with sports and race betting products in competition with legal wagering offered by Australian companies thus depriving the Federal Treasury of GST revenue and the states and community groups of gambling tax.

(2) Can the Minister confirm that one of the organisations involved in this new form of internet gambling, Betfair, now has a senior executive permanently stationed in Australia to directly promote this service to Australian gamblers.

(3) Is it the case that unregulated betting exchanges allow multiple real-time bets on virtually any sport and any outcome; if so, does this development have the potential to increase problem gambling and corruption in sport.

(4) Can the Minister confirm that in the UK, where betting exchanges originated, gambling activity has increased dramatically resulting in the British Racing Authority asking the UK Government to conduct a Royal Commission into the activities of betting exchanges.
(5) Why has the Government not acted to crack down on the foreign betting exchanges.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Interactive wagering and lotteries are not prohibited under the Interactive Gambling Act 2001 (IGA). To the extent that betting exchanges retain the inherent characteristics of a wagering service, they are not, therefore, prohibited in Australia.

The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts conducted the statutory review of the operation of the IGA. The objective of the IGA is to minimise potential social harm attributable to new and innovative forms of gambling, and betting exchanges were considered in this context. The review found that there was no compelling evidence to suggest that betting exchanges were likely to contribute to an increase in the level of problem gambling. The previous Minister announced the Government's decision not take any regulatory action specifically in relation to betting exchanges on 12 July 2004.

The licensing and regulation of gambling services and the revenue received from them is a matter for State and Territory Governments. Any questions about GST revenue would need to be directed to the Treasurer.
(2) I am unable to comment on the movements of employees of private companies.
(3) See the response to part (1).

(4) I understand the British Horseracing Board (BHB) called for an Independent Commission of Inquiry into betting exchanges in October of 2003. The UK Government has prepared a draft gambling bill, aimed at modernising UK gambling regulation. I understand the BHB has been heavily involved in this process, particularly in relation to betting exchanges.
The bill has been subject to the scrutiny of a Joint House Committee of the UK Parliament.

I understand that the BHB urged the Committee examining the bill to provide the proposed Gambling Commission (that would be established by the bill) with powers of investigation in relation to betting exchanges, among other things.

The Joint Committee's final report of 7 April 2004 concluded that there was nothing intrinsically wrong with betting exchanges but supported the need for licensing for both government revenue and fraud investigation reasons. The Committee repeatedly noted the superior audit trail available from betting exchanges and the willing co-operation of the leading operator, Betfair.
(5) See the response to part (1).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

(2) Is it the case that the Government of India requires that it own a controlling interest in a company before it allows it to operate in India.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

answer.para: (1) None. Telstra has advised that while some of its outsourced projects have been awarded to multinational firms that are undertaking part or all of the work in India, Telstra does not operate in India.
(2) The question of ownership conditions imposed by the Government of India on companies operating in India are a matter for the Government of India.
(3) Telstra has advised that it does not operate in India. See part (1).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 3042 (Hansard, 15 June 2004, page 29858), which jobs is Telstra proposing to move offshore and what are the details.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

quote.para: Further to the answer to part (2) of question No. 3435 (Hansard, 1 June 2004, page 29466) can the Minister explain why it is desirable to allow further concentration of media ownership in Australia by Australia's two principal media proprietors owning both newspapers and television stations in Australia's metropolitan markets.

The Government's previous media ownership reform bill lapsed following the calling of the election. The Government now has a further opportunity to consider its approach to media ownership reform, and as part of this process it will be consulting with stakeholders about the best means of implementing its commitment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister read the article titled âNationals flag serious concerns about media lawsâ published in The Australian Financial Review on 4 November 2004.

(2) In respect of the report that, in relation to the intention to remove cross-media and foreign ownership laws or to draft a new plan, the Member for Page sees the need for the Government to look closely at the Trade Practices Act 1974, can the Minister explain what changes may need to be made to that Act; if not, why not.

Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

(2) In respect of the report that the Minister is considering whether to introduce the original media ownership bill or to introduce the form of the bill which contains concession that the Government had previously agreed to protect diversity, has the Minister met with independent Senators to discuss this issue; if not why not; if so, what was the outcome of those meetings.

answer.para: (1) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 17 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister read the article titled âMedia law review to look at digital effectsâ in The Australian Financial Review on 10 November 2004.

(2) In respect of the report that the Minister claims the Government will ensure that consumers can access more, not less, content and that the Minister needs to protect and promote diversity, can the Minister guarantee that the proposed legislation will prevent further concentration of media ownership in Australia; if so, how; if not, why not.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 18 November 2004:

question.para: (1) What was the nature of the Governor-General's participation in the national counter-terrorism exercise known as Mercury 04?
(2) Did the Governor-General's participation in the Mercury 04 exercise relate to procedures for callingout of the Australian Defence Force?
(3) Has the Governor-General participated in any other counter-terrorism or other emergency preparedness exercises; if so, what has been the nature of the Governor-General's involvement?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) As the first ever multi-jurisdictional counter-terrorism exercise, Mercury 04 was the largest counter-terrorism exercise ever conducted in Australia, involving the Australian Government and the governments of Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory.

The Governor-General participated in exercise Mercury 04 through simulated Executive Council meetings. The purpose of these meetings was for the Governor-General, acting on the advice of senior ministers, to consider applications for call out of the Australian Defence Force in support of state and territory civilian authorities, in accordance with arrangements set out under the National Counter-Terrorism Plan.

During the exercise, the Governor-General also visited the National Crisis Centre and Exercise Control Central, both of which were located in the Protective Security Coordination Centre of the Attorney-General's Department.
(2) See above.

(3) As indicated above, Mercury 04 was the first exercise of its type and scope conducted in Australia. I am advised that the Governor-General has not participated directly in previous counter-terrorism exercises, although he has been briefed on issues relating to these exercises. The Official Secretary to the Governor-General has represented the Governor-General in previous annual national counter-terrorism exercises by participating in simulated Executive Council meetings to consider applications for call out of the Australian Defence Force.

answer.para: (1) to (3) I am advised by the Official Secretary to the Governor-General that requests for the granting of Vice Regal Patronage are considered on a case by case basis and on their merits. Factors such as, but not confined to, the nature and aims of the organisation, its financial status and source of funding, the degree to which the organisation has a national focus, and evidence of long standing credibility, are taken into consideration.

I am also advised that the Office of the Official Secretary to the Governor-General consults officials from government departments, business and community groups and academia as necessary in formulating advice for the Governor-General and Mrs Jeffery.

subdebateinfo.title: Howard Government: Continuity of Government Plans
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 153)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 18 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Can he confirm that the Government has Continuity of Government plans to minimise the impact of a terrorist attack or other emergency on the Executive Government and to ensure an early return to normal government functioning.

(2) What funds or resources have been allocated to the development or enhancement of facilities outside Canberra which would allow the Governor-General or an Administrator of the Commonwealth, the Prime Minister and other Ministers and key public servants to carry out government decision making and communicate with the Australian public in the aftermath of a large-scale attack on the Commonwealth Parliament.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I can confirm that the Government has Continuity of Government plans. These plans aim to minimise the impact of a national security emergency on critical government operations and provide for the rapid resumption of `near normal' government business under alternate arrangements until normal operations can be resumed.

(2) I am advised that, wherever practicable, the plan relies on the use of existing facilities, resources and protocols but in some instances, modest additional resources may be required to develop or enhance facilities outside Canberra which would allow the Governor-General or an Administrator of the Commonwealth, the Prime Minister and other Ministers and key public servants to carry out government decision making and communicate with the Australian public in the aftermath of a large-scale attack on the Commonwealth Parliament.

subdebateinfo.title: Howard Government: Continuity of Government Plans
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 155)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 18 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of the first Report of the Continuity of Government Commission in the United States which was sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute and Brookings Institution and funded by the Carnegie, Hewlett Packard, and MacArthur foundations.
(2) Is he aware of the Commission's observation that within the US federal system of government, the Congress is the institution least able to reconstitute itself after a catastrophic attack.

(3) Has his department considered any of the issues discussed in the first Report of the US Continuity of Government Commission, for example, the potential for mass vacancies in the Parliament or large numbers of incapacitated Members or Senators leaving the Parliament unable to function for many months thus leaving a vacuum in constitutional legislative authority; if so, does the Government intend to take any measures to address these issues in the Australian context.

(4) Can he assure the House that any Continuity of Government plans developed by the Commonwealth Government give full weight to the need to protect and, if necessary, re-locate Members of Parliament as well as Members of the Executive.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am advised that the Continuity of Government Commission in the United States issued its first report on the Continuity of Government: Preserving Our Institution - The Continuity of Congress in June 2003.

(2) I am advised that the report states that `the commission chose to begin with Congress because [within the US federal system of government] it is the institution least able to reconstitute itself after a catastrophic attack'. The report also states that `the commission will issue subsequent reports on the continuity of the presidency and the Supreme Court' and notes that `some protections exist for reconstituting the presidency pursuant to the Presidential Succession Act, under [the US] current constitutional framework.'

(3) I am advised that my department has considered the first Report of the US Continuity of Government Commission, including the issue of mass vacancies in the Parliament or large numbers of incapacitated Members or Senators.

Clearly, arrangements for the continued operation of the Parliament, should there be a catastrophic event resulting in mass vacancies or incapacity of Members, are an important part of recovery plans. My department has closely liaised with the Parliamentary Departments in this regard, recognising that business continuity arrangements within their own areas, including planning for significant vacancies, are a matter for them to develop and arrange. The honourable member would be aware that business continuity management is an integral part of the risk management framework, including measures to prevent or minimise the effects of any adverse situation. To this end the government has provided funding to significantly increase security arrangements at Parliament House during the past three years to address these issues in the Australian context.

(4) I am unable for security reasons to discuss in any detail Australian Government Continuity of Government arrangements. Business continuity arrangements in relation to Members of Parliament are the responsibility of Parliamentary Departments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 18 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Would the Minister provide an up-date on the Government's agenda in respect to the full sale of Telstra.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government has consistently stated the importance of the adequacy of rural telecommunications services now and into the future, and has undertaken to address this issue before Telstra is sold.
High quality telecommunications services in regional, rural and remote areas are a key objective of the Government.

The primary focus of the Government in ensuring the adequacy of regional telecommunications services is the implementation of the 39 recommendations made by the Regional Telecommunications (Estens) Inquiry (RTI). These involve arrangements to enhance existing and future telecommunications services in regional, rural and remote Australia.
The Government is implementing its RTI response as a matter of priority.

Services have already improved as a result of the Government's progress to date. But there are still more improvements to be made as recommendations are implemented. The Government is committed to implementing its RTI response in full.

(2) The Government also plans to look at the adequacy of the current telecommunications regulatory regime and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Coonan, is currently conducting a program of visits to rural and regional Australia.
On 13 December 2004, the Government announced a scoping study into the possible sale of the Government's remaining shares in Telstra.
The Government has consistently stated that it has three preconditions for any further sale of Telstra:
Arrangements must be in place to give all Australians, in particular people living in regional Australia, access to adequate telecommunications services;
Passage of sale legislation by Parliament that removes the obligation for the Government to own a minimum of 50.1 per cent of Telstra shares; and
Market conditions being conducive to achieving an appropriate return for taxpayers from the sale.

subdebateinfo.title: Howard Government: Intergovernmental Agreement on Counter-Terrorism Laws
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 168)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Can he confirm that (a) paragraph 3.4 (1) of the Intergovernmental Agreement on Counter-Terrorism Laws (the Agreement) signed at the Council of Australian Governments on 25 June 2004 requires the Commonwealth Government to consult with the States and Territories prior to the making of any regulation listing a terrorist organisation for the purposes of Part 5.3 of the Commonwealth Criminal Code, (b) paragraphs 3.4 (3) and (4) of the Agreement further require the Commonwealth Government to provide the States and Territories with the text of the proposed regulation together with a written brief on the terrorist related activities of the organisation to be listed by the regulation, and to offer an oral briefing by the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, and (c) paragraph 3.4 (6) of the Agreement requires that approval for regulations listing terrorist organisations must be sought and responses from States and Territories must be provided through the Prime Minister and Premiers and Chief Ministers.

(2) In respect of the making of regulations to re-list Al-Qa'ida and Jemaah Islamiyah as terrorist organisations announced by the Attorney-General on 1 September 2004, when and by what means did he consult with and seek the concurrence of the Premiers and Chief Ministers and did he provide the Premiers and Chief Ministers with the text of the proposed regulations, a written briefing and an offer of an oral briefing by the Director-General of ASIO.

(3) In respect of the making of regulations to re-list the Abu Sayyaf Group, Armed Islamic Group, Salafist Group for Call and Combat and Jamiat ul-Ansar as terrorist organisations announced by the Attorney-General on 7 November 2004, when and by what means did he consult with and seek the concurrence of Premiers and Chief Ministers and did he provide the Premiers and Chief Ministers with the text of the proposed regulations, a written briefing and an offer of an oral briefing by the Director-General of ASIO.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Paragraph 3.4(1) of the Intergovernmental Agreement on Counter-Terrorism Laws (the Agreement) provides that âbefore making a regulation specifying a terrorist organisation for the purposes of Part 5.3 of the Commonwealth Criminal Code, the Commonwealth will consult the [states and territories] about itâ.

Paragraphs 3.4(3) and 3.4(4) of the Agreement further provide that âThe Commonwealth will provide the [states and territories] with the text of the proposed regulation and will use its best endeavours to give the other parties a reasonable time to consider and to comment on the proposed regulationâ and that âThe Commonwealth will also provide the [states and territories] with a written brief on the terrorist-related activities of the organisation to be specified by the regulation and offer the [states and territories] an oral briefing by the Director-General of Securityâ.

Paragraph 3.4(6) provides that âApproval for regulations specifying terrorist organisations must be sought, and responses from other parties must be provided, through the Prime Minister and Premiers and Chief Ministersâ.

(2) and (3) The Australian Government considers that the requirements in clause 3.4 of the Agreement do not apply to the re-listing of terrorist organisations. I am advised, however, that the Attorney-General wrote to state and territory attorneys-general on 30 August 2004 to inform them that he had decided to re-list Al-Qa'ida and Jemaah Islamiyah and to provide them with a written briefing prepared by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. The Attorney-General wrote again on 1 November 2004 to inform them that he had decided to re-list the Abu Sayyaf Group, Armed Islamic Group, Salafist Group for Call and Combat and Jamiat ul-Ansar and to provide them with a written briefing prepared by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Does he recall telling the House on 12 March 2002 that in his view, âministerial staff are accountable to the minister and the minister is accountable to the Parliamentâ.

(2) At what point prior to 10 November 2001 did he have conversations with any Minister, staff member or Commonwealth official which cast doubt on whether children from SIEV4 had been thrown overboard as suggested by the Government on 7 October 2001.

(3) Did he have a conversation with the then Minister for Defence on or about 12 October 2001 which went to the veracity of the original report and whether or not subsequent evidence in the form of videos, photos, witness statements or defence reports failed to sustain the original allegation.

(4) In his conversation with the then Minister for Defence on 7 November 2001 did the Minister mention his earlier conversation with the Acting Chief of the Defence Forces Air Marshal Angus Houston; if so, did the Minister's conversation include any expression of doubt over whether or not children had been thrown overboard as indicated in initial government statements.
(5) How many conversations did he have with the then Minister for Defence's aide, Mr Michael Scrafton, and for how long, on 7 November 2001.

(6) Did those conversations at any point carry the implication that one or both parties were aware that neither videos, photos nor witness statements provided evidence that children were thrown overboard because none, in fact, had been.

(7) In his conversations with Mr Scrafton, was any mention made of the photos of the alleged incident previously released by the Government being not in fact photos of children who had been thrown into the water on 7 October 2001.

(8) Does he recall that during his press conference on 19 February 2002 he suggested that he might have had a different recollection of the context of the conversation than Mr Scafton and, as none of the inquiries initiated by the Government reported such a difference, can he explain how he reached this conclusion.

(9) Does he recall saying at his press conference on 19 February 2002 that on 7 November 2001 he had â....asked Miles (Jordana) to go through the material I had already seen or the office receivedâ.
(10) Did any of that material include papers or other documentation about the SIEV4 incident which made no mention of children being thrown overboard.

(11) In respect of Mr Jordana's examination of this material, (a) what documents, videos, photos or witness statements were drawn to his attention either directly, or in verbal briefings, from this process, (b) what information did they contain on whether or not evidence verified the initial government statements, and (c) who briefed him on this material.

(12) When did Mr Jordana, or any one else in the Prime Minister's office, become aware that there was no evidence in videos, photos, or defence reports for the proposition that children on SIEV4 had been thrown overboard.

(13) Did he in any conversation with staff, ministerial colleagues or public servants indicate that he would rather not be briefed on the full circumstances of the SIEV4 children overboard story prior to 10 November 2001.
(14) Did he ask Mr Jordana or any other staff member in the days after the initial report to verify the facts around the interception and sinking of SIEV4 and present them to him.
(15) Did any `talking points' received by him from his staff, his department or the Department of Defence mention the SIEV4 incident and what was the content of that reference.

(16) On 7 November 2001, or at any time afterwards, did Mr Jordana inform him of advice that he had received from Ms Jane Halton regarding doubt his department had that the photos received and made public of the SIEV4 incident verified that children had been thrown overboard.
(17) On how many occasions prior to 10 November 2001 did he discuss the children overboard incident with Ms Jane Halton, what were the dates of their discussions and what advice did she provide.
(18) On how many occasions after 10 November 2001 did he discuss the children overboard incident with Ms Jane Halton, what were the dates of their discussions and what advice did she provide.
(19) On how many occasions prior to 10 November 2001 did he discuss the children overboard incident with Mr Max Moore-Wilton, what were the dates of their discussions and what advice did he provide.
(20) On how many occasions after 10 November 2001 did he discuss the children overboard incident with Mr Max Moore-Wilton, what were the dates of their discussions and what advice did he provide.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) to (20) The Honourable member is referred to the numerous and detailed responses by the Prime Minister regarding these matters already on the parliamentary and public record.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 29 November 2004:

question.para: (1) Is it the case that Broadband service is not available in all areas of the electoral division of Brand; if so, which regions or areas do not have access to Broadband.
(2) Is the Minister aware that a substantial number of commercial enterprises in the electoral division of Brand are unable to obtain Broadband services.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the owners of these businesses are being advised that the reason is that they are either (a) too far from the Exchange, (b) the service is not available due to insufficient pair gains or copper cable, or (c) they are on a rim that does not support ADSL.
(4) Is the Minister aware of the numerous approaches made to Telstra by business owners in the electoral division of Brand regarding their inability to obtain Broadband services.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question, based in part on information provided by Telstra:

answer.para: (1) Broadband services are available in all areas of the electoral division of Brand through a variety of technologies including Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL), Hybrid Fibre Coaxial (HFC), wireless, Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN), one-way satellite and two-way satellite.

(2) As noted in the response to part (1), all businesses are able to access broadband services through either one or more of a number of technologies including Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL), Hybrid Fibre Coaxial (HFC), wireless, Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN), one-way satellite and two-way satellite.

(3) Telstra has advised that a number of business customers are currently unable to receive ADSL services in the electoral division of Brand due to technical barriers such as the distance customers' premises are from their local telephone exchange, and the presence of pair gain equipment or Remote Integrated Multiplexers (RIMs) in the customer access network. There are also a number of alternative broadband providers that offer competitive services to customers in the electoral division of Brand. These include WestNet and EFTel which offer wireless services across a large part of Perth's metropolitan area, e-wire which offers services over its HFC network in Madora, Secret Harbour and Baldivis, and several one-way and two-way satellite providers.

(3) My department has an identified budget allocation for the procurement of professional services in total. This allocation does not differentiate between legal and other professional service fees. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 6 December 2004:

question.para: (1) Has he read the article titled `Courses dropped - tell the students' in The Daily Telegraph on 30 November 2004 which reported that the University of Western Sydney (UWS) recently axed both the Podiatry and Osteopathy courses for 2005 and 2006 and that the Director of the Australian Academy of Osteopaths claimed that by terminating the course the UWS seriously undermined the future of the profession in NSW.

(2) Has he read the article titled `Union rails at closure of courses' in The Australian on 1 December 2004 which reported that staff, students and the professions' national peak bodies were not consulted.
(3) Can he confirm that
(a) the UWS announced the decision to close the courses on 18 November 2004,
(b) staff and students were not consulted or properly notified of the decision,
(c) students received their notification of acceptance for these courses from the University Application Centre three weeks before the decision, and
(d) many students have found it is now too late to apply for other university courses; if not, why not.
(4) Can he say what impact these course closures will have on the osteopathic and podiatric professions and the broader community.
(5) Will he ensure students adversely affected by these course closures are allowed to enrol in other university courses in 2005; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.
(6) Will he have the UWS decision to close these courses and the manner and timing of the closures investigated; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.
(7) Will he ensure university courses in osteopathy and podiatry are available in New South Wales as soon as possible; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (2) and (3) I am aware of the media reports on these issues. The University did not inform me of its decision to suspend the 2005 intake into these courses prior to the announcements reported in the press. I cannot, therefore, confirm that it announced its decision on 18 November 2004 or if it consulted or notified its staff or students of the decision. I am, however, concerned about this matter and the way in which the University appears to have informed applicants. I wrote to the vice-chancellor, Professor Janice Reid, on 8 December 2004 expressing my concerns. I have also decided to include a clause in Funding Agreements from next year that will require all universities to negotiate with my Department before closing specialist courses such as these.

The University has a notice on its website informing students that they can change their preferences with UAC at no charge if they wish to undertake an alternative course at UWS. Students had until 6 January 2005 to change their preferences to other UWS courses.

(4) The University has said that it was not closing the courses but suspending the 2005 and 2006 intakes in order to undertake a course review. The suspension of these courses for those two years, however, may have an impact on the osteopathic and podiatric professions and the Australian Government is concerned about the possible outcomes of this move. I also note that representatives from the professions have expressed their concerns regarding the impact the suspensions will have on the future needs of the community.

(5) Enrolment procedures are a matter for the University and the Universities Admission Centre (UAC). UWS informed students on its web site that they could change their preferences with the UAC at no charge if they wished to undertake any of the alternative courses suggested by UWS.
(6) My Department will be monitoring this situation and will discuss this issue with the University in the next round of Funding Agreement negotiations.

(7) My Department is developing a set of strategic principles for higher education priorities that will guide a national strategic approach to higher education provision across universities and help ensure the protection of national priorities. The principles will help inform the Government in how disciplines designated as national priority areas may be supported.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 9 December 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of the recent decision of the NSW Government to fund inpatient MRI services at Wollongong Hospital.
(2) Is he aware that for the MRI machine at Wollongong Hospital to be financially viable it is necessary for it to conduct outpatient services.

(3) Does he intend to adjust the criteria for future eligibility for Medicare Benefits Scheme (MBS) funding; if so, will the new criteria direct priority for MBS funding away from hospitals with a high private patient workload and give priority to public hospitals; and if they will not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the recent decision of the NSW Government to fund inpatient Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) services at Wollongong Hospital. I am pleased to see the New South Wales State Government meeting its responsibility to provide MRI services to public hospital in-patients.

(2) The Australian Government does not grant Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) eligibility to MRI units within public hospitals to ensure their financial viability. State and Territory Governments are assisted in providing funding towards MRI services in their public hospitals by grants for hospital care provided to them by the Australian Government under the 2003-08 Australian Health Care Agreements.
(3) The criteria for eligibility for MBS funding for MRI services was developed by an expert committee specifically formed for the current expansion of MBS eligibility.

In general, the Australian Government's role in relation to hospitals is to support access to private rather than public in-patient services. The Australian Government already provides funding to State and Territory Governments for public hospitals and public patients under the Australian Health Care Agreements.
